English: A youth's food can enter the stomach of an elder; it is only a youth's ring that cannot slip unto an elder's finger.
Yoruba: Oúnjẹ ọmọ kékeré a máa wọ àgbà nínú; òrùka ọmọ kékeré ni kì í wọ ágbá lọ́wọ́.

English: People have no difficulty paying the money for glorious events; it is the money for trouble that is unpleasant to pay.
Yoruba: Owó ẹ̀yẹ ò sú ẹnií san; tọ̀ràn ni ò súnwọ̀n.

English: A stew does not slush around once inside an elder.
Yoruba: Ọbẹ̀ kì í gbé inú àgbà mì.

English: The filthy person takes advantage of her husband's death for blame; she says since her husband died she has not violated her person with water.
Yoruba: Ọ̀bún ríkú ọkọ tìrànmọ́; ó ní ọjọ́ tí ọkọ òún ti kú òun ò fi omi kan ara.

English: My child's name is Ọ̀gàǹgà; don't you call my child Ògòǹgò any more! Which of the two is a good name.
Yoruba: Ọ̀gà-ǹ-gà lọmọọ̀ mi ń jẹ́, ẹ má pe ọmọọ̀ mi ní Ògò-ǹ-gò mọ́! Èwo lorúkọ rere níbẹ̀?

English: The poisonous cassava has no attraction; it resembles a yam only in vain.
Yoruba: Ọ̀gẹ̀gẹ́ ò lẹ́wà; lásán ló fara wéṣu.

English: The day an elder dies is far better than the day an elder is disgraced.
Yoruba: Ọjọ́ àgbàá kú sàn ju ọjọ́ àgbàá tẹ́.

English: Only one day brings disgrace to a person; the shame is felt every day.
Yoruba: Ọjọ́ kan là ń bàjẹ́, ọjọ́ gbogbo lara ń tini.

English: It takes one day only for one to disgrace oneself; the shame is a daily affair.
Yoruba: Ọjọ́ kan ṣoṣo là ń tẹ́; ojoojúmọ́ lojú ń tini.

English: In all the days the crab has been making oil, it has not filled a pot.
Yoruba: Ọjọ́ tí alákàn-án ti ń ṣepo, kò kún orùbà.

English: “In all the days I have walked this earth I have never seen the like”: that person knows his place.
Yoruba: “Ọjọ́ tí mo ti ḿ bọ̀ n ò rírú ẹ̀ rí”: olúwa ẹ̀ mọ ìwọ̀n ara ẹ̀ ni.

English: It is an avaricious elder that turns himself into a child.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kánjúwà àgbà ní ń sọ ara ẹ̀ dèwe.

English: It is an insatiable chief of the masqueraders cult that stands on tiptoes to watch a performing masquerader.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kánjúwà alágbaà ní ń garùn wo eégún.

English: A man does not cry; hardwood does not ooze sap.
Yoruba: Ọkùnrin kì í ké, akọ igi kì í ṣoje.

English: No wise man ever ties water in a knot in his cloth; no knowledgeable person can tell the number of grains of sand on the earth.
Yoruba: Ọlọgbọ́n kan ò ta kókó omi sáṣọ; ọ̀mọ̀ràn kan ò mọ oye erùpẹ̀ ilẹ̀.

English: The wise person does not consult the Ifá oracle for himself; the knowledgeable person does not install himself a chief; the sharp knife does not carve its own handle.
Yoruba: Ọlọgbọ́n ò tẹ ara ẹ̀ nÍfá; ọ̀mọ̀ràn ò fi ara ẹ̀ joyè; abẹ tó mú ò lè gbẹ́ èkù ara ẹ̀.

English: A child new to eating stews: he shows himself by dripping palm-oil on his chest.
Yoruba: Ọmọ àì-jọbẹ̀-rí tí ń ja epo sáyà.

English: The owner of the earth treads gently on it.
Yoruba: Ọmọ onílẹ̀ á tẹ̀ ẹ́ jẹ́jẹ́.

English: The prince of Ọ̀na Ìṣokùn is sharing out snake meat with his teeth, and another prince says he does not eat such a thing; where did that prince come from?
Yoruba: Ọmọ ọba Ọ̀nà Ìṣokùn ńfi ehín gé ejò, ọmọ ọba kan-án ní òun kì í jẹ ẹ́; ìlú wo lọmọ ọba náà-á ti wá?

English: A child rests his hand on the earth and claims it is as big as a monkey “read chimpanzee”; even if the child is as big as a monkey, is its chest as big as the monkey's?
Yoruba: Ọmọdé dáwọ́tilẹ̀, ó ní òún tó ọ̀bọ; bó tó ọ̀bọ, ó tó gẹ̀gẹ̀ àyàa ẹ̀?

English: A child has three cowries in hand and challenges Èṣù to a game played for money; will three solitary cowries suffice for Èṣù to purchase palm-oil to lick?
Yoruba: Ọmọdé ní ẹẹ́ta lọ́wọ́, ó ní kí Èṣù wá ká ṣeré owó; ẹẹ́ta-á ha tó Èṣùú sú epo lá?

English: The drunkard ignores his misery; the ill-fated person forgets tomorrow.
Yoruba: Ọ̀mùtí gbàgbé ìṣẹ́, alákọrí gbàgbé ọ̀la.

English: The throat cannot accommodate fish-bone.
Yoruba: Ọ̀nà ọ̀fun ò gba egungun ẹja.

English: Problems make hardly any impression on the foal of a horse; its mother is tied down but it grazes nonchalantly about.
Yoruba: Ọ̀ràn ò dun ọmọ ẹṣin; a mú ìyá ẹ̀ so, ó ń jẹ oko kiri.

English: Speech like drunken babble does not befit a venerable person.
Yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ bọ̀tí-bọ̀tí ò yẹ àgbàlagbà.

English: Speech is not pleasant in the mouth of the mother of a thief.
Yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ ò dùn lẹ́nu ìyá olè.

English: What sort of speech can there be in the mouth of the person whose clothes are brown from dirt?
Yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ wo ló wà lẹ́nu alaṣọ pípọ́n?

English: The sun rises and you do not eat corn meal; the sun moves directly overhead and you do not eat yam-flour meal; a visitor arrives for you when the sun is just past the overhead position and you have nothing to entertain him with; and you ask, “Am I not in danger of being disgraced in his eyes”? Aren't you already disgraced in your own eyes? Never mind whether you may be disgraced in others' eyes or not.
Yoruba: Ọ̀sán pọ́n o ò ṣán ẹ̀kọ; oòrún kan àtàrí o ò jẹ àmàlà; àlejòó wà bà ọ ní ìyẹ̀tàrí oòrùn o ò rí nǹkan fún un; o ní “Njẹ́ n ò níí tẹ́ lọ́wọ́ ẹ̀ báyìí”? O ò tíì tẹ́ lọ́wọ́ ara ẹ̀, ká tó ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ wá wípé o ó tẹ̀ẹ́ lọ́wọ́ ẹlòmíràn tàbí o ò níí tẹ́?

English: The fish-eagle cannot catch the kite flying on high; it can only catch Bamidele.
Yoruba: Ọ̀ṣìn ò lè mú àwòdì òkè; Bámidélé lọ̀ṣín lè mú.

English: One never looks good in other people's finery; borrowed trousers do not fit the borrower.
Yoruba: Ọ̀ṣọ́ ọlọ́ṣọ̀ọ́ ò yẹni; ṣòkòtò àgbàbọ̀ ò yẹ́ ọmọ èèyàn.

English: Idle hands are the ones obliged to remove grass specks from their in-law's eyes.
Yoruba: Ọwọ́ àìdilẹ̀ ní ń yọ koríko lójú àna ẹ̀.

English: Honor is always bought dear, filthiness cheap, and idleness at an indifferent price.
Yoruba: Ọ̀wọ́n là ń ra ògo, ọ̀pọ̀ là ń ra ọ̀bùn, iyekíye là ń ra ìmẹ́lẹ́.

English: It is a reckless home owner who is met with alarms when he ventures outside.
Yoruba: Ọ̀yájúu baálé ní ń pàdé ìbòsí lọ́nà.

English: A masochistic woman hardens her head against her husband.
Yoruba: Pamí-nkú obìnrín ṣorí bẹmbẹ sọ́kọ.

English: The most one can expect of the blacksmith is confined to the smithy.
Yoruba: Pátápátá alágbẹ̀dẹ ò ju ilé àrọ lọ.

English: Carefully is the manner in which a beautiful person walks; gently is the manner in which a prince steps.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀lẹ́ larẹwà ń rìn; jẹ́jẹ́ lọmọ ọlọ́jà ń yan.

English: An elderly person's manner of dancing must be very gentle, because the whole body has become worn to a rag.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀lẹ́-pẹ̀lẹ́ nijó àgbà; ara gbogbo ló di àkísà tán.

English: The mud of the Ìjèṣà: it splashes on one and will not be washed off.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀tẹ̀pẹ́tẹ̀ Ìjèṣà, ó ta sẹ́ni lára kò wọ́n.

English: Straight and upright is the way one would walk; it is money that forces one to sneak about.
Yoruba: San là ń rìn; ajé ní ń múni pá kọ̀rọ̀.

English: The insignificant thing is attempting an earth-shaking feat; the person with only nine fingers is lifting a spoon.
Yoruba: Sesere ń dá gọ́ọ́bú; oníkamẹ́sàn-án ń gbé ṣíbí.

English: Move away, move over here! When one moves until one is against the walls of one's father's house, one stands steadfast.
Yoruba: Sún mọ ọ̀hún, sún mọ́ ìhín! Bí a bá kan ògiri ilée baba ẹni, ṣe là ń dúró gbọin-gbọin.

English: The demijohn insults the bottle, saying the latter has a long snout.
Yoruba: Ṣágo ń búgò, ó ló ṣẹnu gbáṣọ́rọ́.

English: The elderly person who acts his proper part will always be respected as an elder.
Yoruba: Ṣàgbà-ṣàgbà ò níí sé àgbà títí láí.

English: The tripe presents itself as fat; the bone presents itself as meat.
Yoruba: Ṣàkì ń ṣe bí ọ̀rá, egungun ń ṣe bí ẹran.

English: Ṣáláporẹ́ does not know its peer inside water.
Yoruba: Ṣáláporẹ́ ò mọ ẹgbẹ́ ẹ̀ nínú omi.

English: Moderate your preening and strutting, beautiful woman of Ṣàpọ́n.
Yoruba: Ṣe bóo ti mọ, ẹlẹ́wàa Ṣàpọ́n.

English: “Who is there whose opinion matters?” is the attitude that makes the farmer come into town dressed only in a loin cloth.
Yoruba: “Ta ní ń bẹ níbẹ̀?” làgbẹ́ fi ń sán ìbàǹtẹ́ wọ̀lú.

English: Who knows O'kolo in Ọ̀yọ́?
Yoruba: Ta ní mọ Òkolo lÓyọ̀ọ́?

English: What would a dog be doing in a mosque?
Yoruba: Ta ní ń jájá ní mọ́ṣáláṣí?

English: At whose dinner table is the dog wagging its tail?
Yoruba: Ta ní ń jẹun tájá ń jùrù?

English: Spinach is never disgraced.
Yoruba: Tẹ̀tẹ̀ kì í tẹ́.

English: The turkey knows towards whom it farts.
Yoruba: Tòlótòló mọ ẹni tó ń yìnbọn ìdí sí.

English: Only an imbecile asserts that there is none like him or her; his or her likes are numerous, numbering more than millions.
Yoruba: Wèrè èèyàn ní ń wípé irú òun ò sí; irú ẹ̀ẹ́ pọ̀ ó ju ẹgbàágbèje lọ.

English: The call goes out for a carpenter and the woodpecker presents itself.
Yoruba: Wọ́n ń pe gbẹ́nàgbẹ́nà ẹyẹ àkókó ń yọjú.

English: “Go buy bean fritters for me so we can eat them together”: that spells uncertainly about one's right to send the person concerned on an errand.
Yoruba: “Yan àkàrà fún mi wá ká jìjọ jẹ ẹ́”: àìtó èèyàn-án rán níṣẹ́ ní ń jẹ́ bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: It is only a mark of respect when one calls Òkóró a kolanut tree; any kolanut that might grow on his head would turn out to be slimy.
Yoruba: Yíyẹ́ là ń yẹ́ Òkóró sí tí à ń pè é nígi obì; obì tí ì bá so lórí ẹ̀ ní ń ya abidún.

English: A child lacks wisdom, and some say that what is important is that the child does not die; what kills more surely than lack of wisdom?
Yoruba: A bímọ kò gbọ́n, a ní kó má ṣàá kú; kí ní ń pa ọmọ bí àìgbọ́n?

English: A sacrifice was prescribed for the vulture, but it refused to sacrifice; a sacrifice was prescribed for the ground-hornbill, but it declined to sacrifice; a sacrifice was prescribed for the pigeon, and it gathered the prescribed materials and made the sacrifice.
Yoruba: A dẹ́bọ fún igúnnugún, ó ní òun kò rú; a dẹ́bọ fún àkàlà, ó ní òun kò rú; a dẹ́bọ fún ẹyẹlé, ẹyẹlé gbẹ́bọ, ó rúbọ.

English: We grab a dog with the hands and it escapes; thereafter we beckon it with two fingers.
Yoruba: A fọwọ́ mú ajá o lọ, a ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ ń fi ìka méjì pè é.

English: You are given some stew and you add water; you must be wiser than the cook.
Yoruba: A fún ọ lọ́bẹ̀ o tami si; o gbọ́n ju ọlọ́bẹ̀ lọ.

English: One does not enter into the water and then run from the cold.
Yoruba: A kì í bọ́ sínú omi tán ká máa sá fún òtútù.

English: One does not engage in a dyeing trade in Ìṣokùń people there wear only white.
Yoruba: A kì í dá aró nÍṣokùń àlà là ń lò.

English: One does not weigh the head down with a load that belongs to the belly.
Yoruba: A kì í dá ẹrù ikùn pa orí.

English: One does not fight to save another person's head only to have a kite carry one's own away.
Yoruba: A kì í du orí olórí kí àwòdì gbé tẹni lọ.

English: One does not compete with another for a chieftaincy title and also show the way to the king's house to the competitor.
Yoruba: A kì í duni lóyè ká fọ̀nà ilée Baálẹ̀ hanni.

English: One does not shave a head in the absence of the owner.
Yoruba: A kì í fá orí lẹ́yìn olórí.

English: One does not leave one elder sitting to walk another elder part of his way.
Yoruba: A kì í fi àgbà sílẹ̀ sin àgbà.

English: One does not dive under water without knowing how to swim.
Yoruba: A kì í fi àì-mọ̀-wẹ̀ mòòkùn.

English: One does not use oneself as an ingredient in a medicine requiring that the ingredients be pulverized.
Yoruba: A kì í fi ara ẹni ṣe oògun alọ̀kúnná.

English: One does not leave cloth in a bundle while bargaining over it.
Yoruba: A kì í fi aṣọ ṣèdìdí yọwó.

English: One does not go to bed while a snake is on the roof.
Yoruba: A kì í fi ejò sórí òrùlé sùn.

English: One does not smear blood (from a woman's deflowering) on a Muslim charm; a de-virgined woman does not give birth to a “female” child.
Yoruba: A kì í fi ẹ̀jẹ̀ ìbálé pa tírà; alákoto ò bí abo ọmọ.

English: One does not ignore leprosy to treat a rash.
Yoruba: A kì í fi ẹ̀tẹ̀ sílẹ̀ pa làpálàpá.

English: One does not brush off antelope meat with squirrel meat.
Yoruba: A kì í fi ẹran ikún gbọn ti àgbọ̀nrín nù.

English: One does not use a sword to kill a snail.
Yoruba: A kì í fi idà pa ìgbín.

English: One does not throw a snail at a god.
Yoruba: A kì í fi ìgbín sọ̀kò sórìṣà.

English: One does not go to bed while there is a fire on one's roof.
Yoruba: A kì í fi iná sórí òrùlé sùn.

English: One does not because of shyness expose oneself to a disease.
Yoruba: A kì í fi ìtìjú kárùn.

English: One does not as a joke say one's mother has collapsed.
Yoruba: A kì í fi ìyá ẹní dákú ṣeré.

English: One does not tease a warrior by saying there is a war (or an invasion.)
Yoruba: A kì í fi ogun dán ẹ̀ṣọ́ wò.

English: One does not hide something in one's hand and yet swear [that one knows nothing about it].
Yoruba: A kì í fi ohun sọ́wọ́ búra.

English: One does not make a gift of someone else's property when it is not one's own.
Yoruba: A kì í fi ohun-olóhun tọrẹ bí kò ṣe tẹni.

English: One does not hide the farm from the pawned worker.
Yoruba: A kì í fi oko sin fún ìwọ̀fà.

English: One does not position the commander of the army at the rear of the column.
Yoruba: A kì í fi olórí ogun ṣe ìfagun.

English: One does not leave the person one has a quarrel with and face his lackey.
Yoruba: A kì í fi oníjà sílẹ̀ ká gbájúmọ́ alápẹpẹ.

English: One does not rely on money to contest a chieftaincy reserved for the strong.
Yoruba: A kì í fi owó du oyè-e alágbára.

English: One does not consume salt according to one's greatness.
Yoruba: A kì í fi ọlá jẹ iyọ̀.

English: One does not show the throat the way to the stomach.
Yoruba: A kì í fi ọ̀nà ikùn han ọ̀fun.

English: One does not show the squirrel the way to the river.
Yoruba: A kì í fi ọ̀nà odò han ikún.

English: One does not ignore one matter to attend to another matter.
Yoruba: A kì í fi ọ̀rọ̀ sílẹ̀ gbọ́ ọ̀rọ̀.

English: One does not grab hold of a person who has pulled a knife.
Yoruba: A kì í gbá ẹni tó yọ̀bẹ mú.

English: One does not carry elephant meat on one's head and dig cricket holes with one's big toe.
Yoruba: A kì í gbé ẹran erin lérí ká máa fẹsẹ̀ wa ihò ìrẹ̀.

English: One does not sit by a river and argue whether the soap will foam or will not foam.
Yoruba: A kì í gbé odò jiyàn-an ọṣẹ́ hó tàbí kò hó.

English: One does not throw a toad away and inquire after its young.
Yoruba: A kì í gbé ọ̀pọ̀lọ́ sọnù ká tún bèrèe jàǹto.

English: One does not carve a tall statue without resting its hand on something.
Yoruba: A kì í gbẹ́ àwòrán gàgàrà ká má fi ọwọ́ ẹ ti nǹkan.

English: One should not expect flight from the flightless chicken; one should not expect striding from a chameleon.
Yoruba: A kì í gbójú-u fífò lé adìẹ àgàgà; a kì í gbójú-u yíyan lé alágẹmọ.

English: One does not deliver a verdict after hearing only one side.
Yoruba: A kì í gbọ́ ẹjọ́ ẹnìkan dájọ́.

English: One does not eat “I almost” in a stew.
Yoruba: A kì í jẹ “Mo fẹ́rẹ̀ẹ́” lọ́bẹ̀.

English: One does not list vultures among edible meats.
Yoruba: A kì í ka igún mọ́ ẹran jíjẹ.

English: One does not count a god's grove as part of the town.
Yoruba: A kì í ka ilé òrìṣà kún ìlú.

English: One does not count a fetus among living children.
Yoruba: A kì í ka oyún inú kún ọmọ ilẹ̀.

English: One does not enumerate children for the parents.
Yoruba: A kì í ka ọmọ fún òbí.

English: One does not so resent having a child that one names it What-is-this-that-has-happened?
Yoruba: A kì í kọ ọmọọ́ bí ká sọ ọ́ ní Èwolódé?

English: One does not chase two rats and avoid coming up with nothing.
Yoruba: A kì í léku méjì ká má pòfo.

English: One does not have children at one's rear and yet refuse food.
Yoruba: A kì í lọ́mọ lẹ́yin kọ oúnjẹ.

English: One does not acknowledge the husband for one's child and also acknowledge her illicit lover.
Yoruba: A kì í mọ ọkọ ọmọ ká tún mọ àlèe rẹ̀.

English: One does not hold a gun carelessly.
Yoruba: A kì í mú ìbọn tetere.

English: One does not opt to work on the farm and also opt to go argue one's case and avoid neglecting one or the other.
Yoruba: A kì í mú oko mú ẹjọ́ kí ọ̀kan má yẹ̀.

English: One does not chain the child of a person who offers too low a price for one's wares.
Yoruba: A kì í mú ọmọ oǹdọ́pọ̀ dè.

English: One does not take a child destined for poverty to Ìlọ́rọ̀.
Yoruba: A kì í mú ọmọ òṣì lọ sí Ìlọ́rọ̀.

English: One does not devote oneself to the home and devote oneself to the farm and not wind up neglecting one of them.
Yoruba: A kì í múlé móko kọ́kan má yẹ̀.

English: One does not have a thousand cowries (or six pence) at home and go chasing abroad for a thousand cowries.
Yoruba: A kì í ní ẹgbàá nílé wá ẹgbàá ròde.

English: One does not kill the imbecile within one's home, because of the day when the one from outside might visit one.
Yoruba: A kì í pa asínwín ilé, nítorí ọjọ́ tí tòde yó bàá wá sílé.

English: One does not kill the vulture; one does not eat the vulture; one does not offer the vulture as a sacrifice to one's head.
Yoruba: A kì í pa igún, a kì í jẹ igún, a kì í fi igún bọrí.

English: One does not dare a wicked person to do his worst.
Yoruba: A kì í pé kí òṣìkà ṣe é ká wò ó.

English: One does not suffer the reputation of being a thief and yet go seeking to dance with kids (baby goats).
Yoruba: A kì í peni lólè ká máa gbé ọmọ ẹran jó.

English: One does not send a shirker to go see what the morning looks like outside.
Yoruba: A kì í rán ọ̀lẹ wo ojú ọjọ́ àárọ̀.

English: One does not collect water from a spring to dump in the deep.
Yoruba: A kì í re nísun lọ dà síbú.

English: One does not see chickens about and throw one's corn to the dog.
Yoruba: A kì í rí adìẹ nílẹ̀ ká da àgbàdo fún ajá.

English: No one ever sees the leavings of the god Orò.
Yoruba: A kì í rí àjẹkù orò.

English: One does not see a bàtá drum on the ground and use one's mouth to mimic its sound.
Yoruba: A kì í rí bàtá nílẹ̀ ká fẹnu sín in jẹ.

English: One does not see leaves lying about and scoop up feces with one's bare hand.
Yoruba: A kì í rí ewé nílẹ̀ ká fọwọ́ fámí.

English: One does not find helpers willing to help with one's load and yet sprout a hump on one's back “from carrying too heavy a load”.
Yoruba: A kì í rí ẹ́ni ranni lẹ́rù ká yọké.

English: One does not see the look on a leopard's face and then taunt the leopard.
Yoruba: A kì í rí ojú ẹkùn ká tọ́ ẹkùn.

English: One does not run from the herald of the masquerader and collide with the masquerader himself.
Yoruba: A kì í sá fún àjíà ká dìgbò lu eégún.

English: One does not walk one's secret lover across a river; the causes of huge disasters are usually insignificant in themselves.
Yoruba: A kì í sin àlè kọjá odò; ohun tí ńṣe ọṣẹ́ ò tó nǹkan.

English: One does not tell an Ọ̀yọ́ person that his knife is sharp, for only then will he say he has not even honed it yet.
Yoruba: A kì í sọ pé abẹ Ọ̀yọ́ mú; nígbà náà ni yó sọ pé bẹ́ẹ̀ ni òun ò tíì pọn.

English: One does not discuss secret matters in the presence of a tattler.
Yoruba: A kì í sọrọ ìkọ̀kọ̀ lójú olófòófó.

English: One cannot be asleep and also be able to vouch for one's anus.
Yoruba: A kì í sùn jẹ́rìí ìdí.

English: One does not flaunt one's ability to make a fist in the face of a leper's child.
Yoruba: A kì í ṣe fáàárí ẹ̀ṣẹ́ dídì sọ́mọ adẹ́tẹ̀.

English: One does not drool in jest in the presence of the child of an epileptic.
Yoruba: A kì í ṣe fáàárí itọ́ dídà sọ́mọ a-kú-wárápá.

English: One does not do a favor and then camp by it.
Yoruba: A kì í ṣoore tán ká lóṣòó tì í.

English: One does not engage in two trades without having one consumed by goats.
Yoruba: A kì í ṣòwò méjì kẹ́ran má jẹ ọ̀kan.

English: One does not wait until the heat of the battle to start looking for palm-leaf midrib.
Yoruba: A kì í ti ojú ogun wẹ́fọ́n.

English: One does not count the fingers of a person who has only nine in his/her presence.
Yoruba: A kì í ti ojú oníka-mẹ́sàn-án kà á.

English: One should not be too embarrassed to eat a jackal with one's host; as he helps himself, one also helps oneself.
Yoruba: A kì í tijú bá baálé ilé jẹ akátá; bó bá mú, ìwọ náà a mú tìẹ.

English: One should not look for a white-clad person in the stall of palm-oil sellers.
Yoruba: A kì í wá aláṣọ-àlà nísọ̀ elépo.

English: One does not wallow in poverty and yet kill an elephant for public distribution.
Yoruba: A kì í wà nínú ìṣẹ́ ká perin tọrẹ.

English: One does not complain about being looked at and be vindicated.
Yoruba: A kì í wíjọ́ọ wíwò ká jàre.

English: One does not praise a child in his presence; only backsliding results.
Yoruba: A kì í yin ọmọdé lójú ara ẹ̀; ìfàsẹ́yìn ní ń kángun ẹ̀.

English: We kneel and sacrifice a ram, and the bàtá drummer shows reluctance to take his leave. Does he wish to inherit a wife?
Yoruba: A kúnlẹ̀ a pàgbò, alubàtá ní “ojú ò fẹ́rakù”; o fẹ́ bá wọn ṣúpó ni?

English: One chases conspiracy away, as though one would have it disappear into the bush.
Yoruba: A lé tẹ̀m̀bẹ̀lẹ̀kun jìnnà bí ẹni pé kó bọ́ jù sígbó.

English: One spreads a mat with the right hand while removing one's pants with the left hand; yet the woman complains that one is not helping her quest for a child.
Yoruba: À n fọ̀tún tẹ́ní, à ń fòsì tú ṣòkòtò, obìnrín ní a kò bá òun gbọ́ tọmọ.

English: One struggles to save the chick from certain death, and it complains that one is preventing it from foraging at the dump.
Yoruba: À ń gba òròmọ adìẹ lọ́wọ́ ikú, ó ní wọn ò jẹ́ kí òun lo̩ jẹ̀ láàtàn.

English: We fight in defence of Ọ̀jà, and Ọ̀jà asks who is fighting in his backyard.
Yoruba: À ń gbèjà Ọ̀jà, Ọ̀já ní ta ní ń jà lẹ́yìnkùlé òun?

English: One curses a child that ìrókò will kill him, and he glances at his rear; does the curse take effect immediately?
Yoruba: A ní ìrókò ni yó pa ọmọdé, ó bojú-wẹ̀yìn; òòjọ́ ní ń jà?

English: The invalid is asked to say, “Tó,” and he complains that he cannot keep saying, “Tó, tò, tó.”
Yoruba: A ní kí olókùnrùn ṣe tó, ó ní òun ò lè ṣe tó, tò, tó.

English: We strive to keep a child from dying, and you say he resembles neither the father nor the mother.
Yoruba: A ní kọ́mọ má kùú, o ní kò jọ bàbá kò jọ ìyá.

English: “We are driven by envy of them” is a bad case to make; a quarrel spawned by jealousy is not easy to settle.
Yoruba: “Àńjùwọ́n” ò ṣéé wí lẹ́jọ́; ìjà ìlara ò tán bọ̀rọ̀.

English: We recite someone's praise names, we intone his attributes, and a person says he does not know who died; we say, “He of the two hundred granaries, he whose yams are plentiful on the farm, he whose corn is abundant in the fields,” and the person asks, “Is the dead person a hunter, or a trader?”
Yoruba: À ń kì í, à ń sà á, ó ní òun ò mọ ẹni tó kú; a ní, “Alákàá ẹgbàá, a-biṣu-wọ̀rọ̀-wọ̀rọ̀-lóko, a-bàgbàdo-tàkì-tàkì-lẹ́gàn”; ó ní, “Ọlọ́dẹ ló kú, tàbí ìnájà?”

English: We recite someone's praise names, we intone his attributes, and a person says he does not know who died; he hears, “Death takes a renowned man, a titled man, whose yams spread like petals, who possesses barns of corn, whose fields are a bounty for birds,” and he asks, “Is the dead man a farmer or a trader?”
Yoruba: À ń kì í, à ń sà á, ó ní òun ò mọ ẹni tó kú; ó ń gbọ́, “Ikú mẹ́rù, Ọ̀pàgá, a-biṣu-ú-ta-bí-òdòdó, a-lábà-ọkà, a-roko-fẹ́yẹ-jẹ”; ó ní, “Àgbẹ̀ ló kú, tàbí ọ̀nájà?”

English: We are discussing pumpkins, a woman asks what we are discussing, and we respond that it is men's talk; after we have gathered the pumpkins, who will cook them?
Yoruba: À ń sọ̀rọ̀ elégédé, obìnrín ń bèrè ohun tí à ń sọ, a ní ọ̀rọ̀ ọkùnrin ni; bí a bá kó elégédé jọ, ta ni yó sè é?

English: We speak of women and someone suggests that we hedge our words and go plant water melon by the stream; who will help in harvesting it?
Yoruba: À ń sọ̀rọ̀ obìnrin, a ní ká sọ́ bàrà ká lọ gbin bàrà sódò; ta ní máa báni pa á?

English: One can tell by looking, and one can tell by taste; a soap seller does not lick her fingers.
Yoruba: A rí i lójú, a mọ̀ ọ́ lẹ́nu; òṣòwò oṣẹ kì í pọ́n-wọ́-lá.

English: We sell guinea-corn, and with the copper coins we redeem the old man.
Yoruba: A ta bàbà, a fowóo bàbà ra baba.

English: We sell guinea-corn, and with the guinea-corn money we buy guinea corn.
Yoruba: A ta bàbà a fowóo bàbà ra bàbà.

English: The gods heed what chameleon proposes.
Yoruba: Àbá alágẹmọ lòrìṣà ń gbà.

English: Plans do not automatically bear fruit; only the faint-hearted do not make plans.
Yoruba: Àbá kì í di òtítọ́; ojo ni kì í jẹ́ ká dá a.

English: Attempts result in achievement; it is faint-heartedness that keeps one from making an effort.
Yoruba: Àbá ní ń di òtítọ́; ojo ni kì í jẹ́ ká da.

English: Unfinished abandoned wall: unable to master it, one befriends it.
Yoruba: Àbàtì àlàpà; a bà á tì, a bá a rẹ́.

English: A treacherous person is not someone to tell profound matters to.
Yoruba: A-bayé-jẹ́ kò ṣéé fìdí ọ̀ràn hàn.

English: A needle cannot be used to make pounded yams.
Yoruba: Abẹ́rẹ́ ò ṣéé gúnyán.

English: A needle that drops into the ocean defies finding.
Yoruba: Abẹ́rẹ́ tó wọnú òkun ò ṣéé wá.

English: Nursing mother, make the herbal decoction in good time; the day is waning.
Yoruba: Abiyamọ, kàgbo wàrà; ọjọ́ ń lọ.

English: A nursing mother does not venture away from home without a cup.
Yoruba: Abiyamọ kì í rìn kó ṣánwọ́ ahá.

English: The nursing mother lies against her child to secure food.
Yoruba: Abiyamọ́ purọ́ mọ́mọọ rẹ̀ jẹun.

English: A nursing mother cups her palm to strike her child.
Yoruba: Abiyamọ́ ṣọwọ́ kòtò lu ọmọọ rẹ̀.

English: Spare-time work is no profession; it is an assignment from one's father that takes all of one's day.
Yoruba: Àbọṣẹ́ kì í ṣe iṣẹ́ òòjọ́; iṣẹ́ẹ baba ẹni ní ń gbani lọ́jọ́ gan-an.

English: The world accepts only adding on.
Yoruba: Àbùkún layé gbà.

English: He who disappoints one teaches one to be more resourceful.
Yoruba: Adánilóró fagbára kọ́ni.

English: A leper must not wait for a bearer of abrasive leaves (eépín  ).
Yoruba: Adẹ́tẹ̀ ò gbọdọ̀ dúró de eléépín.

English: The leper says that he trusts his relatives on a certain matter; he says when he goes on a journey, they would not dare use his sponge to wash themselves.
Yoruba: Adẹ́tẹ̀ẹ́ ní òún sẹ́ ọ̀ràn kan de àwọn ará ilé òun; ó ní bí òún bá lọ sídàálẹ̀, wọn ò jẹ́ fi kàn-ìn-kàn-ìn òun wẹ̀.

English: It is the votive herald-chicken that precedes a dead person.
Yoruba: Adìẹ ìrànà ní ń ṣíwájú òkú.

English: Chicken cannot at this late date bemoan its lack of teeth.
Yoruba: Adìẹ ò lè ti ìwòyí sunkún eyín.

English: A chicken has no knees for cases.
Yoruba: Adìẹ ò lórúnkún ẹjọ́.

English: The chicken sees the snuff seller and enfolds its wings.
Yoruba: Adìẹ́ rí aláásáà, ó pa ìyẹ́ mọ́.

English: Water fowl is no good as a sacrifice to ìpọ̀nrí.
Yoruba: Adìẹ odò ò ṣéé bọ ìpọ̀nrí.

English: Could the small gourd save itself, before we put charms into it?
Yoruba: Àdó gba ara ẹ̀ tẹ́lẹ̀, ká tó fi oògùn sí?

English: He-who-carries-live-coals-in-his-palm does not tarry.
Yoruba: A-fàtẹ́lẹwọ́-fanná kì í dúró.

English: He-who-would-collect-rain-water-in-a-sieve deceives himself.
Yoruba: A-fasẹ́-gbèjò ń tan ara-a rẹ̀ jẹ.

English: The wind is making life difficult for the seller of liquid corn starch; corn flour seller, you had better watch out!
Yoruba: Afẹ́fẹ́ ń da ológìì láàmú; oníyẹ̀fun rọra.

English: There is no disappearing trick better than the availability of a dense forest to disappear into; there is no sacrifice more efficacious than having many people on one's side; there is no “The gods have elevated me” that is higher than the back of a horse.
Yoruba: Àfẹ́ẹ̀rí kan ò ju ká rí igbó ńlá bọ́ sí lọ; ẹbọ kan ò ju ọ̀pọ̀ èèyàn lọ; “Òrìṣá gbé mi lé àtète” kan ò ju orí ẹṣin lọ.

English: He-who-neglects-his-own-affairs-to-care-for-others'-affairs, it is in the middle of the night that his burial is carried out.
Yoruba: A-fi-tiẹ̀-sílẹ̀-gbọ́-tẹni-ẹlẹ́ni, ọ̀gànjọ́ ni wọ́n ńsìnkú-u rẹ̀.

English: The creeper is destroying itself, but it thinks it is destroying its host.
Yoruba: Àfòmọ́ ń ṣe ara-a rẹ̀, ó ní òún ń ṣe igi.

English: Padlocks do not share their secrets with one another.
Yoruba: Àgádágodo ò finú han araa wọn.

English: A sheep does not wake in the morning and droop its mouth.
Yoruba: Àgùntàn ò jí ní kùtùkùyù ṣe ẹnu bọbọ.

English: A wicked elder sows suffering for his children.
Yoruba: Àgbà òṣìkà ń gbin ìyà sílẹ̀ de ọmọọ rẹ̀.

English: Elder, do a favor and remove your eyes from it.
Yoruba: Àgbà ṣoore má wo bẹ̀.

English: A foster child does not become one's own child.
Yoruba: À-gbà-bọ́ ò di tẹni.

English: The maize plant is not a human being; who ever saw children on the back of elephant grass?
Yoruba: Àgbàdo kì í ṣe èèyàn;ta ní ń rí ọmọ lẹ́yìn eèsún?

English: It is completely and securely that a mother (bearing her child on her back) supports the child with a strip of cloth.
Yoruba: Àgbàká labiyamọ ń gbàjá mọ́ ọmọọ rẹ̀.

English: An elder shows a smooth belly to the world; but what he will do is known to him.
Yoruba: Àgbàlagbàá ṣenú kẹrẹndẹn; èyí tó máa ṣe ń bẹ níkùn-un rẹ̀.

English: Òfé, dweller-in-the-corridor, forward as oódẹ́ a sacrifice was prescribed for òfé, but he did not offer it; agánrán went ahead and offered the sacrifice; in the end òfé became a citizen of Ọyọ, while agánrán became a dweller in the bush; and people thought òfé was foolish.
Yoruba: A-gbé-ọ̀ọ̀dẹ̀ bí òfé, a-mọ-ara-í-ré bí oódẹ;a dẹ́bọ fún òfé, òfé ò rú, agánrán gbẹ́bọ, ó rúbọ; àsẹ̀yìnwá àsẹ̀yìnbọ̀ òfé di ará Ọ̀yọ́, agánrán di ará oko; wọ́n rò pé òfé ò gbọ́n.

English: Pumpkin is never bitter in a big household.
Yoruba: Àgbẹ̀jẹ ò korò nílé ńlá.

English: Àgbìgbò, fly warily, for the hunter has arrived in the forest; any àgbìgbò that does not fly warily will wind up in the hunter's bag.
Yoruba: Àgbìgbò, rọra fò, ọdẹ́ ti dé sóko; àgbìgbò tí ò bá rọra fò á bọ́ sápò ọdẹ.

English: The black ram crosses the river and becomes white.
Yoruba: Àgbò dúdú kọjá odò ó di funfun.

English: It is with full voice volume that one recites divination verses for the deaf.
Yoruba: Àgbókan là ń rọ́ Ifá adití.

English: Coconut is no food for birds.
Yoruba: Àgbọn kì í ṣe oúnjẹ ẹyẹ.

English: Tortoise meat is delicious, but there is not enough of it to make a meal.
Yoruba: Ahún dùn;kò tóó jẹ fúnni.

English: Tortoise embarks on a journey and takes his house with it.
Yoruba: Ahún ń re àjò, ó gbé ilée rẹ̀ dání.

English: Tortoise has entered into a narrow-necked pot; now, getting out is a problem.
Yoruba: Ahún wọnú orù, ó ku àtiyọ.

English: Foolishness will be the death of Iṣikań he is told that his mother has died, and he says that when he heard the news he sorely lamented the tragedy; if one's mother dies is it lamentation that is called for?
Yoruba: Àìgbọ́n ni yó pa Iṣikan; a ní ìyáa rẹ̀ẹ́ kú, ó ní nígbà tí òún gbọ́, ṣe ni òún ń dárò; bíyàá ẹní bá kú àárò là ń dá?

English: Lack-of-wisdom-in-youth is imbecility in adulthood.
Yoruba: Àì-gbọ́n-léwe ni à-dàgbà-di-wèrè.

English: It is ineptitude-in-setting-it-down that makes the wine a spoil for the eégún (i.e., that causes the wine to be spilled).
Yoruba: Àì-mọ̀-ọ́-gbé-kalẹ̀ leégún fi ń gba ọtí.

English: Not-knowing-how-to-wash-one's-hands is not-eating-with-elders; a person who knows how to wash his hands will eat with elders.
Yoruba: Àì-mọwọ́-ọ́-wẹ̀ ni àì-bágbà-jẹ; ọmọ tó mọwọ́ọ́ wẹ̀ á bágbà jẹ.

English: Neglect to say, “Here is your's” is what incites the earth's anger.
Yoruba: Àìpé, “Tìrẹ nìyí” ní ń bí ayé nínú.

English: Not-going-to-the-farm, not-going-to-the-river that claps for masqueraders to dance.
Yoruba: Àì-roko, àì-rodò tí ń ṣápẹ́ fún eégún jó.

English: It is abstention from speaking that makes the mouth smell.
Yoruba: Àì-sọ̀rọ̀ ní ń mú ẹnu rùn.

English: A dog born a year ago does not know how to hunt.
Yoruba: Ajá èṣín ò mọdẹ.

English: One should rather commend the dog; the cat does not kill meat for one to eat.
Yoruba: Ajá là bá kí; èse ò pẹran fúnni jẹ.

English: A dog without ears is no good for stalking prey.
Yoruba: Ajá tí ò létí ò ṣéé dẹ̀gbẹ́.

English: It is a dog in whose speed one has faith that one sics at a hare.
Yoruba: Ajá ti erée rẹ̀ẹ́ bá dánilójú là ń dẹ sí ehoro.

English: A dog that swipes salt, what will it do with it?
Yoruba: Ajá tó gbé iyọ̀, kí ni yó fi ṣe?

English: It is a swift dog that one sends after a Kobe antelope.
Yoruba: Ajá tó lè sáré là ń dẹ sí egbin.

English: The person who eats large helpings does not care that there is a famine.
Yoruba: Ajàkàṣù ò mọ̀ bí iyàn-án mú.

English: A-person-who-rises-in-the-morning-without-washing-his-face, one who sees things with yesterday's eyes.
Yoruba: A-jí-má-bọ̀ọ́jú, tí ń fi ojú àná wòran.

English: The elephant is not among the ranks of animals one lies in ambush for.
Yoruba: Àjànàkú kúrò lẹ́ran à ń gọ dè.

English: The elephant is impossible to carry.
Yoruba: Àjànàkú ò ṣéé rù.

English: Tortoise says there is nothing quite like what one knows how to do; it says when it walks through a peanut farm, peanuts keep popping one by one into its mouth.
Yoruba: Ìjàpá ní kò sí oun tó dà bí oun tí a mọ̀ ọ́ ṣe; ó ní bí òún bá ń rìn lóko ẹ̀pà, ọ̀kọ̀ọ̀kan a máa bọ́ sóun lẹ́nu.

English: Tortoise says that since the day it learned the trick of saying yes its neck has ceased to shrink.
Yoruba: Ìjàpá ní ọjọ́ tí òún ti jágbọ́n-ọn òo lọrùn ò ti wọ òun mọ́.

English: The tortoise struts on the farm, the senseless person says it resembles a duck.
Yoruba: Ìjàpá ń yan lóko, aláìlóyeé ní ó jọ pẹ́pẹ́yẹ.

English: Croaking-in-relays is the mark of frogs.
Yoruba: Àjẹ́gbà ni ti kọ̀ǹkọ̀.

English: Leaving-remnants is the indicator of satiation.
Yoruba: Àjẹkù là ń mayo.

English: It is the leavings from his table that the farmer sells.
Yoruba: Àjẹkù làgbẹ̀ ń tà.

English: Long-standing debt, that makes twelve hundred cowries insufficient to spend.
Yoruba: Àjẹsílẹ̀ẹ gbèsè tí ò jẹ́ kí ẹgbẹ̀fà tóó ná.

English: The task one takes on waking in the morning does not flounder.
Yoruba: Àjímú kì í tí.

English: The journey is never so pleasant that the parrot does not return to Ìwó.
Yoruba: Àjò kì í dùn kódídẹ má rèWó.

English: The journey is never so pleasant that the traveler does not return home.
Yoruba: Àjò kì í dùn kónílé má relé.

English: A stranger has eyes, but they do not see.
Yoruba: Àjòjìí lójú, ṣùgbọ́n kò fi ríran.

English: Sitting-without-leaning-the-back-against-something is like standing.
Yoruba: À-jókòó-àì-fẹ̀yìntì, bí ẹní nàró ni.

English: A cornered leopard poses problems.
Yoruba: Àkámọ́ ẹkùn-ún níyọnu.

English: A rag is what one uses as a carrying pad.
Yoruba: Àkísà aṣọ la fi ń ṣe òṣùká.

English: Àko hit the ground and cried out with its whole body.
Yoruba: Àkó balẹ̀, ó fi gbogbo ara kígbe.

English: He-who-plucks-the-African-locustbean-tree-seeds-to-sell spends death's money.
Yoruba: A-ká-ìgbá-tà-á náwó ikú.

English: The palm-wine tapper of Ijaye: instead of looking to his own affairs says Agboroode has been destroyed by invaders.
Yoruba: Akọ̀pẹ Ìjàyè ò gbọ́ tiẹ̀, ó ní ogún kó Agboroode.

English: The wielder of the incantation rattle lifts it, and you respond, “May it be so!”; do you know if he has invoked good or evil?
Yoruba: Aláàjàá gbé e sókè, o ní, “Kó ṣẹ!”; o mọ̀ bí ibi ló wí tàbí ire?

English: A washerman does enter harbor a grudge with the river.
Yoruba: Alágbàfọ̀ kì í bá odò ṣọ̀tá.

English: The person with the cross-bow thinks that the monkey is not clever; the monkey is clever, but it is following its own strategy.
Yoruba: Alákatam̀pòó ṣe bí ọ̀bọ ò gbọ́n; ọ̀bọ́ gbọ́n; tinú ọ̀bọ lọ̀bọ́ ń ṣe.

English: It is the owner of rags who makes sure that needle and thread are available.
Yoruba: Alákìísà ní ń tọ́jú abẹ́rẹ́ tòun tòwú.

English: When the spider wants to engage an enemy, it spins its web around it.
Yoruba: Aláǹtakùn, bí yóò bá ọ jà, a ta ká ọ lára.

English: The spider has woven its web in the sauce-pan; the spoon takes a holiday.
Yoruba: Aláǹtakùnún takùn sí ìṣasùn, ṣíbí gbọludé.

English: The porter cannot carry a horse.
Yoruba: Aláàárù kì í ru ẹṣin.

English: A wastrel “who” uses a dog to stalk fish.
Yoruba: Aláṣedànù tí ń fajá ṣọdẹ ẹja.

English: It is a visitor like a giant rat to whom one offers palm-nuts.
Yoruba: Àlejò bí òkété là ń fi èkùrọ́ lọ̀.

English: A stranger who asks the way will not get lost.
Yoruba: Àlejò tó bèèrè ọ̀nà kò níí sọnù.

English: The woodcock has but one statement: “Ó dilé” (meaning “Time to head for home”) is the cry of the touraco.
Yoruba: Àlùkò ò ní ohùn méjì; “Ó dilé” lagbe ń ké.

English: Disaster-causing legs that drag weeds into town.
Yoruba: Àlùsì ẹsẹ̀ tí ń fa koríko wọ̀lú.

English: The person who knew the way last year does not necessarily know the way this year.
Yoruba: Amọ̀nà èṣí kì í ṣe amọ̀nà ọdún yìí.

English: People who-know-the-answer-yet-ask-the-question, natives of Ọ̀yọ́, if they see you carrying a water-pot they ask whether you are on your way to the farm or the stream.
Yoruba: Amọ̀rànbini Ọ̀yọ́, bí o bá gbé kete lérí, wọn a ní oko lò ń lọ tàbí odò.

English: A wastrel farmer that plants cocoyams.
Yoruba: Amùṣùà àgbẹ̀ tí ń gbin kókò.

English: A wastrel does not know that what is plentiful can be used up.
Yoruba: Àpà èèyàn ò mọ̀ pé ohun tó pọ̀ ọ́ lè tán.

English: The wastrel puts all ten fingers into his mouth; wastrel, a-person-who-eats-with-abandon.
Yoruba: Àpàá fi ọwọ́ mẹ́wẹ̀ẹ̀wá bọ ẹnu; àpà, a-bìjẹun-wọ̀mù-wọ̀mù.

English: The-person-who-kills-and-eats-dogs claims to be afraid of chickens.
Yoruba: Apajájẹ ní ẹ̀rù adìẹ ń ba òun.

English: A-shiftless-person-who-knows-not-what-things-cost rides a horse on rocks.
Yoruba: Àpàkòmọ̀rà, tí ń gẹṣin lórí àpáta.

English: A person who waits patiently for a long time before eating will not eat unwholesome food.
Yoruba: A-pẹ́-ẹ́-jẹ kì í jẹ ìbàjẹ́.

English: It is in furtherance of one's own fortune that one calls the name Temidire.
Yoruba: Àpèmọ́ra là ń pe Tèmídire.

English: When a bachelor becomes old, he makes his own cooking fire.
Yoruba: Àpọ́n dògí ó ṣàrò.

English: A little bit of it is a little bit of it: the policeman's short pants.
Yoruba: Ara ẹ̀ lara ẹ̀: ṣòkòtò ọlọ́pàá.

English: If one has the wherewithal to live a life of ease, one does not gather firewood for sale.
Yoruba: Ara kì í rọni ká ṣẹ́gi ta.

English: One cannot be so much at ease, or so much in pain, that one cannot wake early to consult the oracle.
Yoruba: Ara kì í tu ẹni káká, kí ara ó roni koko, ká má leè jíkàkà dÍfá.

English: Natives of heaven do not sew their hems.
Yoruba: Ará ọ̀run ò ṣẹ́tí aṣọ.

English: The Ààrẹ summons you and you consult the oracle; what if the oracle says all will be well and the Ààrẹ decrees otherwise?
Yoruba: Ààrẹ ń pè ọ́ ò  dÍfá; bÍfá bá fọọre tí Ààrẹ́ fọbi ńkọ́?

English: One-who-saunters-in-front-of-detractors, one-who-struts-before-abusers, those who abuse one have no money at home, only their mouths.
Yoruba: A-rìn-fàà-lójú-akẹ́gàn, a-yan-kàṣà-lojú-abúni, abúni ò lówó nílé ju ẹnuu rẹ̀ lọ.

English: The person who walks casually is the one who will bear a title home; the person who runs fast has no title to show for his efforts.
Yoruba: Arìngbẹ̀rẹ̀ ni yó mùú oyè délé; asárétete ò róyè jẹ.

English: Wrapping-from-waist-to-the-floor is the style of the queen's wrapper; digging-down-to-the-deepest-bottom is the requirement of the dry moat, yàrà.
Yoruba: À-ró-kanlẹ̀ laṣọ ayaba; à-wà-kanlẹ̀ ni ti yàrà.

English: The old person who incurs debt, he says how much of it will he be around to pay?
Yoruba: Arúgbó oǹdágbèsè, ó ní mélòó ni òun óò dúró san níbẹ̀?

English: He-who-hurries-after-riches is on his way to battle; He-who-has-in-abundance is off on his travels; Sooner-or-later-I-will-be-rich is back in his hut, eating roasted yams.
Yoruba: A-sáré-lówó ń bẹ lọ́nà ogun; A-pọ̀ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ ń bẹ lọ́nà èrò; Bó-pẹ́-títí-n-ó-là ń bẹ lábà, ó ń jẹ ẹ̀sun iṣu.

English: Burying-the-dead-without-sharing-in-the-inheritance leads one to poverty.
Yoruba: À-sìnkú-àì-jogún, òṣì ní ń tani.

English: The imbecile said he would torch the house; he was asked not to torch the house; he said he certainly would torch the house; he was told that if he torched the house he would be thrown in it; he said, “That casts the matter in a different light.”
Yoruba: Dò̩dò̩yò̩ ní òun ó ti iná bọlé; wọ́n ní kó má ti iná bọlé; ó ní òun ó sáà ti iná bọlé; wọ́n ní bó bá tiná bọlé àwọn ó sọ ọ́ si; ó ní ìyẹn kẹ̀ ìkan.

English: One-who-throws-stones-at-two-hundred-chickens will be engaged in stone throwing until nightfall.
Yoruba: A-sọ̀kò-sádìẹ-igba, òkò ní ń sọ tí ilẹ̀ẹ́ fi ń ṣú.

English: One-who-turns-play-into-a-fight is always guilty.
Yoruba: A-sọ-aré-dìjà ní ń jẹ̀bi ẹjọ́.

English: Roughhousing keeps the young of the cane rat from learning wisdom.
Yoruba: Àṣàyá kì í jẹ́ kí ọmọ ọ̀yà ó gbọ́n.

English: He-who-frustrates-one, Segba's slave; he broke a gourd and went to Ọ̀yọ́town to hire a calabash stitcher; and a stitcher's fee is six pence.
Yoruba: A-ṣe-kó-súni, ẹrúu Ségbá; ó fọ́ akèrègbè tán ó lọ sóde Ọ̀yọ́ lọ gba onísé wá; bẹ́ẹ̀ni ẹgbàá lowó onísé.

English: What-is-put-aside is what-is-there-to-find; he who puts excrement aside will return to find flies.
Yoruba: À-ṣe-sílẹ̀ làbọ̀wábá; ẹni tó ṣu sílẹ̀ á bọ̀ wá bá eṣinṣin.

English: One taste of wine and the belt snaps; what would happen in the event of drunkenness?
Yoruba: À-ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀-tọ́-ọtí-wò okùn-un bàǹtẹ́ já; bí a bá mu àmuyó ńkọ́?

English: It is an imbecile who is soaked in the rain in the middle of a town.
Yoruba: Aṣiwèrè èèyàn lòjò ìgboro ń pa.

English: Only an imbecile gets into a fight in defence of his town.
Yoruba: Aṣiwèrè èèyàn ní ń gbèjà ìlú-u rẹ̀.

English: Difficult-to-fight as the fight of the market place; the self-conscious person will not run, and the person beating him up will not stop.
Yoruba: Aṣòroójà bí ìjà ọjà; onítìjú ò níí sá; ẹni tí ń nà án ò níí dáwọ́ dúró.

English: A trader in soap does not make big money.
Yoruba: A-ṣòwò-ọṣẹ kì í pa owó ńla.

English: A-person-who-does-a-favor-and-squats-by-it is like a-person-who-has-done-no-favor.
Yoruba: A-ṣoore-jókòó-tì-í, bí aláìṣe ni.

English: White cloth and stains are not friends.
Yoruba: Aṣọ funfun òun àbàwọ́n kì í rẹ́.

English: Cloth fashioned from the bark of the ìrókò tree cannot be wrapped around one's body.
Yoruba: Aṣọ ìrókò ò ṣéé fi bora.

English: Whatever cloth one finds on the vulture belongs to it.
Yoruba: Aṣọ tá a bá rí lára igún, ti igún ni.

English: He-who-spies-on-others-from-behind-their-walls upsets himself; one does as one pleases in one's home.
Yoruba: A-sọ́-ẹ̀yìnkùlé ba araa rẹ̀ nínú jẹ́; ohun tó wuni là ń ṣe nílé ẹni.

English: If one's head was a pot and one gave it to an enemy to inspect, he would say it was irretrievably broken.
Yoruba: Àtàrí ìbá ṣe ìkòkò ká gbé e fún ọ̀tá yẹ̀wò; a ní ó ti fọ́ yányán.

English: The wind is impossible to carry.
Yoruba: Atẹ́gùn ò ṣéé gbé.

English: The palm of the hand is not good for stoking fires.
Yoruba: Àtẹ́lẹwọ́ ò ṣéé fi rúná.

English: Atipo does not recognize beans, he says, “Father, I saw white leaves on the farm.”
Yoruba: Atipo ò mọ erèé; ó ní, “Bàbá, mo réwé funfun lóko.”

English: All-day-long is no match for since-yesterday.
Yoruba: Àtònímòní ò tó àtànámàná.

English: The-seeker-of-all-things-from-God does not yield to impatience.
Yoruba: A-tọrọ-ohun-gbogbo-lọ́wọ́-Ọlọ́run kì í kánjú.

English: He-who-alerts-one-before-he-throws-one is a past master of wrestling.
Yoruba: A-wí-fúnni-kó-tó-dáni, àgbà òmùjà ni.

English: He-who-will-not-listen-to-talk, he-who-will-not-listen-to-counsel, who drinks water with the bare hand.
Yoruba: À-wí-ìgbọ́, àfọ̀-ọ̀-gbọ́ tí ń fi àjèjé ọwọ́ mumi.

English: Previous-instruction enables a child to understand coded speech; a child does not naturally understand codes.
Yoruba: Àwítẹ́lẹ̀ ní ń jẹ́ ọmọ́ gbẹ́nà; ọmọ kì í gbẹ́nà lásán.

English: It is another person's divination that one does not repeat.
Yoruba: Awo aláwo la kì í dá lẹ́ẹ̀mejì.

English: The hawk in the sky eyes the snail-shell slyly; what will it do with a snail.
Yoruba: Àwòdì òkè tí ń wo ìkarahun kọ̀rọ̀, kí ni yó fìgbín ṣe?

English: The elephant's hide cannot be used to fashion a gángan drum.
Yoruba: Awọ erin ò ṣéé ṣe gángan.

English: The hide of a pig is no use for making the gbẹ̀du drum.
Yoruba: Awọ ẹlẹ́dẹ̀ ò ṣéé ṣe gbẹ̀du.

English: The skin of the mouth cannot be used to fashion a drum.
Yoruba: Awọ ẹnu ò ṣéé ṣe ìlù.

English: The Colobus monkey jumps to the ground; it runs for home.
Yoruba: Ààyá bọ́ sílẹ̀, ó bọ́ sílé.

English: The Colobus monkey is wily, but so is Ogungbẹ́ as Ogungbẹ crouches, so the monkey tiptoes.
Yoruba: Àáyá gbọ́n, Ògúngbẹ̀ sì gbọ́n; bí Ògúngbẹ̀ ti ń bẹ̀rẹ̀ ni àáyá ń tiro.

English: The àyàn tree does not accept an axe.
Yoruba: Àyàn ò gbẹdùn.

English: Dry smoked fish is delicious, but what is one to eat before the fish is smoked?
Yoruba: Àyangbẹ ẹjá dùn; ṣùgbọ́n kí la ó jẹ kẹ́já tó yan?

English: The world goes forth, and we follow.
Yoruba: Ayé ń lọ, à ń tọ̀ ọ́.

English: The world is not a thing to exchange threats with; it can inflict disaster on one.
Yoruba: Ayé ò ṣéé bá lérí; wọ́n lè ṣeni léṣe.

English: The world does not deserve to be trusted; if you have a store of wisdom, keep it in you.
Yoruba: Ayé ò ṣéé finú hàn; bí o lọ́gbọ́n, fi síkùn araà rẹ.

English: The executor does not pawn his child; his helper pawns his own.
Yoruba: Baba-ìsìnkú ò fọmọọ rẹ̀ sọfà; alábàáṣe ń fọmọọ rẹ̀ kówó.

English: An unsolicitous host makes for a visitor with no deference.
Yoruba: Baálé àìlọ́wọ̀ ni àlejò àìlọ́wọ̀.

English: The chief of farmers says he has nothing to go to heaven to sell; all he cares about is fair payment for his corn.
Yoruba: Baálẹ̀ àgbẹ̀ẹ́ ní òun ò ní nǹkan-án tà lọ́run, kí owó ọkà òún ṣáà ti pé.

English: “This is what we do” in one place is taboo in another.
Yoruba: “Báyìí là ń ṣe” níbìkan, èèwọ̀ ibòmínìn.

English: If one lives with a maniac one incurs the enmity of the wise; if one shuns iyá leaves one offends the corn-gruel seller.
Yoruba: Bí a bá bá aṣiwèrè gbé, a ó gba odì ọlọgbọ́n; bí a bá bá ewé iyá ṣọ̀tẹ̀, a ó ṣẹ ẹlẹ́kọ.

English: As one castigates ẹrán, one should also castigate ẹràn.
Yoruba: Bí a bá bá ẹrán wí, ká bá ẹràn wí.

English: If one whips a child with the right hand, one embraces it with the left.
Yoruba: Bí a bá fi ọwọ́ ọ̀tún na ọmọ, à fi ọwọ́ òsì fà á mọ́ra.

English: After a joke one gives way to laughter; after satiation one gives way to sleep.
Yoruba: Bí a bá jẹ̀wọ́ tán ẹ̀rín là ń rín; bí a bá yó tán orun ní ń kunni.

English: As one warns the thief, one should also warn the owner of the wayside yams.
Yoruba: Bí a bá kìlọ̀ fólè, ká kìlọ̀ fóníṣu ẹ̀bá ọ̀nà.

English: If one says “Know,” the knowledgeable will know it.
Yoruba: Bí a bá ní mọ̀, ọ̀mọ̀ràn a mọ̀ ọ́.

English: While one weeps, one can still see.
Yoruba: Bí a bá ń sunkún, à máa ríran.

English: If one is sent on an errand like a slave, one carries it out like a freeborn.
Yoruba: Bí a bá ránni níṣẹ́ ẹrú, à fi jẹ́ tọmọ.

English: If one remembers the day of (the loss of) virginity, one should also remember the day of a woman's delivery, and one should remember the vagina that smarts.
Yoruba: Bí a bá rántí ọjọ́ kan ìbálé, ká rántí ọjọ́ kan ìkúnlẹ̀ abiyamọ, ká rántí kan abẹ́ tí ń tani lára.

English: When one sees a devious person one mistakes him for a good person; one talks into a basket and it leaks.
Yoruba: Bí a bá rí èké, à ṣebí èèyàn rere ni; à sọ̀rọ̀ ságbọ̀n a jò.

English: Although one has seen the morning, what about night time?
Yoruba: Bí a bá rí òwúrọ̀, alẹ́ ńkọ́?

English: When one is done discussing a matter one laughs, when one is satiated sleep claims one.
Yoruba: Bí a bá sọ̀rọ̀ tán, ẹrín là ń rín; bí a bá yó tán orun ní ń kunni.

English: If one has committed a great offense, one frees oneself by swearing (innocence).
Yoruba: Bí a bá ṣe ohun ńlá, à fi èpè gba ara ẹni là.

English: If one sells a member of one's household cheap, one will not be able to buy him back at a great value.
Yoruba: Bí a bá ta ará ilé ẹni lọ́pọ̀, a kì í rí i rà lọ́wọ̀n-ọ́n mọ́.

English: If one does not throw a toad into hot water, and then throw it into cold water, it does not know which is better.
Yoruba: Bí a kò bá gbé ọ̀pọ̀lọ́ sọ sínú omi gbígbóná, ká tún gbé e sọ sí tútù, kì í mọ èyí tó sàn.

English: If one is not more clever than the partridge on one's farm, one cannot kill it.
Yoruba: Bí a kò bá gbọ́n ju àparò oko ẹni lọ, a kì í pa á.

English: If one cannot find a bat, one sacrifices a housebat.
Yoruba: Bí a kò bá rádànán, à fòòbẹ̀ ṣẹbọ.

English: If we cannot find a vulture we may not offer a sacrifice; if we cannot find a ground hornbill we may not carry out a ritual.
Yoruba: Bí a kò bá rígún a ò gbọdọ̀ ṣebọ; bí a ò bá rí àkàlà a ò gbọdọ̀ ṣorò.

English: If one does not eat oil because of yams, one will eat yams because of oil.
Yoruba: Bí a kò bá torí iṣu jẹ epo, à torí epo jẹṣu.

English: If one has never had a child, has one not seen chicks flocking after chickens?
Yoruba: Bí a kò bímọ rí, a kò ha rọ́mọ lẹ́yìn adìẹ?

English: If one does not send a message to the market, the market does not send a message to one at home.
Yoruba: Bí a kò ránni sọ́jà, ọjà kì í ránni sílé.

English: If one has never hunted, one would not know the tracks of “it-did-not-go-that-way.”
Yoruba: Bí a kò ṣe ọdẹ rí, a kò lè mọ ẹsẹ̀ẹ kò-lọ-ibẹ̀un.

English: When night comes, one gives the ayò seeds to ayò.
Yoruba: Bí alẹ́ bá lẹ́, à fi ọmọ ayò fún ayò.

English: When night falls, bọnnọ-bọ́nnọ́ goes limp.
Yoruba: Bí alẹ́ bá lẹ́, bọnnọ-bọ́nnọ́ a rẹ̀wẹ̀sì.

English: If night does not fall, the house bat does not fly.
Yoruba: Bí alẹ́ kò lẹ́, òòbẹ̀ kì í fò.

English: If the arms cannot encompass the silk-cotton tree, they may encompass its root.
Yoruba: Bí apá ò ká àràbà, apá lè ká egbò ìdíi rẹ̀.

English: If a terrible epidemic descends on a town, it is confronted with a terrible medicine.
Yoruba: Bí àrùn búburú bá wọ̀lú, oògùn búburú la fi ń wò ó.

English: If a masquerader wishes to disappear into the ground, it cries “Orò!”
Yoruba: Bí eégún ó bàá wọlẹ̀, orò ni ń ṣe.

English: Like play, like play, the makeshift cape became a dress.
Yoruba: Bí eré bí eré, àlàbọrùn-ún dẹ̀wù.

English: After the person with smooth cheeks has stated his or her case, he or she should remember that the person with blemished cheeks will have something to say.
Yoruba: Bí ẹlẹ́rẹ̀kẹ́ régérégé bá ro ẹjọ́ọ tirẹ̀ tán, kó rántí pé ẹlẹ́rẹ̀kẹ́ mẹ́kí á rí rò.

English: If trees fall atop one another, one removes the topmost one first.
Yoruba: Bí igí bá wó lu igi, tòkè là ń kọ́ gbé.

English: When the squirrel has eaten, when the squirrel has drunk, the squirrel looks at the setting sun.
Yoruba: Bí ikún bá jẹ, bí ikún bá mu, ikún a wo oòrùn alẹ́.

English: If the earth catches fire, the toad will hop on a tree.
Yoruba: Bí ilẹ̀ẹ́ bá laná, ọ̀pọ̀lọ́ á fò gun igi.

English: If the town is split into two, one does the will of the heavenly king.
Yoruba: Bí ilú bá dá sí méjì, tọba ọ̀rún là ń ṣe.

English: If a task does not delay one, one does not drag it out.
Yoruba: Bí iṣẹ́ kò pẹ́ ẹni, a kì í pẹ́ iṣẹ́.

English: If a fight is not yet spent, one does not intervene to end it.
Yoruba: Bí kò bá tíì rẹ ìjà, a kì í là á.

English: If a fight is not yet spent, one does not intervene to end it.
Yoruba: Bí kò bá tíì rẹ ìjà, a kì í là á.

English: If a fight is not yet spent, one does not intervene to end it.
Yoruba: Bí kò bá tíì rẹ ìjà, a kì í là á.

English: At the conclusion of a ceremony the acolyte commences to dance, and the onlookers prepare to make their exit.
Yoruba: Bí nǹkan bá tán nílẹ̀, ọmọ ẹbọ a bọ́ síjó, àwọn tó wà níbẹ̀ a múra àti lọ.

English: “If you break I will retie you”; there will be a knot in it.
Yoruba: Bí o bá já n ó so ọ́, kókó yó wà láàárín-in rẹ̀.

English: If you do not understand Ègùn, do you not recognize signs that someone is speaking?
Yoruba: Bí o kò gbọ́ Ègùn, o kò gbọ́ wọ̀yọ̀-wọ̀yọ̀?

English: If you will be a wife to the Olúgbọ́n be a wife to him; if you will be a wife to the Arẹsà be a wife to him, and stop sneaking around hugging walls; a person who would be the wife of the Olúfẹ̀ must gather her affairs into the house.
Yoruba: Bí o máa ṣe aya Olúgbọ́n ṣe aya Olúgbọ́n; bí o máa ṣe aya Arẹsà ṣe aya Arẹsà, kí o yéé pákọ̀kọ̀ lẹ́gbẹ̀ẹ́ ògiri; ẹni tí yó ṣe aya Olúfẹ̀ a kógbá wálé.

English: If a woman has not lived in at least two homes, she never knows which is better.
Yoruba: Bí obìnrin ò bá gbé ilé tó méjì, kì í mọ èyí tó sàn.

English: When day breaks, the trader takes up his trade; the cotton spinner picks up the spindle; the warrior grabs his shield; the farmer gets up with his hoe; the son of the hunter arises with his quiver and his bows; he-who-wakes-and-washes-with-soap makes his way to the river.
Yoruba: Bí ojú bá mọ́, olówò a gbówò; ọ̀rànwú a gbé kẹ́kẹ́; ajagun a gbé apata; àgbẹ̀ a jí tòun tòrúkọ́; ọmọ ọdẹ a jí tapó tọrán; ajíwẹṣẹ a bá odò omi lọ.

English: When the eyes come upon a matter, they must look hard and well.
Yoruba: Bí ojú bá rí ọ̀rọ̀, a wò ó fín.

English: If a youth's eyes do not witness a story, they should be good for hearsay.
Yoruba: Bí ojú ọmọdé ò tó ìtàn, a bá àwígbọ́.

English: When the camwood powder seller grinds the powder, she tests it on her own body.
Yoruba: Bí olósùn-ún bá lọ osùn, araa rẹ̀ ní ń fi dánwò.

English: If the gods take a person with a protruding back, the humpback should make ready.
Yoruba: Bí òrìṣá bá mú ẹlẹ́yìn, kí abuké máa múra sílẹ̀.

English: Like proverbs, like proverbs one plays the ògìdìgbó music;  only the wise can dance to it, and only the knowledgeable know it.
Yoruba: Bí òwe bí òwe là ń lùlù ògìdìgbó; olọgbọ́n ní ń jó o; ọ̀mọ̀ràn ní ń sìí mọ̀ ọ́n.

English: Like proverbs, like proverbs are the pronouncements of Ifá.
Yoruba: Bí òwe bí òwe nIfá ń sọ̀rọ̀.

English: If the filthy person does not know profit, he should know his capital.
Yoruba: Bí ọ̀bùn ò mọ èrè, a mọ ojú owó.

English: If a man sees a snake, and a woman kills it, what matters is that the snake does not escape.
Yoruba: Bí ọkùnrín réjò, tóbìrín pa á, à ní kéjò má ṣáà lọ.

English: Once God has revealed one's enemy to one, he can no longer kill one.
Yoruba: Bí Ọlọ́run-ún bá ti fọ̀tá ẹni hanni, kò lè pani mọ́.

English: If a wise person is cooking yams in an insane way, a knowing person picks them with stakes.
Yoruba: Bí ọlọgbọ́n bá ń fi wèrè se iṣu, ọ̀mọ̀ràn a máa fi gègé yàn án.

English: If a child learns the trick of crying, the mother learns the trick of consoling him or her.
Yoruba: Bí ọmọ́ bá jágbọ́n-ọn kíké, ìyáa rẹ̀ a jágbọ́n-ọn rírẹ̀ ẹ́.

English: If a child learns the trick of dying, his mother should learn the trick of burying.
Yoruba: Bí ọmọ́ bá jágbọ́n-ọn kíkú, ìyá ẹ̀ a jágbọ́n-ọn sísín.

English: When a child is full, he shows his stomach to his father.
Yoruba: Bí ọmọ́ bá yó, a fikùn han baba.

English: If a child expresses gratitude for yesterday's favor, he will receive today's.
Yoruba: Bí ọmọdé bá dúpẹ́ ore àná, a rí tòní gbà.

English: If a youth is felling a tree, an elder will be considering where it will fall.
Yoruba: Bí ọmọdé bá ń bẹ́ igi, àgbàlagbà a máa wo ibi tí yóò wó sí.

English: If a child is an adept ayò player, one defeats him with single seeds.
Yoruba: Bí ọmọdé bá mọ ayò, ẹyọ la ó fi pa á.

English: When a youth falls he looks ahead; when an elder falls he looks behind.
Yoruba: Bí ọmọdé bá ṣubú a wo iwájú; bí àgbá bá ṣubú a wo ẹ̀yìn.

English: If a youth has never seen another person's father's farm, he says no body's father's farm is as large as his father's.
Yoruba: Bí ọmọdé ò bá rí oko baba ẹlòmíràn, a ní kò sí oko baba ẹni tó tó ti baba òun.

English: If a child refuses yesterday's pounded yams, it is stories one treats the child to.
Yoruba: Bí ọmọdé kọ iyán àná, ìtàn la ó pa fún un.

English: If a problem remains long enough, it becomes clever.
Yoruba: Bí ọ̀rán bá pẹ́ nílẹ̀, gbígbọ́n ní ń gbọ́n.

English: If the arms cannot be swung, one carries them on one's head.
Yoruba: Bí ọwọ́ ò bá ṣeé ṣán, à ká a lérí.

English: If guinea worm is becoming an ulcer, one should inform olúgambe.
Yoruba: Bí sòbìyà yó bàá degbò, olúgambe là á wí fún.

English: When emergencies number two, one concentrates on one.
Yoruba: Bí túlàsí bá di méjì, ọ̀kan là ń mú.

English: “Give me one yam” does not precede “Greetings to you on the farm.”
Yoruba: “Bùn mi níṣu kan” kì í ṣáájú “Ẹkú oko òo.”

English: The recent throw-it-all-on-the-floor-that-we-may-redistribute-it inheritance was not well distributed the first time around.
Yoruba: Dà-á-sílẹ̀-ká-tun-pín, ogún ijọ́un, a ò pín in re.

English: It is wrapping that makes a knife sharp.
Yoruba: Dídì ní ń mú abẹ mú.

English: It is bit by bit that the nose of the pig enters the fence.
Yoruba: Díẹ̀-díẹ̀ nimú ẹlẹ́dẹ̀ẹ́ fi ń wọgbà.

English: The diviner does not take Ifá lightly.
Yoruba: DÍfá-dÍfá ò fIfá ṣeré.

English: The egg-bearing spider never leaves its eggs behind.
Yoruba: Dùgbẹ̀-dùgbẹ̀ kì í fi ẹyin rẹ̀ sílẹ̀.

English: Stop and say hello to the wicked; if you do not say hello to the wicked, the wicked will find problems for you.
Yoruba: Dúró o kíkà; bí o ò dúró kíkà, ìkà a ba tìrẹ jẹ́.

English: I am hungry and the soap seller hawks her wares; when I have not washed my inside, how can I wash my outside?
Yoruba: Ebi ń pa mí ọlọ́ṣẹ ń kiri; ìgbà tí n ò wẹnú n ó ṣe wẹ̀de?

English: The Ijeṣa person is not hungry and he rejects corn-loaf prepared by an Ọ̀yọ́ person; when hunger gripped the son of Obokun (an apellation for Ijeṣa people) he ate ori(the Ọ̀yọ́ name for corn-loaf.)
Yoruba: Ebi ò pàJèṣà ó lóun ò jẹ̀kọ Ọ̀yọ́; ebí pa ọmọ Obòkun ó jẹ ori.

English: The muslim is not hungry and he vows he will not eat a red Colobus monkey; hunger gripped Suleiman and he ate a monkey.
Yoruba: Ebi ò pÀmọ̀le ó ní òun ò jẹ àáyá; ebí pa Súlè ó jọ̀bọ.

English: The Ẹ̀gbá masquerader must needs speak Ẹ̀gbá.
Yoruba: Eégún Ẹ̀gbá, Ẹ̀gbá ní ń fọ̀.

English: It is the masquerader that succors one that one makes shrouds for; it is the god that succors one that one worships; if a tree succors me, I will take kolanuts and worship the tree.
Yoruba: Eégún tí yó gbeni là ń dáṣọ fún; òrìṣà tí yó gbeni là ń sìn; bi igí bá gbè mí mà kó obì mà bọ igi.

English: The masquerader that will perform like Lébé must become like Lébé; the one that will sumersault like Olúfolé (meaning “Great-One-Jumps-A-House”) must perform his feat in the open spaces.
Yoruba: Eégún tí yó ṣe bíi Lébé, Lébé ni yó dà; èyí tí yó tàkìtì bí Olúfolé, òfurugbàdà ni yó ta á.

English: A snake sees a tight hole and crawls into it; has its mother hands to pull it out?
Yoruba: Ejòó rí ihò tó há ó kó wọ̀ ọ́; ìyáa rẹ̀ẹ́ lọ́wọ́ àti fà á yọ?

English: The seller of steamed ground beans does not hawk her wares on a farm.
Yoruba: Elékuru kì í kiri lóko.

English: How much does a hen cost that one would contract to raise chicks for the owner?
Yoruba: Èló là ń ra adìẹ òkókó, tí à ń gba ọmọọ rẹ̀ sìn?

English: I-will-court-no-woman-being-courted-by-another-man will court no woman at all.
Yoruba: Èmi-ò-níí-fẹ́-obìnrin-tẹ́nìkan-ńfẹ́, olúwarẹ̀ ò níí fẹ́ obìnrin ni.

English: I-will-not-defecate-on-existing-excrement will walk a good distance into the bush.
Yoruba: Èmi-ò-níí-ṣu-imí-le-imí, olúwarẹ̀ ó rìn jìnnà ààtàn.

English: Curses are the antidote for curses.
Yoruba: Èpè la fi ń wo èpè sàn.

English: It is palm oil that goes best with yams; it is a ladder that is best for climbing granaries; a woman is more pleasant to make love to than a man.
Yoruba: Epo ló ṣeé jẹṣu; àkàsọ̀ ló ṣeé gun àká; obìnrín dùn-ún bá sùn ju ọkùnrin lọ.

English: Palm-oil is the countenance of stew.
Yoruba: Epo lojú ọbẹ̀.

English: All one does with ayò seeds is play.
Yoruba: Eré là ń fọmọ ayò ṣe.

English: A wayfarer does not know the location of the rest stop and yet have his neck crushed from the weight of a heavy load.
Yoruba: Èrò kì í mọ ibùsọ̀ kọ́rùn ó wọ̀ ọ́.

English: Intention is the eldest, contemplation is the next, and plan of action is the third.
Yoruba: Ète lẹ̀gbọ́n; ìmọ̀ràn làbúrò; bí-a-ó-ti-ṣe lẹ̀kẹta wọn.

English: Order is the first law in heaven.
Yoruba: Ètò lòfin kìn-ín-ní lóde ọ̀run.

English: A goat is not a wise choice as the guard over yams.
Yoruba: Ewúrẹ́ ò ṣeé fiṣu ṣọ́.

English: To what turned out favorably for those going ahead, you coming behind, pay close attention.
Yoruba: Èyí tó yẹ ará iwájú, èrò ẹ̀yìn fiyè sílẹ̀.

English: One can only remonstrate with a wicked person to urge him or her to improve his or her town.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀bẹ̀ là ń bẹ òṣìkà pé kó tún ìlúu rẹ̀ ṣe.

English: A little sacrifice, a little medicine, is what keeps the one who does not die alive.
Yoruba: Ẹbọ díẹ̀, oògùn díẹ̀, ní ń gba aláìkú là.

English: It is a sacrifice on behalf of only one person that demands only one person as offering.
Yoruba: Ẹbọ ẹnìkan là ń fi ẹnìkan rú.

English: The teasing involves pounded yams; the corn-loaf is unwrapped, and the father of the household asks, “Did someone call me?”
Yoruba: Ẹ̀fẹ̀ẹ́ dẹ̀fẹ̀ iyán; a paláwẹ́ ẹ̀kọ baálé ilé ní ẹ̀ ń pèun bí?

English: The teasing involves pounded yam; even if you throw me on the ground I will eat with you.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀fẹ̀ẹ́ dẹ̀fẹ̀ iyán; ò báà gbémi lulẹ̀ n ó bá ọ jẹun.

English: One does not upon failing to find suitable company in this world go looking in heaven.
Yoruba: Ẹgbẹ́ ẹni kì í wọ́n láyé ká wá a lọ sọ́run.

English: One may complain about a person who courts one's wife, but one does not complain about a person who courts one's daughter.
Yoruba: Ẹjọ́ a-fẹ́ni-lóbìnrin là ń wí; a kì í wíjọ́ a-fẹ́ni-lọ́mọ.

English: One gets bitten by a snake only once.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀ẹ̀kan lejò ń yánni.

English: An overly loquacious person is someone to flee from.
Yoruba: Ẹlẹ́nuú tóó rí sá.

English: The pig says since the day it learned to reply to every statement with a grunt it has not got into any trouble.
Yoruba: Ẹlẹ́dẹ̀ẹ́ ní ọjọ́ tí òún ti jágbọ́n-ọn hùn, ọjọ́ náà ni ọ̀rọ̀ ò ti nìun lára mọ́.

English: The person with complaints selects the most pressing ones to press.
Yoruba: Ẹlẹ́jọ́ ṣa èyí tó wù ú wí.

English: One does not complain that a corpse one will have to bury stinks.
Yoruba: Ẹni a óò gbé òkúu rẹ̀ sin, a kì í sọ pé ó ń rùn pani.

English: The person invited to take a look at the palace stateroom: he exclaims, “What a maze of apartments!”
Yoruba: Ẹni a pé kó wáá wo kọ̀bì: ó ní kí nìyí kọ́bi-kọ̀bi?

English: The person people have gathered to watch should not himself or herself be a spectator.
Yoruba: Ẹni à ń wò kì í wòran.

English: Whoever people speak to should listen; whoever people instruct should accept instruction; the one who does not listen will be covered by the earth.
Yoruba: Ẹni a wí fún ko gbọ́; ẹni a fọ̀ fún kó gbà; èyí tí ò gbọ́ yó filẹ̀ bora.

English: People killed by folly are innumerable; people killed by wisdom are few.
Yoruba: Ẹni àìgbọ́n pa ló pọ̀; ẹni ọgbọ́n pa ò tó nǹkan.

English: Whoever sees mucus in the nose of the king is the one who cleans it.
Yoruba: Ẹní bá ríkun nímú ọlọ́jà ní ń fọn ọ́n.

English: One appeals only to those capable of helping one.
Yoruba: Ẹní bá tó ẹnií gbà là ń ké pè.

English: Whoever deprives himself of the title of Apena will wait until he dies before tasting free meat.
Yoruba: Ẹní du araa rẹ̀ lóyè Apènà: kó tó jẹ ẹran ọ̀fẹ́, ó dọ̀run.

English: It is someone wiser than one who consults the oracle for one.
Yoruba: Ẹní gbọ́n juni lọ ní ń tẹni nÍfá.

English: Whoever chases after two rats will catch neither.
Yoruba: Ẹní léku méjì á pòfo.

English: Whoever wishes to raise an alarm will have to murder his father.
Yoruba: Ẹní máa ké ìbòsí á pa baba rẹ̀ jẹ.

English: Whoever offers a sacrifice to a deity must also offer a sacrifice to humans in order for the sacrifice to be efficacious.
Yoruba: Ẹní rúbọ òrìṣà gbọ́dọ̀ rú ti èèyàn kí ẹbọọ́ tó gbà.

English: The person on whose head a coconut is broken will not share in eating it.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí a bá fi oríi rẹ̀ fọ́ àgbọn ò níí jẹ níbẹ̀.

English: One pays attention to the person with whom one is bargaining, not to the commotion of the market place.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí a bá ń bá nájà là ń wò, a kì í wo ariwo ọjà.

English: Let the person one advises heed one; the heedless person places himself at risk.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí a wífún kó gbọ́; ẹni tí kò gbọ́, taraa rẹ̀ ni yó dà.

English: It is the person with a thorn in his foot who limps to the person with a needle.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ẹ̀gún gún lẹ́sẹ̀ ní ń ṣe lákáǹláká tẹ̀lé alábẹ́rẹ́.

English: Only the unwise hungers while fasting.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí kò gbọ́n lààwẹ̀ ń gbò.

English: It is a person who does not know how to carry out instructions that is forced to repeat his or her efforts.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí kò mọ iṣẹ́ẹ́ jẹ́ ní ń pààrà lẹ́ẹ̀mejì.

English: Only a person who does not know the king trifles with the king.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí kò mọ ọba ní ń fọba ṣeré.

English: It is the incorrigible fighter who has to remain on his or her knees until nightfall.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó lè jà ni yóò kúnlẹ̀ kalẹ́.

English: The person who will worship Ògun will keep his or her market purchases separate from those of others.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí yó bọ Ògún, yó ra ọjàa tirẹ̀ lọ́tọ̀.

English: The person who will leap must first crouch.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí yó fò yó bẹ̀rẹ̀.

English: Whoever wishes to eat steaming corn pap will play with the child of the seller.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí yó mu ẹ̀kọ fòrò, yó bàá ọmọ ẹlẹ́kọ ṣeré.

English: The person who wishes to eat free corn pap will play with the seller's child.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí yó mu ẹ̀kọ ọ̀fẹ́ yó bàá ọmọ ẹlẹ́kọ ṣeré.

English: Whoever chooses concubinage as a practice must provide herself with a sleeping mat; whoever chooses Ṣàngò's trade (one to do with metal) must purchase his magical rattle.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí yó ṣòwò àlè, ẹníi rẹ̀ ní ń ká; ẹni tí yó ṣòwòo Ṣàngó, ààjàa rẹ̀ ní ń rà.

English: The person who will lend one money and will not keep pestering one for repayment: one can tell from the tone of his or her voice.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí yó yááni lówó, tí kò níí sinni, ohùn ẹnuu rẹ̀ la ti ń mọ̀.

English: Whoever throws water ahead will step on cool earth.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó bá da omi síwájú á tẹ ilẹ̀ tútù.

English: Whoever looks at the dead with yesterday's eyes will be stripped naked by the spirits.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó bá fi ojù àná wòkú, ẹbọra a bọ́ ọ láṣọ.

English: If one must eat a toad one should eat one with eggs.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó bá máa jẹ ọ̀pọ̀lọ́ a jẹ èyí tó lẹ́yin.

English: Whoever will smite a secret-cult priest had better smite an important one; for a lowly one twelve hundred cowries in fines, and for an important one twelve hundred cowries.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó bá máa lu òṣùgbó a lu ńlá; kékeré ẹgbẹ̀fà, ńlá ẹgbẹ̀fà.

English: Whoever wishes to catch a monkey must act like a monkey.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó bá máa mú ọ̀bọ a ṣe bí ọ̀bọ.

English: It is a person who has prior knowledge of the facts of a matter that can foil a devious person's attempts to skirt them.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó bá mọ ìdí ọ̀ràn tẹ́lẹ̀ ní ń bu àbùjá èké.

English: If one must use a tree-climbing rope and it breaks, one must pause to repair it.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó bá ní igbàá lò, bí igbàá bá já, kó dúró so ó.

English: Whoever prolongs his or her defecating will be visited by a host of flies.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó bá pẹ́ lórí imí, eṣinṣin kéṣinṣin yóò bá a níbẹ̀.

English: Whoever remembers Efuji should show no kindness to any horse.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó bá rántí Efuji, kó má fi ore ṣe ẹṣin.

English: Those who gratefully remember past favors extend compassion to the survivors of the deceased; who would rather show compassion to the child of a masquerader?
Yoruba: Ẹni tó bá rántí ọjọ́ ní ń ṣe ọmọ òkú pẹ̀lẹ́; ta ní jẹ́ ṣe ọmọ eégún lóore?

English: Whoever announces that the legs of the masquerader are showing is the one who goes in search of a needle.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó bá sọ pé ẹsẹ̀ eégún ń hàn ní ń wá abẹ́rẹ́ lọ.

English: Whoever hires a pawn for only sixpence will join the pawn in grinding pepper.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó bá yá ìwọ̀fà ẹgbàá, tòun tirẹ̀ ní ń lọ ata kúnná.

English: The person who remains prone has perfected the charm for wrestling.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó dùbúlẹ̀ ṣe oògùn ìjàkadì tán.

English: Whoever plays around with his or her black hair will serve others with his or her white hair.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó fi irun dúdú ṣeré, yó fi funfun sin ẹniẹlẹ́ni.

English: Whoever paid his or her own money for a horse will not let it be sacrificed for a good-luck charm.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó fi owóo rẹ̀ ra ẹṣin, kò níí jẹ́ kó ṣe àrìnjẹ́.

English: The dandy who does not know how to extend greetings to people is no different from a boor.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó gbajúmọ̀ tí kò mọ èèyàn-án kí, òun òbúrẹ́wà ẹgbẹ́ra.

English: Whoever wishes to lay a dead toad in state will have to build his own cult shrine separately.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó máa tẹ́ òkú ọ̀pọ̀lọ́, yóò ní ilé ògbóni tirẹ̀ lọ́tọ̀.

English: If a person offers to lend one a dress, one should consider what he or she has on.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó máa yáni lẹ́wù, ti ọrùn-un rẹ̀ là ń wò.

English: The person who shakes a tree stump shakes himself.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó mi kùkùté, araa rẹ̀ ní ń mì.

English: It is someone who knows the duiker intimately who can recite its praise, “spindle-legged duiker.”
Yoruba: Ẹni tó mọ ẹtu ní ń kì í ní “òbèjé, ẹlẹ́sẹ̀ ọwọ̀.”

English: The person who claps for a mad person to dance to is no different from the mad person.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó ń ṣápẹ́ fún wèrè jó, òun àti wèrè ọ̀kan-ùn.

English: The person who kills the donkey will carry a heavy burden.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó pa kẹ́tẹ́kẹ́tẹ́ yó ru káyá ẹrù.

English: Whoever sends for Orò is contracting for sleeplessness.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó ránṣẹ́ sí oròó bẹ̀wẹ̀ fún àìsùn.

English: Whoever goes to Ibadan and does not visit Oluyọle's house merely went wood gathering.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó re Ìbàdàn tí kò dé ilé Olúyọ̀lé, oko igi ló lọ.

English: The person who makes a sacrifice but does not follow the prescribed taboos is just like someone who throws away the money for the sacrifice.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó rúbọ tí kò gba èèwọ̀, bí ẹni tó fi owó ẹbọ ṣòfò ni.

English: The person who throws palm-nuts at a pig gives food to it.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó sọ ẹlẹ́dẹ̀ lékùrọ́, oúnjẹ ló fún un.

English: Whoever because of cold weather uses the pestle as kindling to warm him/herself must not expect to eat pounded yams.
Yoruba: Ẹni tó torí òtútù fi ọmọrí odó yáná ò gbọdọ̀ retí a-ti-jẹyán.

English: A mouth that will not stay shut, lips that will not stay closed, are what bring trouble to the cheeks.
Yoruba: Ẹnu àìmẹ́nu, ètè àìmétè, ní ń mú ọ̀ràn bá ẹ̀rẹ̀kẹ́.

English: A rabbit's mouth does not accept a leash.
Yoruba: Ẹnu ehoro ò gba ìjánu.

English: The cheeks are the home of laughter.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀rẹ̀kẹ́ ni ilé ẹ̀rín.

English: It is fear that makes one call witches the good people.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀rù bíbà ní ń múni pe àjẹ́ ní ará ire.

English: “I agree” is not a load that causes one's neck to shrink.
Yoruba: Ẹrùu hòo kì í wọni lọ́rùn.

English: The ridiculing of the person with gonorrhea does not belong with the eunuch.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀sín alátọ̀sí ò sí lọ́wọ́ òkóbó.

English: The bird of the forest does not know how to fly in the grassland.
Yoruba: Ẹyẹ igbó kì í mọ fífò ọ̀dàn.

English: A bird is preparing for flight, and people throw stones at it.
Yoruba: Ẹyẹ ń wá àtifò, wọ́ ń sọ òkò sí i.

English: Leave the fighting to God, sit back and watch.
Yoruba: Fi ìjà fún Ọlọ́run jà, fọwọ́ lérán.

English: Hide-me-and-I-will-kill-you is the name a disease answers to.
Yoruba: Fimí-pamọ́-kí-n-pa-ọ́ làrùn-ún jẹ́.

English: “Hold my child for me so I may wiggle my buttocks”; if one cannot wiggle one's buttocks one should return the child to its mother.
Yoruba: “Gba ọmọ fún mi kí n rèdí”; bí ìdí ò bá ṣeé rè ká gbọ́mọ fọ́lọ́mọ.

English: All the animals of the forest assembled and decided to make Hyena their secretary; Hyena was happy, but a short while later it burst into tears. Asked what the matter was, it said perhaps they might reconsider and reverse themselves.
Yoruba: Gbogbo ẹranko ìgbẹ́ pé, wọn ní àwọn ó fi ìkokò ṣe aṣípa; nígbà tó gbọ́ inú ẹ̀ é̩ dùn; ṣùgbọ́n nígbà tó ṣe ó bú sẹ́kún; wọ́n ní kí ló dé? Ó ní bóyá wọ́n lè tún ọ̀ràn náà rò kí wọ́n ní kì í ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀ mọ́.

English: Asking “directions” keeps one from losing one's way; the person who refuses to ask is responsible for his/her own difficulties.
Yoruba: Ìbéèrè kì í jẹ́ kí ẹni ó ṣìnà; ẹni tí kò lè béèrè ní ń pọ́n ara ẹ̀ lójú.

English: One's home is a legitimate place to buy things on credit; what is bad is avoiding payment.
Yoruba: Ibi tí a bá ń gbé la ti ń gbàwìn; à-rà-àì-san ni ò sunwọ̀n.

English: One does not throw rocks at the place where one has one's palm-oil stored.
Yoruba: Ibi tí a gbé epo sí a kì í sọ òkò síbẹ̀.

English: Where one began one's climb, there one effects one's descent.
Yoruba: Ibi tí a ti gùn, ibẹ̀ la ti ń rọ̀.

English: Where one is eating food like mucus, one should not bring up matters like phlegm.
Yoruba: Ibi tí a ti ń jẹun bí ikun bí ikun, a kì í sọ̀rọ̀ bíi kẹ̀lẹ̀bẹ̀ bíi kẹ̀lẹ̀bẹ̀ níbẹ̀.

English: One should live according to the customs and fashions of the place one finds oneself in; if one lands in the city of lepers, one should make a fist, i.e., conceal one's fingers.
Yoruba: Ibi tí à ń gbé là ń ṣe; bí a bá dé ìlú adẹ́tẹ̀ à di ìkúùkù.

English: It is precisely where you will eventually have to sleep that you have laid down your child to sleep.
Yoruba: Ibi tí o máa sùn lo tẹ́ ọmọ sí.

English: The vulture has endured the drenching rain from a great distance, but who sent the vulture on an errand?
Yoruba: Ibi tí òjòó ti ń pa igún bọ̀ jìnnà; ta ní rán igún níṣẹ́?

English: Wherever the rain catches up with the day, there it drenches it.
Yoruba: Ibi tí òjòó bá ọjọ́ ní ń pa á sí.

English: Wherever the yọ̀nmọ̀ntì (food made from benniseed) seller falls, there she has sold all her wares.
Yoruba: Ibi tí oníyọ̀nmọ̀ntìí ṣubú sí, ibẹ̀ ló ti tà á tán.

English: As the bees hum and the small calabash containing charms hums, the intestine does not keep silent.
Yoruba: Ibi tí oyín gbé ń hó, tí àdó ń hó, ìfun ò dákẹ́ lásán.

English: It is at its home base that a company or trade prospers.
Yoruba: Ìdí òwò ni òwòó gbé tà.

English: The vulture did others a favor and became bald in return; the hornbill did others a favor and developed a goiter in return; in the future, one should not do those kinds of favor.
Yoruba: Igún ṣoore ó pá lórí, àkàlà ṣoore ó yọ gẹ̀gẹ̀; nítorí ọjọ́ mìíràn kẹni ó má ṣe oore bẹ́ẹ̀ mọ́.

English: One swears when it is time to swear.
Yoruba: Ìgbà ara là ń búra.

English: It is a calabash that one cuts decorative patterns on; one does not cut patterns on china plates.
Yoruba: Igbá là ń pa, a kì í pa àwo.

English: The rainy season passes, the dry season passes, and the suggestion is that the rat's burrow be sealed up tight; when will the time be ripe to kill the rat?
Yoruba: Ìgbà òjò ń lọ, ìgbà ẹ̀rùn ń lọ, a ní ká dí isà eku kó le; ìgbà wo la óò tó wá peku náà?

English: The time of one's arrival on the farm is one's dawn.
Yoruba: Ìgbà tí a bá dóko làárọ̀ ẹni.

English: Whenever one first sees a person, that is that person's morning.
Yoruba: Ìgbà tí a bá rẹni lòwúrọ̀ ẹni.

English: It is a calabash that understands one's language that one describes as a measure.
Yoruba: Igbá tó gbédè là ń pè lóṣùwọ̀n.

English: Had the snail been careless in its foraging it would have died in the bush.
Yoruba: Ìgbín ìbá má mọ̀ ọ́n jẹ̀ ìbá ti kú síjù.

English: Had the snail been careless in its foraging it would not “have grown large enough to” be worth twenty cowries.
Yoruba: Ìgbín ìbá má mọ̀ ọ́n jẹ̀ kò tó okòó.

English: The snail never embarks on a dyeing trade, and the spotted grass-mouse never digs for àràn.
Yoruba: Ìgbín kì í pilẹ̀ aró, àfè ìmòjò kì í pilẹ̀ àràn.

English: The forest is the home for animals to live in.
Yoruba: Igbó lẹranko ń gbé.

English: The elbow develops a hump right from its youth.
Yoruba: Ìgbọ̀nwọ́ ti kékeré yọké.

English: A street fight is the death of a bashful person; warring is the death of a strong man.
Yoruba: Ìjà ní ń pa onítìjú; ogun ní ń pa alágbára.

English: It is dance that strips one of one's cloth; it is a fight that takes off one's shirt.
Yoruba: Ijó ní ń bọ́ṣọ, ìjà ní ń bọ́ ẹ̀wù.

English: An abandoned well kills a horse and we rejoice; it will in time kill a human being.
Yoruba: Ikúdú pa ẹṣin à ń yọ̀; ó ń bọ̀ wá pa ọmọ èèyàn.

English: Is a dog's house the place to go in search of horns?
Yoruba: Ilé ajá là ń wá ìwo lọ?

English: It is in the home of a person who has food that one sets one's chest like a trap.
Yoruba: Ilé olóuńjẹ là ń dẹ̀bìtì àyà sí.

English: It is on the ground that the stool sits to await the buttocks.
Yoruba: Ilẹ̀ nìjòkò ń jókòó de ìdí.

English: One does not string decorative beads all around one's waist.
Yoruba: Ìlẹ̀kẹ̀ àmúyọ, a kì í sin kádìí tán.

English: One enters the porch first before one enters the house.
Yoruba: Ìloro là ń wọ̀ ká tó wọlé.

English: It is time to get out of here, the gatekeeper of Atadi; his home was burglarized, his wife was taken from him, the divining string he was going to use to investigate matters was snatched by a dog, his son who ran after the dog to retrieve the divining string fell into a well; the gatekeeper of Atadi then spoke up and said, “It is time to get out of here.”
Yoruba: Ìlọọ́ yá, oníbodè Atàdí; wọ́n kó o nílé, wọ́n gbà á lóbìnrin, ọ̀pẹ̀lẹ̀ tó ní òun ó fi wádìí ọ̀ràn, ajá gbé e, ọmọ ẹ̀ tó lé ajá láti gba ọ̀pẹ̀lẹ̀, ó yí sí kàǹga; oníbodè Atàdí wá dáhùn ó ní, “Ìlọ-ọ́ yá.”

English: The fire of the stinging tragia plant does not burn a person twice.
Yoruba: Iná èsìsì kì í jóni lẹ́ẹ̀mejì.

English: It is too much fire that will ruin the stew of a bushman.
Yoruba: Iná kúkú ni yó ba ọbẹ̀ ará oko jẹ́.

English: The fire that challenges water will die off.
Yoruba: Iná tó ń lérí omi á kù sọnù.

English: The whip used on the senior wife is resting on the rafters waiting for the new wife.
Yoruba: Ìpàṣán tí a fi na ìyálé ń bẹ láàjà fún ìyàwó.

English: Ìròrẹ́ cannot fight, so it makes its home close to the wasp's.
Yoruba: Ìròrẹ́ ò leè jà ó múlé ti agbọ́n.

English: The fart within a masquerader's shroud “is” something to be endured.
Yoruba: Isó inú ẹ̀kú, à-mú-mọ́ra.

English: The fate that has befallen the goat, the sheep should bear in mind.
Yoruba: Ìṣeǹṣe ewúrẹ́, kágùntàn fiyè síi.

English: Whether the yams are large or not, it is one by one that one extracts them from the heap.
Yoruba: Iṣú ta iṣu ò ta, ọ̀kọ̀ọ̀kan là ń wúṣu lébè.

English: The lemon plant that grows in the bush and does not support itself against something will be uprooted by the forest breeze.
Yoruba: Ìtórò tó so lóko tí kò fẹ̀yìntì, afẹ́fẹ́ oko ní ń tú u.

English: The way a wise person looks at things is different from the way an imbecile does.
Yoruba: Ìwòo ọlọgbọ́n ò jọ ti aṣiwèrè.

English: “My wife is not good looking, but I married her for the sake of children”; to how many people will one give that explanation?
Yoruba: Ìyàwó mi ò sunwọ̀; nítorí ọmọ ni mo ṣe fẹ́ ẹ; ẹni mélòó la ó wìí fún tán?

English: The junior wife has said what will be her last; she said the senior wife's mouth is as white as the new yam.
Yoruba: Ìyàwó sọ ọ̀rọ̀ kan tán: ó ní ìyálé òun a-bẹnu-funfun-bí-ègbodò.

English: The wife has done the unpardonable; her husband has adopted an I-will-not-eat-any-longer attitude.
Yoruba: Ìyàwó ṣe ọ̀ràn kan tán; ọkọ ẹ̀ ẹ́ ṣe ọ̀ràn-an n kò-jẹ-mọ́.

English: “Unroof your house and I will help you re-roof it” usually gives one only one bundle of thatching grass.
Yoruba: “Já ilé ẹ̀ kí ń bá ẹ kọ́ ọ”; ìtẹ́ èèkàn kan ní ń fúnni.

English: Busily wagging tail, busily wagging tail, a goat enters a bachelor's house busily wagging its tail; what does a bachelor have to eat whose left-over the goat can have?
Yoruba: Jùrù-fẹ̀fẹ̀ jùrù-fẹ̀fẹ̀, ewúrẹ́ wọ ilé àpọn jùrù-fẹ̀fẹ̀; kí làpọ́n rí jẹ tí yó kù sílẹ̀ féwúrẹ́?

English: Instead of permitting defeat by a child in a game, an elder should resort to elderly wiles.
Yoruba: Kàkà kí ọmọdé pàgbà láyò, àgbà a fi ọgbọ́n àgbà gbé e.

English: Whatever keeps one from being deaf to certain things keeps one from being happy.
Yoruba: Kì í jẹ́ kí etí ẹni di kì í jẹ kí inú ẹni dùn.

English: It is not to every person who says “Whoever has received some bounty from God should give to me” that one gives alms.
Yoruba: Kì í ṣe gbogbo ẹni tí ń ṣe “Ẹni Ọlọ́rún bùn ó bùn mi” là ń fún ní nǹkan.

English: What is there to wear in a pair of trousers bought at three for three hundred cowries, or three a penny?
Yoruba: Kí ni à ń wọ̀ nínúu ṣòkòtò mẹ́ta ọ̀ọ́dúnrún?

English: What would a cap be doing atop the ògógó mushroom? Pepper will remove it.
Yoruba: Kí ni fìlà yó ṣe lórí ògógó? Ata ni yó ṣi.

English: Do goats eat woolen fabrics?
Yoruba: What is the cloth-selling woman have to sell that she carries a whip in her hand?
