Yoruba: Gbogbo ajá ní ń jẹ imí: èyí tó bá jẹ tiẹ̀ mẹ́nu laráyé ń pè ní dìgbòlugi.

English: Every way of fighting is a legitimate way of fighting. If you are strong enough to throw me, I will fight back by looking at you with absolute disdain.
Yoruba: Gbogbo ìjà nìjà; bóo gbémi lulẹ̀ mà mọ́ ẹ lójú lákọ lákọ.

English: All women are unfaithful; only those who know no moderation are put down as whores.
Yoruba: Gbogbo obìnrin ló ń gbéṣẹ́, èyí tó bá ṣe tiẹ̀ láṣejù laráyé ń pè láṣẹ́wó.

English: Just one utterance by the masquerader Agán is sufficient to effect a great deal of wonders.
Yoruba: Gbólóhùn kan Agán tó awoó ṣe.

English: One solitary statement muddies an entire affair; one solitary statement clears all the confusion.
Yoruba: Gbólóhùn kan-án ba ọ̀rọ̀ jẹ́; gbólóhùn kan-án tún ọ̀rọ̀ ṣe.

English: One asks only one question of the palm-oil seller, but she rambles endlessly on.
Yoruba: Gbólóhùn kan la bi elépo; elépo ń ṣe ìrànrán.

English: At the beginning of one's penury one seems like the child of most prosperous parents.
Yoruba: Ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ òṣì bí ọmọ ọlọ́rọ̀ là ń rí.

English: It is from the time one makes one's boasts that one should begin to mind one's charms (or juju).
Yoruba: Ibi ìṣáná la ti ńkíyè sóògùn.

English: The ladder always rests on a propitious spot.
Yoruba: Ibi rere làkàsọ̀ńgbé sọlẹ̀.

English: One should limit the depth of one's involvement in cattle trading to the extent of one's astuteness.
Yoruba: Ibi tí a gbọ́n mọ là ń ṣòwò-o màlúù mọ.

English: Just as one cares for the sick, one should also care for oneself.
Yoruba: Ibi tí a ti ń wo olókùnrùn lati ń wo ara ẹni.

English: One should keep one's eyes on where one is going, not where one stumbled.
Yoruba: Ibi tí à ńlọ là ńwò, a kì í wo ibi tí a ti ṣubú.

English: Wherever the jackal lurks, the chicken must give the place a wide berth.
Yoruba: Ibi tí akátá ba sí, adìẹ ò gbọdọ̀ débẹ̀.

English: The cooking pot must never harbor a grudge to the same extent that the sieve does; if the pot does so, the corn-meal trader will have nothing to sell.
Yoruba: Ibi tí inú ń bí asẹ́ tó, inú ò gbọdọ̀ bí ìkòkò débẹ̀; bínú bá bí ìkòkò débẹ̀, ẹlẹ́kọ ò níí rí dá.

English: Where it stops, there one designates “child.”
Yoruba: Ibi tí ó mọ là ń pè lọ́mọ.

English: Anger “is the” father of hopelessness.
Yoruba: Ìbínú baba òṣì.

English: It is in anger that the king draws his sword; it is shame that makes him go through with the beheading.
Yoruba: Ìbínú lọbá fi ń yọ idà; ìtìjù ló fi ń bẹ́ ẹ.

English: Anger accomplishes nothing; forebearance is the father of character traits; an elder who has forebearance has everything.
Yoruba: Ìbínú ò da nǹkan; sùúrù baba ìwà; àgbà tó ní sùúrù ohun gbogbo ló ní.

English: Anger does not know that its owner has no legs to stand on.
Yoruba: Ìbínú ò mọ̀ pé olúwa òun ò lẹ́sẹ̀ ńlẹ̀

English: A ram's stepping backwards is not indicative of cowardice.
Yoruba: Ìbìsẹ́yín àgbò kì í ṣojo.

English: Whether a gun has a trigger or not, who would calmly permit the gun to be pointed at him/her?
Yoruba: Ìbọn-ọ́n ní apátí kò lápátí, taní jẹ́ jẹ́ ka kọjú ìbọn kọ òun?

English: It is the incessant chattering of the Pataguenon monkey that causes people to belabor it with sticks; it is the annoying sounds of the ògbìgbì bird that causes people to throw stones at it; it is indiscriminate feeding that causes the bat to ingest food and excrete with the same mouth.
Yoruba: Ì-dún-kídùn-ún òyo ni wọ́n fi ń sọ òyo nígi; ì-fọ̀-kúfọ̀ ògbìgbì ni wọ́n fi ń ta ògbìgbì lókò; ì-jẹ-kújẹ àdán ní ń fií tẹnu pọ̀ fẹnu ṣu.

English: It is excessive love that induces the goat to grow a beard in sympathy with her mate.
Yoruba: Ìfẹ́ àfẹ́jù lewúrẹ́ fi ń bá ọkoọ ẹ̀ hu irùngbọ̀n.

English: Citing comparable things and recalling similar occurrences “in the past” makes ending a quarrel impossible.
Yoruba: Ìfi ohun wé ohun, ìfi ọ̀ràn wé ọ̀ràn, kò jẹ́ kí ọ̀ràn ó tán.

English: Wariness is the elders' most efficacious juju.
Yoruba: Ìfunra loògùn àgbà.

English: “Protruding twig, do not poke me in the eye”; one must keep one's eyes on the twig from a distance.
Yoruba: Igi ganganran má gùnún mi lójú, òkèèrè la ti ń wò ó wá.

English: Whatever tree engages in a contest of threats with Ṣàngó will suffer the fate of drying up.
Yoruba: Igi tó bá bá Ṣàngó lérí, gbígbẹ ní ń gbẹ.

English: The vulture conceals a lot of wisdom in itself.
Yoruba: Igúnnugún gbọ́n sínú.

English: It is when there is a surfeit of flesh on the body that one cuts some of it for sale.
Yoruba: Ìgbà ara ń bẹ lára là ń bù ú tà.

English: That a calabash faces downwards is no antisocial sign; the calabash is only acting according to its nature.
Yoruba: Igbá dojúdé ò jọ ti òṣónú, tinú igbá nigbá ń ṣe.

English: It is only when one pleads with the Ègùn person (from Porto Novo or Àjàṣẹ́ in present-day Benin Republic)that he draws his knife.
Yoruba: Ìgbà tí a bá ní kí Ègùn má jà ní ń yọ̀bẹ.

English: Just as the talk turns to the partridge it shows up to raid the farm
Yoruba: Ìgbà tí a bá perí àparò ní ń jáko.

English: It is the broken calabash that has iron staples driven into its edges; it is the cracked pot that has its neck tied with a rope.
Yoruba: Igbá tó fọ́ ní ń gba kasẹ létí; ìkòkò tó fọ́ ní ń gba okùn lọ́rùn.

English: The snail sets out on a journey and makes a load of its house.
Yoruba: Ìgbín ń ràjò ó filée ẹ̀ ṣẹrù.

English: A snail that forages at the base of the African breadfruit tree and never leaves the base of the African breadfruit tree will be taken home wrapped in the leaf of the African breadfruit tree.
Yoruba: Ìgbín tó ń jẹ̀ ní màfọ̀n, tí ò kúrò ní màfọ̀n, ewé àfọ̀n ni wọn ó fi dì í dele.

English: It is only at the end that the person with a blunt cutlass realizes his error.
Yoruba: Ìgbẹ̀yìn ní ń yé olókùúàdá.

English: Empty boasts ruin a person's reputation.
Yoruba: Ìhàlẹ̀-ẹ́ ba ọ̀ṣọ́ èèyàn jẹ́.

English: Yesterday's food find so delighted the hare; the hare went to the spot of yesterday's feeding and never returned.
Yoruba: Ìjẹǹjẹ àná dùn méhoro; ehoroó rebi ìjẹ àná kò dẹ̀yìn bọ̀.

English: The brown monkey vows it will not run from a dog, only because the dog has not caught a glimpse of it.
Yoruba: Ìjímèrè tó lóun ò níí sá fájá, ojú ajá ni òì tíì to.

English: Unrestrained dancing is what causes the masquerader's penis to become exposed.
Yoruba: Ijó àjójù ní ń mú kí okóo eégún yọ jáde.

English: Haste and patience end up the same.
Yoruba: Ìkánjú òun pẹ̀lẹ́, ọgbọọgba.

English: Ikekere (type of fish) is treating a deadly thing as something to laugh about.
Yoruba: Ìkekere ń fọ̀rọ̀ ikú ṣẹ̀rín.

English: Carrying dust is taboo in Ifẹ́ no dog dares bark in the shadow of the leopard.
Yoruba: Ìkó-eruku èèwọ̀ Ifẹ̀; ajá kì í gbó níbòji ẹkùn.

English: Yams cook in a pot and nobody knows, but when the yams get into the mortar alarms sound.
Yoruba: Ìkòkò ń seṣu ẹnìkan ò gbọ́; iṣú dénú odó ariwó ta.

English: The newborn child who thrusts his/her hand into ashes will find out for himself/herself if it is hot.
Yoruba: Ìkókó ọmọ tó tọwọ́ bọ eérú ni yó mọ bó gbóná.

English: Death stalks Dẹdẹ, and Dẹdẹ stalks death.
Yoruba: Ikú ń dẹ Dẹ̀dẹ̀, Dẹ̀dẹ̀ ń dẹ ikú.

English: The squirrel is eating a banana and the squirrel is wagging its tail; the squirrel does not know that it is what is sweet that kills.
Yoruba: Ikún ń jọ̀gẹ̀dẹ̀ ikún ń rèdí; ikún ò mọ̀ pé ohun tó dùn ní ń pani.

English: Excessive envy of others causes one to take on witching, and makes one become a wizard.
Yoruba: Ìlara àlàjù ní ń múni gbàjẹ́, ní ń múni ṣẹ́ṣó.

English: It is from the home that the Ìjèṣà person takes fire to the farm.
Yoruba: Ilé nÌjèṣàá ti ń múná lọ sóko.

English: Fire does not enter into a stream and yet have the opportunity to live.
Yoruba: Iná kì í wọ odò kó rójú ṣayé.

English: Fire is not something one conceals under one's clothing.
Yoruba: Iná ò ṣéé bò máṣọ.

English: The baboon does not send an ultimatum to the leopard.
Yoruba: Ìnàkí kì í ránṣẹ́ ìjà sẹ́kùn.

English: It is inside oneself that the name one will name one's child resides.
Yoruba: Inú ẹni lorúkọ tí a ó sọ ọmọ ẹni ń gbé.

English: Too much good will towards others engenders suspicion and attracts insults.
Yoruba: Inúure àníjù, ìfura atèébú ní ń mù wá báni.

English: The occiput does not recognize contempt; a turned back does not see a disdainful gesture.
Yoruba: Ìpàkọ́ ò gbọ́ ṣùtì, ìpẹ̀yìndà ò mọ yẹ̀gẹ̀ yíyẹ̀.

English: One throws back the head first before throwing corn into the mouth.
Yoruba: Ìpàkọ́ là ń dà sẹ́yìn ká tó da yangan sẹ́nu.

English: Misfortune does not kill; it is indulgent happiness that kills.
Yoruba: Ìṣẹ́ kì í pani; ayọ̀ ní ń pani.

English: Safe keeping is what is appropriate for a needle.
Yoruba: Ìtọ́jú ló yẹ abẹ́rẹ́.

English: Close investigation keeps the affairs of the town in order.
Yoruba: Ìtọsẹ̀ ló nìlú.

English: Today's behavior “causes” tomorrow's problem.
Yoruba: Ìwà òní, ẹjọ́ ọ̀la.

English: One would be wiser to insult “another person's” mother; if one insults the father a fight would certainly ensue.
Yoruba: Ìyá là bá bú; bí a bú baba ìjà ní ń dà.

English: A famine rages and the grasshopper grows fat; the famine subsides and the grasshopper grows lean.
Yoruba: Ìyàn-án mú, ìrẹ́ yó; ìyàn-án rọ̀, ìrẹ́ rù.

English: The wife was the one made love to, but it is the husband who got pregnant.
Yoruba: Ìyàwó la bá sùn; ọkọ ló lóyún.

English: The bride does not speak, and she is also blind.
Yoruba: Ìyàwó ò fọhùn, ó fọ́jú.

English: One single room will not do for two invalids.
Yoruba: Ìyẹ̀wù kan ṣoṣo ò lè gba olókùnrùn méjì.

English: Alalantori watches a hole without a visible opening, how much more a squirrel's burrow.
Yoruba: Isà tí ò lójú Alalantorí ń dẹ ẹ́, áḿbọńtorí àgbá ikún.

English: The thief is exposed on the ninth day; the woman who sleeps around is exposed on the seventeenth day.
Yoruba: Isán ni à ń mọ olè; ìtàdógún là ń mọ dọ́kọ-dọ́kọ.

English: A task one was not asked to do usually travels in the company of punishment.
Yoruba: Iṣẹ́ tí a kò ránni, òun ìyà ló jọ ń rìn.

English: The saliva one has spat out of one's mouth does not return to one's mouth.
Yoruba: Itọ́ tí a tu sílẹ̀ kì í tún padà re ẹnu ẹni mọ́.

English: Next year's pounded yam will still find some stew.
Yoruba: Iyán àmọ́dún bá ọbẹ̀.

English: Pluck a fig leaf and be attacked by soldier-ants; put a leaf in your mouth and be attacked by the deaf.
Yoruba: Já ewé ọ̀pọ̀tọ́ kí o ríjà eèrùn; jáwé bọ ẹnu kóo ríjà odi.

English: You reveler, do things in moderation; if the string of life is cut there is no retying it.
Yoruba: Jayé-jayé fi ẹ̀lẹ̀ jayé; báyé bá já kò ní àmúso.

English: Eat-your-fill-of-it medicine is no good.
Yoruba: Jẹ ẹ́ kí o yó oògùn ni kò sunwọ̀n.

English: Let a child die at his/her own mother's hands.
Yoruba: Jẹ́ kí ọmọ ó ti ọwọ́ ìyáa ẹ̀ kú wá.

English: Instead of mother-witch's affairs improving, all the children she bears turn out to be female; birds climb upon birds.
Yoruba: Kàkà kí ó sàn lára ìyá àjẹ́, ó fi gbogbo ọmọ bí obìnrin; ẹye ń gorí ẹyẹ.

English: Instead of apologizing for past misbehavior, a child should rather guard against a repetition.
Yoruba: Kàkà kí ọmọ ó bẹ̀bẹ̀ ọ̀ràn, òmíràn ni kò níí ṣe mọ́.

English: Kànìké set fire to the forest on account of a single cowry shell.
Yoruba: Kànìké tìtorí oókan kùngbẹ́.

English: However small the snake, show it no mercy.
Yoruba: Kékeré ejò, má foore ṣe é.

English: One kills the roots of the ìrókò tree while it is still a sapling; when it matures it is out of control.
Yoruba: Kékeré la ti ń pa ẹkàn ìrókò; bó bá dàgbà ọwọ́ kì í ká a mọ́.

English: The muslim teaches his children how to squat from their youth.
Yoruba: Kékerè nìmàleé ti ń kọ ọmọọ ẹ̀ lóṣòó.

English: The neckless gourd will itself indicate to the farmer how to tie it up.
Yoruba: Kèrègbè tí kò lọ́rùn ni yóò júwe bí àgbẹ̀ ó ti so òun kọ́.

English: The broken gourd ceases plying the river.
Yoruba: Kèrègbè tó fọ́ a padà lẹ́yìn odò.

English: Just so that people might know that Woru killed a partridge, he was greeted “Welcome,” and he responded, “My hunting-bag is full!”
Yoruba: Kí a baà lè mọ̀ pé Wòrú pa awó, wọ́n ní “Káàbọ̀”; ó ní “Kẹnkẹn làpò.”

English: Just so that people might know that Àjàpá (the tortoise) has joined the secret society, he was greeted “Welcome,” and he responded, “Initiate or a novice?”
Yoruba: Kí a baà lè mọ̀ pé àjàpá ṣe ògbóni, wọ́n ní “Káàbọ̀”; ó ní “Awo àbí ọ̀gbẹ̀rì?”

English: Let us keep on cutting tobacco leaves to pieces while looking up, and let us see at day's end how many fingers will be left.
Yoruba: Kí a máa re tábà ká máa wòkè, kọ́jọ́ tó kanrí ká wo oye ìka tí yó kù.

English: Between blowing a flute and wriggling one's nose, one will have to go.
Yoruba: Kí á fọn fèrè, ká jámú síi, ọ̀kan yóò gbélẹ̀.

English: One should stand far back from a snake that has not been beheaded; the death that would kill one deserves a wide berth.
Yoruba: Kí á jìnnà séjò tí a ò bẹ́ lórí; ikú tí yó panni a jìnnà síni.

English: One should first chase the jackal away before reprimanding the chicken.
Yoruba: Kí á lé akátá jìnnà ká tó bá adìẹ wí.

English: To work and make a great deal of money is nothing like knowing how to spend it.
Yoruba: Kí á siṣẹ́ ká lówó lọ́wọ́ ò dàbíi ká mọ̀ọ ná.

English: Let us place some on the ground and put some in the mouth, but let what is placed on the ground be more than what is left in the calabash.
Yoruba: Kí á ta sílẹ̀ ká ta sẹ́nu, ká má jẹ̀ẹ́ kí tilẹ̀ pọ̀ ju ti inú igbá lọ.

English: Let us light a lamp to kill the wasp; let us use a long stick to kill the snake; let us light a torch to secure the help of Ṣangó when one is face-to-face with Mádiyàn “enter into no dispute” one runs out of patience.
Yoruba: Kí á tan iná pa agbọ́nrán, ká fọ̀pá gbọọrọ pejò, ká dìtùfù ká fi gbọ̀wẹ̀ lọ́wọ́ọ Ṣàngó; ní ìṣojúu Mádiyàn lagaraá ṣe ń dáni.

English: Before one realizes that tough hand-woven cloth is not leather, three years will have passed.
Yoruba: Kí á tó mọ̀ pé kíjìpá kì í ṣe awọ, ó di ọdún mẹ́ta.

English: It never slips out of a person's hand and fall to the ground; it always drops into someone else's hand.
Yoruba: Kì í bọ́ lọ́wọ́ èèyàn kó bọ́ sílẹ̀; ọwọ́ ẹlòmíràn ní ń bọ́ sí.

English: It is not in the presence of the fox that the chicken forages nonchalantly.
Yoruba: Kì í ṣe ojúu kọ̀lọ̀kọ̀lọ̀ ladìẹ́ ti ń jẹ̀.

English: The calabash of camwood is never so empty that it can not soil white cloth.
Yoruba: Kì í tán nígbá osùn kó má ba àlà jẹ́.

English: The bread seller never learns in time, not until his ware has become three a penny.
Yoruba: Kì í tètè yé oníbúrẹ́dì; ó dìgbà tó bá di mẹ́ta kọ́bọ̀.

English: One never learns in good time: that is a profound proverb.
Yoruba: Kì í tètè yéni: òwe ńlá ni.

English: What got into the bald person that made him/her swim under water?
Yoruba: Kí ni ó yá apárí lórí tó ń mòòkùn lódò?

English: What was the cat doing that caused it to be burnt in a house fire? Was it looking for its trousers or gathering its property?
Yoruba: Kí ni ológìní ń wá tó fi jóna mọ́le? Ṣòkòtò ló fẹ́ẹ́ mú ni, tàbí ẹrù ní ń dì?

English: Let everybody take matters easy; the vagina cannot tear a cloth by gaping at it.
Yoruba: Kí oníkálùkù rọra ṣe é; ìfẹjú òbò ò lè fa aṣọ ya.

English: Sudden pouncing does not capture greatness; working like a slave does not ensure anything.
Yoruba: Kìtì ò mọ́là; ká siṣẹ́ bí ẹrú ò da nǹkan.

English: There is no dog that does not bark; excessive barking by a dog is what makes people say it is rabid.
Yoruba: Kò sí ajá tí kì í gbó; àgbójù ajá là ń pè ní dìgbòlugi.

English: There is no time one makes a dress that one lacks opportunities to wear it casually.
Yoruba: Kò sí ìgbà tí a dá aṣọ tí a ó rílẹ̀ fi wọ́.

English: There is nothing that gets hard that does not eventually become soft.
Yoruba: Kò sí ohun tí ń le tí kì í rọ̀.

English: There is nothing that patience cooks that is not well cooked.
Yoruba: Kò sí ohun tí sùúrùú sè tí kò jinná.

English: There is nothing that goes up that will not eventually come down.
Yoruba: Kò sí ohun tó lọ sókè tí kò ní padà wá sílẹ̀.

English: There is nothing that kills faster than talking too much.
Yoruba: Kò sí ohun tó yára pa ẹni bí ọ̀rọ̀ àsọjù.

English: The insect that eats the vegetable wins the case against the vegetable; leaves should observe moderation in their attractiveness.
Yoruba: Kòkòrò tó jẹ̀fọ́ jàre ẹ̀fọ́; ìwọ̀n lewéko ń dára mọ.

English: The key of excess is usually good only to open the door of disgrace.
Yoruba: Kọ́kọ́rọ́ àṣejù, ilẹ̀kùn ẹ̀tẹ́ la fi ń ṣí.

English: The woman who divorces husbands at the least provocation does not allow one to know when a matter really hurts.
Yoruba: Kọkọ-kọkọ ò jẹ́ ká mọ ẹni tí ọ̀ràn ń dùn.

English: No one stump can break one's oil-pot twice.
Yoruba: Kùkùté kan kì í fọ́ni lépo lẹ́ẹ̀mejì.

English: Hurry forth and hurry back like a messenger ant.
Yoruba: Kùn yún, kùn wá bí ikọ̀ eèrà.

English: The butterfly does not join others at a market of thorns; otherwise its cloth  will be shredded.
Yoruba: Labalábá kì í bá wọn nájà ẹlẹ́gùnún; aṣọọ ẹ̀ á fàya.

English: The butterfly that collides with a thorn with have its cloth shredded.
Yoruba: Labalábá tó dìgbò lẹ̀gún, aṣọ ẹ̀ á fàya.

English: Common sense “is” the father of good character; whoever has patience has everything.
Yoruba: Làákàyè baba ìwà; bí o ní sùúrù, ohun gbogbo lo ní.

English: A worrisome problem that soars to the heavens must eventually come down.
Yoruba: Làálàá tó ròkè, ilẹ̀ ní ń bọ̀.

English: It is by gentle but persistent beating that the bachelor beats his child to death.
Yoruba: Lù mí pẹ́, lù mí pẹ́ làpọ́n fi ń lu ọmọọ ẹ̀ pa.

English: Avoiding contact is the only medicine for leprosy.
Yoruba: Má bà á loògùn ẹ̀tẹ̀.

English: Do not ask me to play the sort of game the gourd played and got a rope around its neck.
Yoruba: Má bàá mi ṣeré tí kèrègbèé fi gba okùn lọ́rùn.

English: Do not eat up my stew with pounded yam made from wateryams before your trip into the forest farm.
Yoruba: Má fi iyán ewùrà gbọ́n mi lọ́bẹ̀ lọ sóko ẹgàn.

English: “Do not cut a path through my farm” is a protest one must make some day.
Yoruba: “Má fi okoò mi dá ọ̀nà,” ọjọ́ kan là ń kọ̀ ọ́.

English: “Do not hang your trouble around my neck” is the oracle delivered to the shuttle and the weft thread.
Yoruba: “Má fi tìrẹ kọ́ mi lọ́rùn” là ń dá fún apèna àti òwú.

English: Do not go impatiently about enjoying life, the oracle delivered to the Alárá household; do not rush into chieftaincy, the oracle for the Òkè Ìjerò household; there comes another life in the future that is as delicious as licking honey.
Yoruba: Má fìkánjú jayé, awo ilé Alárá; má fi wàà-wàà joyè, awo Òkè Ìjerò; ayé kan ń bẹ lẹ́yìn, ó dùn bí ẹní ń lá oyin.

English: I will eat a whole yam, I will also eat a slice of yam, satiation ends it all.
Yoruba: Màá jẹ iṣu, màá jẹ èrú, ibi ayo ló mọ.

English: Never be sluggish; sluggishness killed Bíálà; but then over-eagerness killed Abídogun.
Yoruba: Má ṣe jáfara: àfara fírí ló pa Bíálà; ara yíyá ló pa Abídogun.

English: Mábàjẹ́ will never think of giving his covering cloth to a shiftless person to use.
Yoruba: Mábàjẹ́ ò jẹ́ fi aṣọọ ẹ̀ fún ọ̀lẹ bora.

English: Two gbẹ̀du drums are too much to hang on one's shoulders.
Yoruba: Méjìi gbẹ̀du ò ṣéé so kọ́.

English: “I did not come to live a life of litigation” gave his daughter to six suitors all at once.
Yoruba: “Méè-wáyé-ẹjọ́” fọmọ ẹ̀ fọ́kọ mẹ́fà. Méèwáyéẹjọ́

English: “I will drag you through the bush” will have to clear a path with his own back.
Yoruba: “N óò wọ́ ọ kágbó,” ẹ̀yìn-in rẹ̀ ni yó fi lànà.

English: It is with the town dweller in mind that one makes the bush person's trousers well.
Yoruba: Nítorí ara ilé la ṣe ń dá ṣòkòtò ará oko dára.

English: It is so that one would be able to rest that one forgoes rest.
Yoruba: Nítoríi ká lè simi la ṣe ń ṣe àì-simi.

English: It is so that one would not have to suffer that one pawns Májìyà.
Yoruba: Nítoríi ká má jìyà la ṣe ń yá Májìyà lọ́fà.

English: It is in anticipation of the day a child will get into trouble that one gives it a name.
Yoruba: Nítorí ọjọ́ tí ó bá máa dáràn la ṣe ń sọmọ lórúkọ.

English: Its is with tomorrow in mind that we do favors for today.
Yoruba: Nítorí ọ̀la la ṣe ń ṣòní lóore.

English: It is with the wise person in mind that one makes the idiot's garment full length.
Yoruba: Nítorí ọlọgbọ́n la ṣe ń dá ẹ̀wùu aṣiwèrè kanlẹ̀.

English: Three things one must never treat as of little consequence: one must never treat fire as of little consequence; one must never treat a quarrel as of little consequence; and one must never treat an illness as of little consequence.
Yoruba: Nǹkan mẹ́ta la kì í pè ní kékeré: a kì í pe iná ní kékeré; a kì í pe ìjà ní kékeré; a kì í pe àìsàn ní kékeré.

English: You come upon the carcass of a buffalo in the marshes and you pull out your butchering knife; do you know where the bushcow came from?
Yoruba: O bá ẹfọ̀n lábàtà o yọ̀bẹ sí i; o mọ ibi ẹfọ̀n-ọ́n ti wa?

English: When goods get into the hands of the retailer they become objects to haggle about.
Yoruba: Ó dé ọwọ́ aláròóbọ̀ ó di níná.

English: In the mouth of a toothless person bean fritters become like bones.
Yoruba: Ó dé orí akáyín àkàràá deegun.

English: You have not found corn loaf and yet you are readying the vegetable stew.
Yoruba: O kò rí àkàṣù ò ń pata sẹ́fọ̀ọ́.

English: You made only one trip to Ìjebu and you returned with a calabash of charms.
Yoruba: O lọ sÍjẹ̀bú ẹ̀ẹ̀kan, o ru igbá àṣẹ bọ̀ wálé.

English: You quarrel with your wife and you put on a baleful look; do you propose to use evil charm on her?
Yoruba: Ò ǹ bá obínrin ẹ jà ò ń kanrí mọ́nú; o máa nà á lóògùn ni?

English: “Watch out, watch out, for here it comes!” For such a thing one would best prepare a snare.
Yoruba: “Ó ń bọ̀, ó ń bọ̀!” ẹ̀wọ̀n là ń so̩ sílẹ̀ dè é.

English: There is a limit to the protection black stinging ants can offer palmfruits.
Yoruba: Ó ní ibi tí tanpẹ́pẹ́ ń gbèjà ẹyìn mọ.

English: There was something the elder ate to line his stomach before he said what “little” is before him will suffice to sate his hunger.
Yoruba: Ó ní ohun tí àgbàá jẹ tẹ́lẹ̀ ikùn kó tó sọ pé èyí yó òun.

English: There was something the elder ate to line his stomach before he said his/her suffering is enough food for him/her.
Yoruba: Ó ní ohun tí àgbàá jẹ tẹ́lẹ̀ ikùn kó tó sọ pé ìyàá yó òun.

English: Raising an alarm or calling for help goes only so far to aid someone in a fight.
Yoruba: Ó ní ohun tí ìbòsí ràn nínú ìjà.

English: The longest respite for the pregnant woman is nine months.
Yoruba: Ó pẹ́ títí aboyún, oṣù mẹ́sàn-án.

English: You see an adult chicken at the market and you eagerly go for it; if it was of any value would the owner sell it?
Yoruba: O rí àgbébọ̀ adìẹ lọ́jà ò ń ta geere sí i; ìba ṣe rere olúwa rẹ̀ ò jẹ́ tà á.

English: You foul the air in my face and I lick my lips, you glance back and I prostrate myself before you, and yet you stretch your hand into the bush; would you tie me up?
Yoruba: O só pa mí mo pọ́nnu lá, o bojúwẹ̀yìn mo dọ̀bálẹ̀, o tiwọ́ bọ̀gbẹ́; o fẹ́ dè mí ni?

English: You borrow money at home and you refuse to repay it, you arrive on the farm and open the pot containing plantains for inspection, and when you have a baby you name it Adéṣínà; if ṣí-ṣí does not leave you alone, why don't you leave it alone?
Yoruba: O ṣíwó nílé o kò san, o dóko o ń ṣí ìkòkò ọ̀gẹ̀dẹ̀ wò, o bímọ o sọ ọ́ ní Adéṣínà; bí ṣíṣí ò bá sìn lẹ́yìn rẹ, o kì í sìn lẹ́yìn-in ṣíṣí?

English: You are perched at the lofty neck of the palm-tree and you are bandying words with God.
Yoruba: O wà lọ́rùn ọ̀pẹ ò ń bá Ọlọ́run ṣèlérí.

English: Innumerable wives, innumerable problems.
Yoruba: Obìnrin bẹẹrẹ òṣì bẹẹrẹ.

English: A woman who cuts wood in the grove of Orò has cut her last.
Yoruba: Obìnrin tó gégi nígbó Orò, ó gé àgémọ.

English: A woman who cuts wood in the grove of Orò has cut her last.
Yoruba: Òbòó ní ìtìjú ló mú òun sápamọ́ sábẹ́ inú, ṣùgbọ́n bí okó bá dé, òun á sínà fún un.

English: The parrot says no one will prescribe it as a sacrifice in its presence; when it sees people consulting the oracle, it will go hide in its closet.
Yoruba: Odídẹrẹ ní wọn ò lè tí ojú òun yan òun mọ́ ẹbọ; bí wọ́n bá ń dÍfá, òun a sá wọlé.

English: The parrot eyes the cramped house as though it would enter; the big-headed bird ágbìgbò eyes the hole in the tree as though it did not emerged from there.
Yoruba: Odídẹrẹ́ ń wolé hóró-hóró bí ẹni pé yó kòó sílé; àgbìgbò náà wọ̀ràn ń wohò igi bí ẹni pé kò tibẹ̀ jáde.

English: A chasm is nothing to lean on.
Yoruba: Òfèèrèfé ò ṣéé fẹ̀yìn tì.

English: A long foreseen war does not kill a cripple.
Yoruba: Ogun àgbọ́tẹ́lẹ̀ kì í pa arọ.

English: What one eats is what one sells; but not like Kerosene.
Yoruba: Ohun à ń jẹ là ń tà; bí epo òyìnbó kọ́.

English: All things are good or pleasing only to a point.
Yoruba: Ohun gbogbo, ìwọn ló dùn mọ.

English: It is never long before a thing becomes invaluable to the owner.
Yoruba: Ohun gbogbo kì í pẹ́ jọ olóhun lójú.

English: Nothing ever satisfies a thief.
Yoruba: Ohun gbogbo kì í tó olè.

English: Everything has its price, but no one knows his/her own worth; bloodshed never has a good cause.
Yoruba: Ohun gbogbo là ń diyelé; ṣùgbọ́n kò sẹ́ni tó moye araa ẹ̀; ẹ̀jẹ̀ ò fojú rere jáde.

English: One does not sniff at what one will eventually eat anyway.
Yoruba: Ohun tí a bá máa jẹ a kì í fi runmú.

English: That which one should do slowly and carefully one should not do in a hurry; sooner or later everything comes within one's reach.
Yoruba: Ohun tí à bá ṣe pẹ̀sẹ̀, ká má fi ṣe ìkánjú; bó pẹ́ títí ohun gbogbo a tó ọwọ́ ẹni.

English: Whatever one trains one's eyes upon will not get charred.
Yoruba: Ohun tí a bá tẹjúmọ́ kì í jóná.

English: Whatever one handles gently will not be ruined; it is what one attempts with force that causes one grief.
Yoruba: Ohun tí a fi ẹ̀sọ̀ mú kì í bàjẹ́; ohun tí a fagbára mú ní ń nini lára.

English: It is that which one gives to a caretaker to look after that he looks after.
Yoruba: Ohun tí a fún ẹlẹ́mọ̀ṣọ́ ní ń ṣọ́.

English: It is always something one does not expect to become a load that eventually becomes a huge task.
Yoruba: Ohun tí a ò pé yó dẹrù ní ń diṣẹ́.

English: It is whatever one can find that one uses to fill gaps in one's roof; that does not apply to a faggot spewing flames.
Yoruba: Ohun tí a rí la fi ń bọ párá ẹni; bí igi tíná ń bẹ lẹ́nuu ẹ̀ kọ́.

English: That which a dog sees and barks at is nothing compared to what the sheep contemplates in silence.
Yoruba: Ohun tí ajá rí tó fi ń gbó ò tó èyí tí àgùntàn-án fi ń ṣèran wò.

English: Whatever the invalid craves is what spells his/her death.
Yoruba: Ohun tó bá wu olókùnrùn ní ń pa á.

English: Whatever a child crave will not give him/her stomach ache.
Yoruba: Ohun tó bá wu ọmọọ́ jẹ kì í run ọmọ nínú.

English: It is all of a sudden that one sees a baby in the arms of the colobus monkey.
Yoruba: Òjijì là ń rọ́mọ lọ́wọ́ alákẹdun.

English: When people are trapped in a hut by a downpour there is no sense in fighting to get a word in the discussion; after the older person has spoken, the younger person will speak.
Yoruba: Òjò kan kì í báni lábà ká jìjàdù ọ̀rọ̀ọ́ sọ; bí ẹgbọ́n bá sọ tán, àbúrò á sọ.

English: The rain is falling, the call of the secret cult is sounding loudly outside; the threading pin that lacks a change of clothing will sleep naked.
Yoruba: Òjò ń rọ̀, orò ń ké; atọ́kùn àlùgbè tí ò láṣọ méjì a ṣe ògèdèǹgbé sùn.

English: The edge of a razor is not a thing to lick.
Yoruba: Ojú abẹ ò ṣéé pọ́nlá.

English: It is not in the watchful presence of a kite that a chicken strolls to a rock.
Yoruba: Ojú àwòdì kọ́ ladìẹ ń re àpáta.

English: The muslim cannot take his mind off liquor, he has a child and named him Ìmórù máhá wá.
Yoruba: Ojú ìmàle ò kúrò lọ́tí, ó bímọ ẹ̀ ó sọ ọ́ ní Ìmórù-máhá-wá.

English: Ojú ìmàle ò kúrò lọ́tí, ó bímọ ẹ̀ ó sọ ọ́ ní Lèmámù.
Yoruba: The following is a variant.

English: It is at the same place that the youth will come up on the elder.
Yoruba: Ojú kan náà lèwe ń bágbà.

English: “It takes a great deal of fortitude to set out for Ibadan”; he ties his money around his waist.
Yoruba: Ojú là ń gbó re ọ̀nà Ìbàdàn: ó fi ogún ọ̀kẹ́ gbàdí.

English: The husband of the wife is only being unduly hasty; in time two concubines will inevitably quarrel.
Yoruba: Ojú ní ń kán ọkọlóbìnrin; àlè méjì á jà dandan.

English: “We might see each other again” who sold his dog for twenty cowries; he said if that is how things are sold, they might well see each other again.
Yoruba: “Ojú ò fẹ́rakù” tó ta ajáa ẹ̀ lókòó; ó ní bó bá jẹ́ bẹ́ẹ̀ ni wọ́n ńtà á wọn a máa tún araa wọn rí.

English: It is in the presence of the cat that the mouse must not saunter.
Yoruba: Ojú ológbò lèkúté ò gbọdọ̀ yan.

English: Eyes that cannot stand lamplight, and that cannot stand sunlight, are not eyes that will last one until the twilight of one's life.
Yoruba: Ojú tí kì í wo iná, tí kì í wo òòrùn; ojú tí ń báni dalẹ́ kọ́.

English: The eyes that will last one until night time will not start oozing matter at the dawn.
Yoruba: Ojú tí yóò bani kalẹ̀ kì í tàárọ̀ ṣepin.

English: Covetousness “is” the father of envy.
Yoruba: Ojúkòkòrò baba ọ̀kánjúà.

English: He entered through the front door, but it was through a hidden shortcut that he snuck away; it consulted the Ifa oracle for the visitor who has an affair with his host's wife.
Yoruba: Ojúlé ló bá wá; ẹ̀bùrú ló gbà lọ́; ó dÍfá fún àlejò tí ń fẹ́ obìnrin onílé.

English: Horses sell for only one cowrie in heaven; there is no shortage of people who will go there, but who ever returns from there?
Yoruba: Oókan ni wọ́n ń ta ẹṣin lọ́run; ẹni tí yó lọ ò wọ́n; ṣùgbọ́n ẹni tí yó bọ̀ ló kù.

English: One cowrie makes a miser of one; two cowries make a spendthrift of one.
Yoruba: Oókan-án sọni dahun eéjì sọni dàpà.

English: A huge morsel forces the child's eyes wide open.
Yoruba: Òkèlè gbò-ǹ-gbò-ó fẹ ọmọ lójú toto.

English: Only one morsel kills an elder.
Yoruba: Òkèlè kan ní ń pa àgbà.

English: The giant bush rat that has its tail stripped by a trap knows that it is its visit to the fifth-day market that was postponed.
Yoruba: Òkété tó bọ́ ìrùú mọ̀ pé ìpéjú ọjà ọrún òun ló sún.

English: Large bundle, father of all wars; when preparing for war, each person prepares his bundle to take along.
Yoruba: Òketè baba ogun; bí a ṣígun, olúkúlùkù ní ń di òketèe ẹ̀ lọ́wọ́.

English: It is a mature and sizeable dog that one sacrifices to Ògún.
Yoruba: Òkìpa ajá la fi ń bọ Ògún.

English: A stone thrown in anger does not kill a bird.
Yoruba: Òkò àbínújù kì í pẹyẹ.

English: The farm is where gbégbé belongs.
Yoruba: Oko ni gbégbé ń gbé.

English: A missile that a bird sees will not kill the bird.
Yoruba: Òkò tí ẹyẹ́ bá rí kì í pẹyẹ.

English: The eunuch cannot make fun of the person with gonorrhea.
Yoruba: Òkóbó ò lè fi alátọ̀sí ṣẹ̀sín.

English: It is a dead elephant one approaches with a cutlass; who would dare draw a machete to attack an elephant “that is alive”?
Yoruba: Òkù àjànàkú là ń yọ ogbó sí; ta ní jẹ́ yọ agada séerin?

English: It is never long before a ram's tethering rope slips to its horns.
Yoruba: Okùn àgbò kì í gbèé dorí ìwo.

English: No thief steals a gbẹ̀du drum.
Yoruba: Olè kì í gbé gbẹ̀du.

English: The dozing person does not confess; nothing deceives like sleep.
Yoruba: Olóògbé ò jẹ́wọ́; atannijẹ bí orun.

English: It is those who worry about their image who die in war.
Yoruba: Olójútì logun ń pa.

English: The facial scarifier does not scarify an albino's face.
Yoruba: Olóòlà kì í kọ àfín.

English: The cult priest raises his divining wand and the worshippers proclaim the omen is good; whether it is good or bad they do not know.
Yoruba: Olórìṣàá gbé ààjà sókè, wọ́n ní ire ni; bí ire ni, bí ibi ni, wọn ò mọ̀.

English: Water is the first thing one's foot encounters before it encounters the sand.
Yoruba: Omi là ń kọ́ ọ́ tẹ̀ ká tó tẹ iyanrìn.

English: Today, my chicken has gone to roost in the wrong place; tomorrow, my chicken has gone to roost in the wrong place; some day soon the errant chicken will disappear permanently.
Yoruba: Òní, adìẹẹ̀ mí ṣìwọ̀; ọ̀la, adìẹẹ̀ mí ṣìwọ̀; ọjọ́ kan la óò fẹ́ àìwọlé adìẹ kù.

English: Today, the patriarch collapsed; tomorrow, the patriarch collapsed; one day death will throw the patriarch.
Yoruba: Òní, babaá dákú; ọ̀la, babaá dákú; ọjọ́ kan ni ikú yóò dá baba.

English: Today, the horse threw the patriach; tomorrow, the horse threw the patriarch; if the patriarch does not stop riding the horse, one day the horse will throw him to his death.
Yoruba: Òní, ẹṣin-ín dá baba; ọ̀la, ẹṣin-ín dá baba; bí baba ò bá yé ẹṣin-ín gùn, ọjọ́ kan lẹṣin óò dá baba pa.

English: The hair scrapper is scraping your head and you are feeling your scalp with your hand; what do you expect will be left for you there?
Yoruba: Onígbàjámọ̀ ń fárí fún ọ, ò ń fọwọ́ kàn án wò; èwo ló máa kù fún ọ níbẹ̀.

English: The home owner heads for home and they say the guard is on the run; the guard is not on the run, he is merely heading home.
Yoruba: Onílé ń relé wọ́n ní oǹdè ń sá; oǹdè ò sá, ilé ẹ̀ ló lọ.

English: Today, the antelope falls into a ditch; tomorrow, the antelope falls into the ditch; is there no other animal in the forest?
Yoruba: Ònímónìí, ẹtuú jìnfìń ọ̀lamọ́la, ẹtuú jìnfìn; ẹran miìíràn ò sí nígbó ni?

English: Always it is the hot-tempered person that finds food for the even-tempered person.
Yoruba: Onínúfùfù ní ń wá oúnjẹ fún onínúwẹ́rẹ́wẹ́rẹ́.

English: Only the patient person will win the daughter of the Hausa man.
Yoruba: Onísùúrù ní ń ṣe ọkọ ọmọ Aláwúsá.

English: The owner of the yams is the one who knows where the mature yams are.
Yoruba: Oníṣu ní ń mọ ibi iṣú gbé ta sí.

English: A favor has turned to mud in Awẹ́ towń the vulture did a favor and went bald.
Yoruba: Ooré di ẹrẹ̀ lAwẹ́; àwọn igúnnugún ṣoore wọ́n pá lórí.

English: The benediction is longer than the sermon.
Yoruba: Oore ọ̀fẹ́ gùn jùwàásù.

English: The favor Agbe did in Ọ̀fà town reduced him to begging.
Yoruba: Oore tí Agbeé ṣe lỌ́fà, ó dagbe.

English: The sort of favor the vulture did and went bald, the sort of favor the ground hornbill did and developed a goitre, one does not do it.
Yoruba: Oore tí igúnnugún ṣe tó fi pá lórí, tí àkàlá ṣe tó fi yọ gẹ̀gẹ̀, a kì í ṣe irú ẹ̀.

English: The favor was excessive; it was repaid with wickedness.
Yoruba: Ooreé pọ̀, a fìkà san án.

English: The porcupine itself will procure the wood with which it will be roasted.
Yoruba: Òòrẹ̀ ní ń ṣẹ́gi tí a ó fi wì í.

English: The head of a snake is nothing to scratch one's nose with.
Yoruba: Orí ejò ò ṣéé họ imú.

English: Singing goes before plotting.
Yoruba: Orin ní ń ṣíwájú ọ̀tẹ̀.

English: The song that we sang yesterday, without sleep, without respite; we do not resume singing it in the morning.
Yoruba: Orin tí a kọ lánàá, tí a ò sùn, tí a ò wo, a kì í tún jí kọ ọ́ láàárọ̀.

English: A small god is not a thing to hang from the rafters.
Yoruba: Òrìṣà kékeré ò ṣéé há ní párá.

English: The young chick does not know the eagle; it is its mother that knows the kite.
Yoruba: Òròmọ adìẹ ò màwòdì; ìyá ẹ̀ ló màṣá.

English: Hissing goes before crying; had-one-but-known comes at the conclusion of an unfortunate matter; all the elders in the town assembled but they could find no antidote for had-we-but-known.
Yoruba: Òṣé ní ń ṣíwájú ẹkún; àbámọ̀ ní ń gbẹ̀yìn ọ̀ràn; gbogbo àgbà ìlú pé, wọn ò rí oògùn àbàmọ̀ ṣe.

English: Food that one expects to last, one does not eat in huge handfuls.
Yoruba: Oúnjẹ tí a ó jẹ pẹ́, a kì í bu òkèlèe ẹ̀ tóbi.

English: Money does not live with a thief.
Yoruba: Owó ò bá olè gbé.

English: A hush-hush matter; difficult to utter as speech.
Yoruba: Òwúyẹ́; a-ṣòro-ó-sọ bí ọ̀rọ̀.

English: One does not count a pregnancy as a child already delivered.
Yoruba: Oyún inú: a kì í kà á kún ọmọọ tilẹ̀.

English: Only those who struggle with one know one's strategies.
Yoruba: Ọ̀bánijà ní ń mọ ìjagun ẹni.

English: Ọ̀bàrà receive a cudgel blow; it consulted the Ifá oracle for a disobedient child.
Yoruba: Ọ̀bàrà gba kùm̀mọ̀; ó dÍfá fún a-láwìí-ì-gbọ́.

English: Purveyor of general disaster, who carries a gángan drum into town.
Yoruba: Ọ̀bàyéjẹ́, tí ń ru gángan wọ̀lú.

English: “Stew is the breast milk of adults” is what killed the calabash repairer of Ògòdò town.
Yoruba: “Ọbẹ̀ lọmú àgbà” ló pa onígbaǹso Ògòdò.

English: The ṣìlò knife is playing with one and one says it is not sharp; just as in play it slashes one's hand.
Yoruba: Ọbẹ ṣìlòó ń báni ṣeré a ní kò mú; bí eré bí eré ó ń pani lọ́wọ́.

English: The sort of stew you cooked and set the house on fire, you will explain.
Yoruba: Ọbẹ̀ tóo sè tílé fi jóná wàá sọ ọ́.

English: Inspector of the ground inspects the ground; if a goat wishes to lie down it first inspects the ground.
Yoruba: Ọ̀bẹlẹ̀wò bẹlẹ̀wò; bí ewúrẹ́ yó bàá dùbúlẹ̀ a bẹ ilẹ̀ ibẹ̀ wò.

English: The monkey will be its own death.
Yoruba: Ọ̀bọ ni yo para ẹ̀.

English: Sprightly person who hurls himself sidewise against a tree.
Yoruba: Ọ̀dárayá tí ń fi ẹ̀gbẹ́ na igi.

English: Habitual criminal bird that eats oranges.
Yoruba: Ọ̀daràn ẹyẹ tí ń musàn.

English: The hunter who would kill elephants with his cap; his fame lasts only one day.
Yoruba: Ọdẹ a-fi-fìlà-pa-erin, ọjọ́ kan ni òkìkíi ẹ̀ ń mọ.

English: The never-soil-your-foot-with-mud dandy eventually soils his whole body.
Yoruba: Ọ̀gáa má fi ẹsẹ̀ yí ẹrẹ̀, gbogbo ara ní ń fi yí i.

English: A full-grown warthog is not something to confront.
Yoruba: Ọ̀gán ìmàdò ò ṣéé kò lójú.

English: The banana is rotting, people say it is ripening.
Yoruba: Ọ̀gẹ̀dẹ̀ ń bàjẹ́, a ní ó ń pọ́n.

English: A fool carries a cudjel around.
Yoruba: Ọ̀gọ̀ ń gbé ọ̀gọ rù.

English: The iron stake has been driven into the ground; the problem now is how to pull it out.
Yoruba: Ọ̀gbágbá wọlẹ̀, ó ku àtiyọ.

English: It is excessive cunning that kills the mature cane rat.
Yoruba: Ọgbọ́n àgbọ́njù ní ń pa òdù ọ̀yà.

English: Excessive cleverness turns one into a phantom; if there is too much magical charm it turns the owner into an imbecile; if a woman is too cunning her husband's clothes wind up ill-fitting.
Yoruba: Ọgbọ́n àgbọ́njù ní ń sọ ẹni diwin; bí oògún bá pọ̀ lápọ̀jù a sọni di wèrè; bóbìnrín bá gbọ́n àgbọ́njù, péńpé laṣọ ọkọọ ẹ̀ ń mọ.

English: Today's wisdom, next year's madness.
Yoruba: Ọgbọ́n ọdúnnìí, wèrè ẹ̀míì.

English: It is with cunning and patience that one brings an elephant into town.
Yoruba: Ọgbọ́n pẹ̀lúu sùúrù la fi ń mú erin wọ̀lú.

English: The day one is destined to be lost one is never able to contain one's excitement.
Yoruba: Ọjọ́ tí a ó bàá nù, gágá lara ń yáni.

English: The day one arranged one's corn in the granary, one did not think in terms of the rat.
Yoruba: Ọjọ́ tí a to ọkà a ò to ti èkúté mọ́ ọ.

English: The day farming entails being careful not to hurt the soil, one should stop farming.
Yoruba: Ọjọ́ tí àgbẹ̀ ṣíṣeé bá di kíyèsílẹ̀, ká ṣíwọ́ oko ríro.

English: On the day the white flying ants wish to swarm, the worms that prey on them keep still.
Yoruba: Ọjọ́ tí elétutuú bá máa fò, ìjàm̀pere kì í rìn.

English: “It is” an insatiable farmer who plants cotton on a farm by the stream.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kánjúwà àgbẹ̀ tí ń gbin òwú sóko àkùrọ̀.

English: Covetousness, father of all diseases.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kánjúwà baba àrùn.

English: Covetousness, father of thievery; bug-eyed greedy person stares at another person's property without blinking.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kánjúwà baba olè; àwòròǹṣoṣòó wo ohun olóhun má ṣèẹ́jú.

English: A greedy person takes a morsel of food and tears gush from his eyes.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kánjúwàá bu òkèlè, ojù ẹ̀ẹ́ lami.

English: The covetous person arrives in a gathering, and his eyes dart about restlessly.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kánjúwà èèyàn-án dé àwùjọ, ó wòkè yàn-yàn-àn-yàn.

English: The greedy person does not drink other people's blood; he drinks only his own.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kánjúwà kì í mu ẹ̀jẹ̀ ẹlòmíràn; ẹ̀jẹ̀ ara ẹ̀ náà ní ń mu.

English: Impatient envy is not a good state in which to seek anything.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kánjúwà ò ṣéé fi wá nǹkan.

English: The insatiable cat that sits in the doorway, does it want to kill cats in another house?
Yoruba: Ọ̀kánjúwà ológbò tó jókòó sẹ́nu ọ̀nà; ṣé eku eléku ló fẹ́ pa jẹ?

English: It is an insatiable Ṣàngó priest who names his son Bámigbóṣé one should procure for oneself a ritual rod one can carry.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kánjúwà Oníṣàngó ní ń sọ ọmọ rẹ̀ ní Bámgbóṣé; ìwọ̀n oṣé tí a lè gbé là ń gbé.

English: Covetousness and thievery are similar to each other.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kánjúwà pẹ̀lú olè, déédé ni wọ́n jẹ́.

English: The insatiable person receives twelve thousand cowries out fourteen thousand; he asked that the remaining two thousand be shared, perhaps two hundred of them will come to him.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kánjúwàá pín ẹgbàafà nínú ẹgbàaje; ó ní kí wọ́n pín ẹgbàá kan tó kù, bóyá igbiwó tún lè kan òun.

English: The squirrel scrambles up the ìrókò treé the fire in the hunter's eyes is doused.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kẹ́rẹ́ gorí ìrókò, ojú ọdẹẹ́ dá.

English: The boat is leaking, the boat is leaking! After it sinks won't matters end?
Yoruba: Ọkọ̀ ń jò, ọkọ̀ ń jò! Ìgbà tó bá rì, kò parí ná?

English: Broom sticks drop off one by one.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kọ̀ọ̀kan lọwọ̀ ń yọ.

English: The millipede knew the way before it went blind.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kùn-ún mọ̀nà tẹ́lẹ̀ kójú ẹ̀ tó fọ́.

English: A man who marries two jealous women has no one to tend his home in his absence.
Yoruba: Ọkùnrin tó fẹ́ òjòwú méjì sílé ò rẹ́ni fi ṣọ́lé.

English: “Tomorrow I take my leave,” who uses a shallow pot as his water jar.
Yoruba: “Ọla ni mò ń lọ,” tí ń fi koto ṣe àmù.

English: “Greatness won't let me see”; the son of the Èwí, king of Adó, who lights a lamp to walk with in broad daylight.
Yoruba: “Ọlá ò jẹ́ kí n ríran”; ọmọ Èwí Adó tí ń tanná rìn lọ́sàn-án.

English: It is the person who separates two fighters who gets gashed on the head.
Yoruba: Ọ̀làjà ní ń fi orí gbọgbẹ́.

English: A hunter does not fire off his gun because of the wind.
Yoruba: Ọlọ́dẹ kì í torí atẹ́gùn yìnbọn.

English: The excessively cunning person is trying his hand at stealing.
Yoruba: Ọlọ́gbọ́n bẹẹrẹẹ́ pète ìgárá.

English: A chick flies up, and we exclaim, “A game animal has escaped, alas!”
Yoruba: Ọmọ adìẹẹ́ fò, a ní “Ẹrán lọ àkẹ́ẹ̀!”

English: The seeds in an ayò game are not things to be angry at.
Yoruba: Ọmọ inú ayò ò ṣéé bá bínú.

English: The child of your rival-wife dies and you say the person who saw you in heaven did not lie; what if your own child dies?
Yoruba: Ọmọ orogún ẹ ẹ́ kú, o ní ẹní rí ẹ lọ́run ò purọ́; bí tìẹ́ bá kú ńkọ́?

English: A child insults an ìrókò tree and glances back apprehensively; does it take revenge immediately?
Yoruba: Ọmọdé bú ìrókò, ó bojú wẹ̀yìn; òòjọ́ ní ń jà?

English: A child wakes from sleep and says in code, “Bean fritters two-by-two.” Had the others been taking them thus before he woke would any have been left?
Yoruba: Ọmọdé jí ti ojú orun wá, ó ní “Àkàrà kéjìkéjì”; wọ́n ti ń mú u kẹ́ẹ̀ kó tó jí, ì ká ká níkẹ̀?

English: A pestle is a lethal weapon in itself, let alone after rubbing poison on it.
Yoruba: Ọmọrí odó pani lọ́tọ̀, ká tó wí pé ká kùn ún lóògùn.

English: The drunkard does not drink the gourd through.
Yoruba: Ọ̀mùtí ò mu agbè já.

English: A short cut causes a person to land on his palms.
Yoruba: Ọ̀nà ẹ̀bùrú dá ọwọ́ olúwaa ẹ̀ tẹlẹ̀.

English: The road to the secret grove of the egúngún cult may lead to heaven.
Yoruba: Ọ̀nà ìgbàlẹ̀ a máa já sọ́run.

English: It is by missing one's way that one learns the way; if one does not fall one does not learn how to tie one's load properly.
Yoruba: Ọ̀nà là ń ṣì mọ̀nà; bí a ò bá ṣubú, a kì í mọ ẹrùú dì.

English: The road will eventually expose the thief; the farm hut will eventually expose the farmer.
Yoruba: Ọ̀nà ni yó mùú olè; ahéré ni yó mùú olóko.

English: The pathway of the throat, the pathway to heaven: the two are very much alike.
Yoruba: Ọ̀nà ọ̀fun, ọ̀nà ọ̀run: méjèèjì bákan náà ni wọ́n rí.

English: The walking-stick that is carried on the shoulder, which has its eye pointed backward.
Yoruba: Ọ̀pá àgbéléjìká, a-tẹ̀yìn-lójú.

English: It is a great deal of medicine that possesses a child and robs it of all self-control.
Yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ oògùn ní ń ru ọmọ gàle-gàle.

English: Is it because a snake is biting a toad that one says the earth portends disaster?
Yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀lọ́ lejò ń bùjẹ, tí à ń wí pé ilẹ̀ẹ́ rorò?

English: The responsibility for trouble never fails to fall on the head of the tortoise.
Yoruba: Ọ̀ràn kì í yẹ̀ lórí alábahun.

English: Only huge problems befall the mahogany bean tree; only minor problems befall the baobab tree.
Yoruba: Ọ̀ràn ńlá-ńlá ní ń bá àpá; ọ̀ràn ṣẹ́kú-ṣẹ́kú ní ń bá oṣè.

English: Problems have hardly any effect at all on the pumpkin shoot; broken off in the morning, it reappears the following night.
Yoruba: Ọ̀ràn ò dun gbọ̀ọ̀rọ̀; a dá a láàárọ̀, ó yọ lálẹ́.

English: The problem posed by the banana tree is nothing that calls for a machete.
Yoruba: Ọ̀ràn ọ̀gẹ̀dẹ̀ ò tó ohun tí à ń yọ àdá sí.

English: Words are what the child of the ear eats.
Yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ lọmọ etí ń jẹ.

English: The matter in question is not overwhelming; it is the elaboration for it that is almost forbidding.
Yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ ò pọ̀, àkàwée ẹ̀ ló pọ̀.

English: There matter pertaining to corn has a limit; life has its measure.
Yoruba: Ọ̀ràn ọkàá ní ìba; ayé ní òṣùwọ̀n.

English: A lot of words will not fill a basket; it will only lead to lies.
Yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ púpọ̀ ò kún agbọ̀n; irọ́ ní ń mú wá.

English: A matter that is wrapped in gbòdògì leaves will, if wrapped in cocoyam leaves, rip them to tatters.
Yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ tí a dì ní gbòdògì: bo déwée kókò yó fàya.

English: A matter that does not have a means to voice itself had better be silent.
Yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ tí ò ní ohùn fífọ̀, dídákẹ́ ló yẹ ẹ́.

English: The beauty bestowed by tattooing with the juice of the bùjé plant does not last nine days; a prostitute's beauty does not last more than a year.
Yoruba: Ọ̀ṣọ́ oníbùjé ò pé isán; ọ̀ṣọ́ onínàbì ò ju ọdún lọ.

English: One step after the other is the manner to walk through mire; one step after the other is how one walks through dust.
Yoruba: Ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ là ń tẹ ẹrẹ̀; ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ là ń tẹ eruku.

English: Your eyes are on the patriarch's hand, but they ignore his feet.
Yoruba: Ọwọ́ọ baba lẹ wò, ẹ ò wo ẹsẹ̀ẹ baba.

English: Expensive commodities come to the home; inexpensive ones go to the market.
Yoruba: Ọ̀wọ́n yúnlé, ọ̀pọ̀ọ́ yúnjà.

English: Stockfish is not a meat one eats without repercussions; keep on drinking herbal remedies.
Yoruba: Pala-pálà kì í ṣe ẹran àjẹgbé; ẹ ṣáà máa mu àgúnmu.

English: The grassland that proposes to burn into the river is asking for a lecture.
Yoruba: Pápá tó ní òun ó jòó wọ odò, ọ̀rọ̀ ló fẹ́ẹ́ gbọ́.

English: The serpent refuses to be trifled with.
Yoruba: Paramọ́lẹ̀ẹ́ kọ ọ̀ràn àfojúdi.

English: It is very carefully and patiently that a snake climbs the coconut palm.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀lẹ́-pẹ̀lẹ́ lejòó fi ń gun àgbọn.

English: The soiling caused by speech; it stains a person and cannot be removed.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀tẹ̀pẹ́tẹ̀ ọ̀rọ̀, a-ta-síni-lára-má-wọ̀n-ọ́n.

English: It may take long, but the coop will eventually cover the chicken.
Yoruba: Pípẹ́ ni yó pẹ̀ẹ́, agbọ̀n á bo adìẹ.

English: It may take long, but the stammerer will eventually manage to say “Papa.”
Yoruba: Pípẹ́ ni yó pẹ̀ẹ́, akólòlò á pe baba.

English: It may take a while, but the palm-wine tapster will descend from atop the palm-tree.
Yoruba: Pípẹ́ ni yó pẹ̀ẹ́, akọ̀pẹ yó wàá sílẹ̀.

English: It may take a while, but the under-water swimmer will eventually surface.
Yoruba: Pípẹ́ ni yó pẹ̀ẹ́, amòòkùn yó jàáde nínú odò.

English: It may take a while, but the deceitful person will not be undiscovered.
Yoruba: Pípẹ́ ni yó pẹ̀ẹ́, èké ò mú rá.

English: It may take a while, but the person who went to the stream will return home.
Yoruba: Pípẹ́ ni yó pẹ̀ẹ́, ẹní lọ sódò á bọ̀ wálé.

English: It may take a while, but Ọ̀rúnmìlà will surely eat corn.
Yoruba: Pípẹ́ ni yó pẹ̀ẹ́, Ọ̀rúnmìlà yó jẹ àgbàdo dandan.

English: Think it through before you do it; that is better than doing it before you think it through.
Yoruba: Rò ó kóo tó ṣe é, ó sàn ju kóo ṣé kóo tó rò ó.

English: Invoke it exactly as the maker of the charm instructed.
Yoruba: Sà á bí olóògùn-ún ti wí.

English: Patience has its profits.
Yoruba: Sùúrùú lérè.

English: Patience is the talisman for living.
Yoruba: Sùúrù loògùn ayé.

English: There is no end to the need for patience.
Yoruba: Sùúrù ò lópin.

English: Ṣàǹgbákó makes a sound and we say the sound is foul, and then Ṣàǹgbàkù lends its voice in its support.
Yoruba: Ṣàǹgbákó ró, a ní kò róo re, Ṣàǹgbàkùú gbè é lẹ́sẹ̀.

English: Exhibitionist, a dog owner who ties a sheep's mane around his own neck.
Yoruba: Ṣe-ká-rí-mi, alájá tó so ẹ̀gi mọ́rùn.

English: “May I perch here awhile?” is the ruse by which the climber-parasite becomes a permanent resident.
Yoruba: “Ṣé kí n fìdí hẹ?” làfòmọ́ fi ń di onílé.

English: The habit that made a person a pawn: if the person persists in it it will make him or her a slave.
Yoruba: Ṣe-ǹ-ṣe dìwọ̀fà, bó ṣe é yó dẹrúu wọn.

English: The habit of the goat is what the sheep pays attention to.
Yoruba: Ṣe-ǹ-ṣe ewúrẹ́ làgùntàn ńfiyè sí.

English: “Shoot at it” does not help one find arrows.
Yoruba: “Ta á sí i” kì í báni wá ọfà.

English: Who sent Abẹ́lu into a boat, as a result of which action he says he was drowned in the boat?
Yoruba: Ta ní rán Abẹ́lù wọ ọkọ̀, tó ní ọkọ̀ọ́ ri òun?

English: “It is yesterday's matter that we are fighting over” is what killed Chief Know-Nothing.
Yoruba: “Tàná là ńjà lé lórí”, ló pa Baálẹ̀ẹ Kòmọ̀kan.

English: An unbecoming thing, as unpleasant to wear as the garment of disgrace.
Yoruba: Tantabùlù, aṣòróówọ̀ bí ẹ̀wù àṣejù.

English: Incessant proneness to fighting is the affliction of Ọ̀pọ́ndá people.
Yoruba: Tìjà tìjà ní ń ṣe ará Ọ̀pọ́ndá.

English: It is the persistence of daylight that imposes suffering on the mud-floor worm; when night falls it will find food.
Yoruba: Tọ̀sán tọ̀sán ní ń pọ́n ìtalẹ̀ lójú; bílẹ̀ẹ́ bá ṣú yó di olóuńjẹ.

English: No cheese today, but there will be cheese tomorrow.
Yoruba: Wàrà ò sí lónìí, wàràá wà lọ́la.

English: Slowly, slowly is the manner in which termites consume a house.
Yoruba: Wẹ́rẹ́ wẹ́rẹ́ nikán ń jẹlé.

English: Watching is enough for a spectacle.
Yoruba: Wíwòó tó ìran.

English: “Demolish your house and I will help you rebuild it”: he will give one only one bundle of thatching grass.
Yoruba: “Wó ilé ẹ kí ń bá ọ kọ”: ẹrù ikán kan ní ńpa fúnni.

English: The greedy person fed to satiation, and he summons his friends.
Yoruba: Wọ̀bìàá yó tán, ó pe ẹgbẹ́ ẹ̀ wá.

English: People said, “Ìbàrìbá person, you child stole something.” She responds, “That he stole something I can understand, but I cannot understand the rope around his neck.”
Yoruba: Wọ́n ní,; “Ìbàrìbá, ọmọ ẹẹ́ jalè.” Ó ní “A gbọ́ tolè tó jà; èwo lokùn ọrùn-un ẹ̀'?”

English: People lie to you and you do not accept the lie; can you ever know what the truth is?
Yoruba: Wọ́n purọ́ fún ọ, o ò gbà; o lè dé ìdí òótọ́?

English: Because the dog sits on its haunches they went and spent their money on purchasing a monkey.
Yoruba: Wọ́n torí ajá ń lóṣòó lọ fowó rọ̀bọ.

English: The leopard's stealthy gait is not a result of cowardice; it is simply stalking a prey.
Yoruba: Yíyọ́ ẹkùn, tojo kọ́; ohun tí yó jẹ ní ń wá.

English: All your strutting and bragging, where is it now? The wife threw the husband down so hard that he grew a hump on his back.
Yoruba: Yọkọlú-yọkọlú, kò ha tán bí? Ìyàwó gbọ́kọ ṣánlẹ̀, ọkọọ́ yọké.

English: We lop off the hyena's right fore limb; we lop off the hyena's left hind limb; the question is, who will face it now?
Yoruba: A hán ìkokò lọ́wọ́ ọ̀tún, a hán ìkokò lẹ́sẹ̀ òsì; ó ku ẹni tí yó kò ó lójú.

English: One should not attempt to scare an old “woman” with a huge penis.
Yoruba: A kì í dá ẹ̀rù okó ńlá ba arúgbó.

English: One does not fall from a prone position.
Yoruba: A kì í dùbúlẹ̀ ṣubú.

English: One is never so fortunate at daily thievery that it matches owning one's own things.
Yoruba: A kì í fi ojoojúmọ́ rí olè jà kó dà bíi tọwọ́ ẹni.

English: One never trades with other people's eyes and profit.
Yoruba: A kì í fi ojú olójú ṣòwò ká jèrè.

English: One does not easily or casually take the child from the palm-nut.
Yoruba: A kì í fi ojúbọ́rọ́ gba ọmọ lọ́wọ́ èkùrọ́.

English: One does not hear the thud of a falling leaf.
Yoruba: A kì í gbọ́ “gbì” ìràwé.

English: One does not, despite knowing where one is going, suffer a constricted neck from one's heavy load.
Yoruba: A kì í mọ ibi tí à ńlọ kí ọrùn ó wọ ẹni.

English: One does not say there is a time for the market; if it were so, why would people continuously patronize it?
Yoruba: A kì í sọ pé ọjàá nígbà; bó bá nígbà, kíníṣe tí wọ́n tún ńná a?

English: One does not carry the ọ̀jẹ̀ masquerade and yet affect bashfulness; the mendicant's eyes must always be like flint.
Yoruba: A kì í ṣe ọ̀jẹ̀ ṣe ojú tì mí; konko lojú alágbe.

English: One does not conduct one's feud with an animal in a half-hearted manner; if one finds a snail one hits it with a matchet.
Yoruba: A kì í ṣe ọ̀tẹ̀ eranko gán-ń-gán; bí a bá he ìgbín àdá là ń nà á.

English: One does not scratch the ground for the chicken to find food.
Yoruba: A kì í walẹ̀ fún adìẹ jẹ.

English: The more one weeds ẹ̀kukù the more it sprouts leaves; the more one tramples aṣẹro the more it grows; the more one rails against Ògún the more he thrives.
Yoruba: À ń pa ẹ̀kukù, ẹ̀kukù ń rúwé; à ń yan nínú aṣẹro, aṣẹro ń dàgbà; à ń kébòsí Ògún, ara Ògún ń le.

English: We make circles round the mahogany bean tree, but it is too much to handle; we make circles around the baobab tree, but it is too much to handle; we makes circles around the well, but it is nothing to jump into in anger.
Yoruba: À ń pòyì ká apá, apá ò ká apá; à ń pòyì ká oṣè, apá ò ká oṣè; à ń pòyì ká kànga, kò ṣé bínú kó sí.

English: “We know not what God will do” keeps one from committing suicide.
Yoruba: “A ò mọ̀yí Ọlọ́run yó ṣe” kò jẹ́ ká bínú kú.

English: A giant rat is killed on an okra farm and thrown it into a sack containing okra leaves; the giant rat has arrived at its home.
Yoruba: A pa ẹmọ́ lóko ilá, a jù ú sí ọ̀kẹ́ ìlasa; ilé ẹmọ́ lẹmọ́ lọ.

English: The needle will pass before the way of the thread is blocked.
Yoruba: Abẹ́rẹ́ á lọ kí ọ̀nà okùn tó dí.

English: He who summons others to render him communal help seeks enemies.
Yoruba: Abẹ̀wẹ̀ ń wá ọ̀tá fúnra ẹ̀.

English: Nursing mother, enemy of the barren woman; working person, enemy of the idler.
Yoruba: Abiyamọ ọ̀tá àgàn; ẹní ń ṣiṣẹ́ ọ̀tá ọ̀lẹ.

English: The pregnant woman delivered; her sides are much eased.
Yoruba: Aboyún bí, ìhá tù ú.

English: Bat, who slept by the orange tree, found no orange to pick, let alone parrot who said it came over very early at dawn.
Yoruba: Àdán tó sùn sídìí ọsàn ò rí he, áḿbọ̀sì oódẹ tó ní òún jí dé.

English: Adékànḿbí is not contesting a title; he is merely asking a question.
Yoruba: Adékànḿbí ò du oyè; ó bèèrè ni.

English: The aftertaste of the bitterleaf is sweet.
Yoruba: Adùn ní ń gbẹ̀yìn ewúro.

English: One's delight in a cloth costing a hundred and forty cowries is over; one spreads it out to show to seven people, one finds seven lice, and on the seventh day it is torn.
Yoruba: Adùn-ún tán lára aṣọ ogóje; a nà án han ẹni méje; a bẹ̀ ẹ́ wò a rí iná méje; ó di ọjọ́ keje ó fàya.

English: He-who-eats-corn-meal-with-bean-fritters does not know the virtues of stew.
Yoruba: A-fàkàrà-jẹ̀kọ́ ò mọ iyì ọbẹ̀.

English: The wind does not blow against the liquid inside a coconut and cause it to spill.
Yoruba: Afẹ́fẹ́ kì í fẹ́ kí omi inú àgbọn dànù.

English: Glaring wildly does not bespeak manliness.
Yoruba: Àfẹjútoto ò mọ ọkùnrin.

English: Blowing from all directions is how one blows at a fire “to kindle it”.
Yoruba: Àfẹ́ká là ń fẹ́ iná.

English: The Catholic missionary is not in the pay of the British administration.
Yoruba: Àgùdà ò jẹ lábẹ̀ẹ Gẹ̀ẹ́sì.

English: It is an elder who lacks the authority to send a child on an errand who tells the child to go fetch water so they could drink it together.
Yoruba: Àgbà tí kò tó ọmọdéé rán níṣẹ́ ní ńsọ pé kó bu omi wá ká jo mú.

English: A foster child does not become one's own child.
Yoruba: Àgbàbọ́ ò di tẹni.

English: Borrowed trousers, if they are not too tight around the legs, they will be too loose; one's own things fit one exactly.
Yoruba: Àgbàbọ̀ọ ṣòkòtò, bí kò fúnni lẹ́sẹ̀ a ṣoni; rẹ́mú-rẹ́mú ni ohun ẹni ń bani mu.

English: It is completely that smoke fills the forest.
Yoruba: Àgbàká lèéfí ń gba igbó.

English: It is completely that the feet take over a path.
Yoruba: Àgbàká lẹsẹ̀ ńgba ọ̀na.

English: Despite all difficulties, the animal àgbaǹgbá sprouts prominent horns on its head.
Yoruba: Àgbaǹgbá ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀, ó làwo lórí san-san.

English: It is not the flood that will make away with the river.
Yoruba: Àgbàrá kọ́ ni yó gbèé omi lọ.

English: It is completely that goitre takes over the neck.
Yoruba: Àgbàtán ni gẹ̀gẹ̀ńgba ọ̀fun.

English: A farmer remains on the farm and sees the moon.
Yoruba: Àgbẹ̀ gbóko róṣù.

English: Groaning-internally is how an antelope groans; rumbling-internally is how a leopard rumbles, the grunts of a pig stay inside the pig.
Yoruba: Àgbinsínú legbin ń gbin; àkùnsínú lẹkùn ń kùn; hùn hùn hùn ẹlẹ́dẹ̀ inú ẹlẹ́dẹ̀ ní ń gbé.

English: He-who-places-his-hopes-on-inheritance delivers himself to destitution.
Yoruba: Agbójúlógún fi araa rẹ̀ fóṣì ta.

English: Baying-and-surviving is the fate of the deer; whenever a deer bays, on that day its death is averted.
Yoruba: Àgbólà ni tàgbọ̀nrín; ọjọ́ tí àgbọ̀nrín bá gbó ni ọjọ́ ikúu rẹ̀ ń yẹ̀.

English: Not standing still is what is described as dancing.
Yoruba: Àìdúró là ń pè níjó.

English: It is not-having-attained-the-age-for-losing-one's-teeth that makes one cover (the mouth) with one's hand.
Yoruba: Àìtó eyín-ín ká ni à ń fọwọ́ bò ó.

English: A domesticated dog does not know how to hunt.
Yoruba: Ajá ilé ò mọdẹẹ́ ṣe.

English: The snare does not snare a cat's paw.
Yoruba: Àjà kì í jìn mọ́ ológbò lẹ́sẹ̀.

English: A dog that will chew dried corn must be brave; a cat that will eat a frog will dip its face in water.
Yoruba: Ajá tó máa rún ọkà á láyà; ológbò to máa jẹ àkèré á ki ojú bọ omi.

English: It is an agile dog that kills a squirrel.
Yoruba: Ajá wéré-wéré ní ń pa ikún.

English: The dog looks at birds with eyes full of disdain.
Yoruba: Ajá wo ẹyẹ láwòmọ́jú.

English: Wealth throws a person away like a stone.
Yoruba: Ajé sọ ọmọ nù bí òkò.

English: Eating without adverse effects is the vulture's way of consuming sacrificial offerings.
Yoruba: Àjẹgbé nigún ń jẹbọ.

English: You who have fallen into the dungeon, do not be impatient to arrive home; when the toad drops into a pit it cannot be impatient to get out.
Yoruba: Ajìnfìn, má ta ojú ilé; ọ̀pọ̀lọ́ jìnfìn má ta ojú àtijáde.

English: The sit-tight person denies the tentative sitter a place.
Yoruba: A-jókò-ó-kunkun ò jẹ́ kí a-jókòó-jẹ́jẹ́ ó jókòo.

English: Familial obligations do not extend to diseases; let each person look well to his or her arms.
Yoruba: Àjùmọ̀bí ò kan ti àrùn; kí alápá mú apáa rẹ̀ kó le.

English: He-who-plucks-the-African-locustbean-tree-seeds-to-sell spends death's money.
Yoruba: A-ká-ìgbá-tà-á náwó ikú.

English: The arrow for a warthog is a major project; an ordinary poison has no effect on the cat.
Yoruba: Àkànṣe lọfà ìmàdò; jagan oró ò ran èse.

English: Scorpion says that its status transcends what-type-of-insect-is-this?
Yoruba: Àkèekèé ní òún kúrò ní kòkòròo kí nìyí?

English: The scorpion travels accompanied by venom.
Yoruba: Àkèekèé rìn tapó-tapó.

English: For the exceptionally brave person the proper profession is warring; for the gregarious person, trading; the illustrious he-goat, even when it is poor, finds enough to eat.
Yoruba: Akíkanjú-kankan, ogun ní ń lọ; abùwàwà, ọjà ní ń ná; àkànní òbúkọ, bó bá tòṣì a máa rí jẹ.

English: It is completely that goitre takes over the throat.
Yoruba: Àkótán ni gẹ̀gẹ̀ ń kó ọ̀fun.

English: The cock crows, and the lazy person hisses.
Yoruba: Àkùkọọ́ kọ, ọ̀lẹẹ́ pòṣé.

English: The chameleon has given birth to its young; inability to dance is the responsibility of the child.
Yoruba: Alágẹmọọ́ ti bímọọ rẹ̀ ná; àìmọ̀-ọ́jó kù sọ́wọ́ọ rẹ̀.

English: She who borrows a wrapper-skirt to wear is not home free; the owner of the cloth will take it back come tomorrow.
Yoruba: Alágbàró ò yege; aláṣọ á gbà á bó dọ̀la.

English: A person with cross-bows in his eyes cannot kill an animal.
Yoruba: Alákatam̀pò ojú ò lè ta ẹran pa.

English: The lizard that fell from atop the ìrókò tree without breaking its limbs says if no one admires his feat, he will do the admiring himself.
Yoruba: Aláǹgbá tó já látorí ìrókò tí kò fẹsẹ̀ ṣẹ́, ó ní bẹ́nìkan ò yìn un òun ó yinra òun.

English: It is the owner of the body that elevates the body; when a chicken wishes to enter the porch it stoops.
Yoruba: Alára ní ńgbáraá ga; bádíẹ́ bá máa wọ̀ọ̀dẹ̀ a bẹ̀rẹ̀.

English: He-who-can-fight-but-cannot-fight-for-long, the equal of a coward.
Yoruba: A-lèjà-má-lè-jà-pẹ́, ẹlẹgbẹ́ ojo.

English: The lump is only the head's visitor.
Yoruba: Àlejò orí ni kókó.

English: One's arms are one's relatives; one's elbows are one's siblings by the same mother.
Yoruba: Apá lará; ìgbọ̀nwọ́ niyèkan.

English: The potsherd lives on the farm but does not decay.
Yoruba: Àpáàdìí gbóko kò rà.

English: Killing-without-recourse is Orò's way of killing trees.
Yoruba: Àpagbé lOrò ń pagi.

English: It is a bald person that may be disdainful of the razor.
Yoruba: Apárí ní ń fojú di abẹ.

English: A person who waits patiently for a long time before eating will not eat unwholesome food.
Yoruba: Apẹ́ẹ́jẹ kì í jẹ ìbàjẹ́.

English: Scooping a spring dry does not stop more water from collecting.
Yoruba: Àpọntán kò wí pé kí odò má sun.

English: A body cannot be too heavy for the owner to lift.
Yoruba: Ara kì í wúwo kí alára má lè gbe.

English: My body can endure chills, and can endure coldness.
Yoruba: Araà mí gba òtútù, ó gba ọ̀nini.

English: The huge sik-cotton tree belittles the axe.
Yoruba: Àràbà ńlá fojú di àáké.

English: A subordinate military officer who is audacious is the equal of his superior.
Yoruba: Ààrẹ àgòrò tó bá gbójú, tòun tolúwa rẹ̀ lẹgbẹ́ra.

English: Having an opportunity to act is also having an opportunity to tell stories.
Yoruba: Àríṣe làríkà.

English: It is only the noise of the whirlwind that reaches heaven.
Yoruba: Ariwo àjìjà ní ń dọ́run.

English: Àro stayed so long on the farm that he forgot how to beat the drum.
Yoruba: Àroó pẹ́ lóko, kò tún mọ ìlùú lù.

English: It is the person in a hurry who studies the complexion of the day.
Yoruba: Asúrétete ní ń wojú ọjọ́.

English: The kite does not snatch chicks in secret, it snatches them openly.
Yoruba: Àṣá ò gbádìẹ níkọ̀kọ̀; gbangba làṣá ń gbádìẹ.

English: The kite cannot swoop down and carry off a goat.
Yoruba: Àṣá ò lè balẹ̀ kó gbéwúrẹ́.

English: The kite looks long at the tortoise; the eagle looks long at the tortoise; what can the hawk, father of the kite, do to the tortoise?
Yoruba: Àṣá wo ahun títí; àwòdí wo ahun títí; idì baba àṣá, kí ló lè fi ahun ṣe?

English: The kite looks slyly at the snail, but its shell stops the bird from snatching it.
Yoruba: Àṣá wo ìgbín kọ̀rọ̀; ìkaraun-un rẹ̀ ò jẹ́ kó gbé e.

English: The kite watches the monkey but has no hands to carry it off.
Yoruba: Àṣá wọ̀bọ kò rọ́wọ́ gbé e.

English: The secrets of the hyena's being will not be revealed through the actions of the dog.
Yoruba: Àṣírí ìkokò, ajá kọ́ ni yó tùú u.

English: One's palm does not deceive one.
Yoruba: Àtẹ́lẹwọ́ ẹni kì í tanni.

English: The space is never so tight that a chicken will not be able to reach its incubating nest.
Yoruba: Àyè kì í há adìẹ kó má dèé ìdí àbaa rẹ̀.

English: The more one peels the bark of the baobab, the fatter it becomes.
Yoruba: Bí a bá ń pa èpo oṣè, ṣe ní ń máaá sanra sí i.

English: If one does not experience enough suffering to fill a basket, one cannot enjoy enough good to fill a cup.
Yoruba: Bí a kò bá jìyà tó kún agbọ̀n; a ò lè jẹ oore tó kún ahá.

English: If one does not act like a pig on the way to Ikòròdú one cannot act like Adégbọrọ̀at the king's market.
Yoruba: Bí a kò bá ṣe bí ẹlẹ́dẹ̀ lọ́nà Ìkòròdú, a ò lè ṣe bí Adégbọrọ̀ lọ́jà ọba.

English: If a lazy person is suffering from hunger, he/she should be left to die.
Yoruba: Bí ebí bá ń pa ọ̀lẹ, à jẹ́ kó kú.

English: If a poor person's forked stake is not long enough in the morning, it will be long enough at night.
Yoruba: Bí ẹkẹ́ẹ tálákà ò tó lówùúrọ̀, á tó lálẹ́.

English: If a person does not extend greetings to one, God's greetings are worth more than two hundred peoples'.
Yoruba: Bí ẹnìkan ò kíni “Kú-ù-jokòó,” kíkí Ọlọ́run-ún ju ti igba èèyàn lọ.

English: A slave that would eat intestines must begin with the liver.
Yoruba: Bí ẹrú yó bàá jẹ ìfun, ibi ẹ̀dọ̀ níí tí ń bẹ̀rẹ̀.

English: When the cub becomes a grown leopard, it kills animals for food.
Yoruba: Bí ẹ̀yá bá dẹkùn, ẹran ní ńpajẹ.

English: If the pedigree is bent, if the pedigree is crooked, each person will play the father in his own home.
Yoruba: Bí ìbí bá tẹ̀, bí ìbí bá wọ́, oníkálukú a máa ṣe baba nílé araa rẹ̀.

English: When day breaks the lazy person will still be asleep.
Yoruba: Bí ilẹ̀ẹ́ bá mọ́, ojú orun lọ̀lẹ ń wà.

English: If lice are not completely gone from one's clothings, one's nails will not be free of blood.
Yoruba: Bí iná kò bá tán láṣọ, ẹ̀jẹ̀ kì í tán léèékánná.

English: If a youth is in the grips of excessive privations, he should go after an elephant; if he kills an elephant his privations will be over; if an elephant kills him, his privations will be over.
Yoruba: Bí ìṣẹ́ bá ń ṣẹ́ ọ̀dọ́ láṣẹ̀ẹ́jù, kó lọ sígbó erin; bó bá pa erin ìṣẹ́ẹ rẹ̀ a tán; bí erín bá pá a, ìṣẹ́ẹ rẹ̀ a tán.

English: If one cannot go forward, one will be able to retreat.
Yoruba: Bí iwájú ò bá ṣeé lọ sí, ẹ̀yìn a ṣeé padà sí.

English: However numerous the cattle might be, it is with only one staff that the Fulbe man herds them.
Yoruba: Bí màlúù tó màlúù, ọ̀pá kan ni Fúlàní fi ń dà wọ́n.

English: “If I must die let me die” is what makes a man strong; “I simply will not court death” is what makes a man lazy or cowardly.
Yoruba: “Bí mo lè kú ma kú” lọmọkùrín fi ń lágbárá “N ò lè wáá kú” lọmọkùnrín fi ń lẹ.

English: However long it may take, the stammarer will eventually say, “Father.”
Yoruba: Bí ó pẹ́ títí, akólòlò á pe baba.

English: In time, a sojourner becomes a native.
Yoruba: Bí ó pẹ́ títí, àlejò á di onílé.

English: One practices one's Islam as one pleases; if the Imam wishes he may break his fast with pork.
Yoruba: Bí ó ti wuni là ń ṣe ìmàle ẹni; bó wu Lèmó̩mù a fẹlẹ́dẹ̀ jẹ sààrì.

English: If one is sure of one's Ògún cult object, one taps ones head with it.
Yoruba: Bí Ògún ẹní bá dánilójú, à fi gbárí.

English: If one's eyes do not become as red as camwood stain, one does not come by something as red as brass.
Yoruba: Bí ojú kò pọ́nni bí osùn, a kì í he ohun pupa bí idẹ.

English: If what one bought for one's money does not fill one, the little extra thrown into the bargain will not.
Yoruba: Bí ojú owó ẹni ò yóni, ènì ò lè yóni.

English: When day dawns the cattle egret makes for the home of the dealer in chalk, the blue touraco heads for the home of the indigo dealer, the purple àlúkò bird seeks out the dealer in camwood resin.
Yoruba: Bí ojúmọ́ mọ́ lékèélékèé a yalé ẹlẹ́fun, agbe a yalé aláró, àlùkò a yalé olósùn.

English: If the hand does not cease going down and going to the mouth, satiation results.
Yoruba: Bí ọwọ́ kò sin ilẹ̀, tí kò sin ẹnu, ayo ní ń jẹ́.

English: Even though Ṣango kills the silk-cotton tree and kills the ìrókò tree, no such fate can befall the huge tree.
Yoruba: Bí Ṣàǹgó bá ńpa àràbà, tó ń pa ìrókò, bíi tigi ńlá kọ́.

English: Dàńdógò is not a garment for the young.
Yoruba: Dàńdógó kì í ṣe ẹ̀wù ọmọdé.

English: One should give everything a try; if one's owner dies one goes to claim his wife.
Yoruba: Dídán là ń dán ọ̀ràn wò; bí olówó ẹní kú, à lọ ṣúpó.

English: A perpetually shining appearance is what chracterizes the pigeon even until death.
Yoruba: Dídán lẹyẹlé ń dán kú.

English: It is bit by bit that rats eat leather.
Yoruba: Díẹ̀-díẹ̀ leku ń jawọ.

English: It is bit by bit that a bird eats an orange.
Yoruba: Díẹ̀-díẹ̀ lẹyẹ ń mu ọsàn.

English: Gradual efforts complete a task.
Yoruba: Díẹ̀-díẹ̀ ní ń tánṣẹ́.

English: The talking drum endures all matters without complaint.
Yoruba: Dùndún fọ̀ràn gbogbo ṣàpamọ́ra.

English: A single heap on the farm does not warrant “I am just about done.”
Yoruba: Ebè kan ṣoṣo àkùrọ́ kúrò ní “Mo fẹ́rẹ̀ẹ́ ṣíwọ́.”

English: It is hunger that will force sense into the imbecile.
Yoruba: Ebi ni yó kọ̀ọ́ wèrè lọ́gbọ́n.

English: The snake is hungry, and the tortoise saunters by.
Yoruba: Ebí ń pa ejò, ahún ń yan.

English: Hunger keeps one from folding one's hands; hunger causes the mouth “or cheeks” to shrink.
Yoruba: Ebi ò jẹ́ ká pa ọwọ́ mọ́; ebí ṣenú papala.

English: Insults do not attach to one's body like pods.
Yoruba: Èébú kì í so.

English: No charm can act upon the day and keep it from dawning.
Yoruba: Èdì kì í mú ọjọ́ kó má là.

English: The masquerader who is accustomed to eating horse heads will not be daunted by ram heads.
Yoruba: Eégún tí ń jẹ orí ẹṣin, orí àgbò ò lè kò ó láyà.

English: Okro that has gone fibrous has delivered itself from the knife.
Yoruba: Èkó ilá gba ara ẹ̀ lọ́wọ́ ọ̀bẹ.

English: Being bothered by sandflies is no misfortune.
Yoruba: Èminrin ń jẹni, kò tó ìyà.

English: An angry curse does not kill an enemy.
Yoruba: Èpè ìbínú ò pa odì.

English: The curses of okro leaves do not affect the deer.
Yoruba: Èpè ìlasa kì í ja àgbọ̀nrín.

English: Creeping weeds cannot kill the silk rubber tree.
Yoruba: Èpò ìbúlẹ̀ kì í pa irẹ́.

English: The elephant forages a long time without cutting its hand on a spear; the buffalo forages a long time without falling into a trap; numerous small birds fly across the sky without colliding with trees.
Yoruba: Erín jẹ̀ jẹ̀ jẹ̀ kò fọwọ́ kọ́ aṣá; ẹ̀fọ́n jẹ̀ jẹ̀ jẹ̀ kò ki ẹsẹ̀ wọ pòòlò; ẹyẹ kékéèké ń fò lókè wọn ò forí gbági.

English: Error does not await the king before it dons a crown; Ogunṣọṣẹ  does not wait for the sun before it dons a bloody cloak; the flower does not wait for the sun before it brightens; brightness comes with the child from its house.
Yoruba: Èṣì ò rọ́ba dádé; Ògúnṣọṣẹ́ ò róòrùn wẹ̀wù ẹ̀jẹ̀; òdòdó ò róòrùn pọ́n; ilé ọmọ lọmọ́ ti pọ́n wá.

English: The fly is procuring wine while the worm is cooking bean-meal, and the sugar-fly asks them to find something to cork the gourd so nothing would enter into it.
Yoruba: Eṣinṣín ń pọntí; ekòló ń ṣú ọ̀lẹ̀lẹ̀; kantí-kantí ní ká wá nǹkan dí agbè lẹ́nu kí nǹkankan má kòó sí i.

English: The locusts are done feeding, the locusts have departed; the locusts have gone to Wata, their home.
Yoruba: Eṣú jẹ oko tán eṣù lọ; eṣú lọ Wata, ilée rẹ̀.

English: As far as the broom is concerned it is taboo: one does not make kindling of broomsticks.
Yoruba: Èèwọ̀ ni tọwọ̀; a kì í figi ọwọ̀ dáná.

English: The African black kite is never killed in a brushfire emergency.
Yoruba: Ewu iná kì í pa àwòdì.

English: The goat is celebrating an event, the sheep is in a procession with drums, and the he-goat asks to be accompanied to its in-law's home.
Yoruba: Ewúrẹ́ ń ṣọdún, àgùtán gbàlù sẹ́yìn, òbúkọọ́ ní ká sin òun lọ sílé àna òun.

English: A goat can in no wise take the fig tree's leaves aloft for any purpose.
Yoruba: Ewúrẹ́ ò lè rí ewé ọdán òkè fi ṣe nǹkan.

English: The bitter-leaf did not become bitter as a result of cowardice.
Yoruba: Ewúro ò fi tojo korò.

English: Whether a person be short or ugly, if there is no debt, there can be no disgrace.
Yoruba: Èèyàn ìbáà kúrú, ìbáà búrẹ́wà, gbèsè ò sí, ìtìjú ò sí.

English: The consumption of sacrificial offerings will not kill the vulture.
Yoruba: Ẹbọ jíjẹ kì í pa igún.

English: A thousand ants cannot lift “a cube of” sugar; they can only mill around it in vain.
Yoruba: Ẹgbẹ̀rún eèrà ò lè gbé ṣúgà; wọ́n ó kàn tò yí i ká lásán ni.

English: A thousand fishes will not overload a river.
Yoruba: Ẹgbẹ̀rún ẹja ò lè dẹ́rù pa odò.

English: A cat's back never touches the ground.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀yìn ológbò kì í balẹ̀.

English: The lawyer argues other people's cases, much more his own.
Yoruba: Ẹjọ́ ẹlẹ́jọ́, lọ́yà ń rò ó, áḿbọ̀ǹtorí ẹjọ́ araa rẹ̀.

English: An apprehender does not apprehend a masquerader.
Yoruba: Ẹlẹ́mùn-ún ò mú eégún.

English: The larkheeled Cuckoo vows that rather than not being delicious in the stew, it will crush its arms and legs in pursuit of that end.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀lúlùú ní kàkà kí òun má dun ọbẹ̀, òun á rúnwọ rúnsẹ̀ sí i.

English: It is the Ẹ̀lukú masquerader without a matchete that is hacked to death by its colleagues.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀lukú tí kò ní èlè lẹgbẹ́ẹ rẹ̀ ń ṣá pa.

English: Whoever has a job should not malinger; if Providence smiles on one one can hardly fail.
Yoruba: Ẹní bá ń ṣiṣẹ́ kì í ṣọ̀lẹ; bórí bá túnniṣe a kì í tẹ́ bọ̀rọ̀.

English: Whoever is used to eating full-grown he-goats will eat lambs that have sprouted horns.
Yoruba: Ẹní bá ń jẹ òbúkọ tó gbójú, yó jẹ àgùtàn tó yọ̀wo.

English: The same person who weeds the road to Ìjẹ̀bú without carrying off the weeds will eventually remove them.
Yoruba: Ẹní bá yẹ ọ̀nà Ìjẹ̀bú tì ni yó yẹ̀ ẹ́ tán.

English: The person who takes one's wife cannot stop one's locust bean seeds from fermenting.
Yoruba: Ẹní gbani láya ò ní kírú ẹni má rà.

English: Whoever wishes to eat heartily must lock his door firmly.
Yoruba: Ẹní máa jẹun kunkun a tìlẹ̀kùn kunkun.

English: Whoever wishes to see a crab go to sleep will stay long by its hole.
Yoruba: Ẹní máa rí àtisùn akàn á pẹ́ létí isà.

English: Whoever will eat the honey in a rock does not worry about the edge of the axe.
Yoruba: Ẹní máa jẹ oyin inú àpáta kìí wo ẹnu àáké.

English: Whoever wishes to see ducks go to sleep will go into debt paying for (fuel) oil.
Yoruba: Ẹní máa rí àtisùn-un pẹ́pẹ́yẹ á jẹ gbèsè àdín.

English: Ògún is on the side of the swift.
Yoruba: Ẹní yára lÒgún ń gbè.

English: Whoever is shunned by people should rejoice; whoever is shunned by God should look out.
Yoruba: Ẹni èèyàn ò kí kó yọ̀; ẹni Ọlọ́run ò kí kó ṣọ́ra.

English: Whoever dies from poverty dies a miserable death; whoever dies from work dies a noble death.
Yoruba: Ẹni ọ̀lẹ́ paá re ọ̀run òṣì; ẹni iṣẹ́ paá re ọ̀run ẹ̀yẹ.

English: The person who plants a hundred yam seedlings and says he planted two hundred, after he has eaten a hundred truths, he will come to eat a hundred lies.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó gbin ọrún èbù tó pè é nígba, tó bá jẹ ọgọ́rùn-ún òtítọ́ tán, á wá jẹ ọgọ́rùn-ún irọ́.

English: It is for the person who sweeps the floor that the floor is clean.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó gbálẹ̀ ni ilẹ̀ ń mọ́ fún.

English: It is the industrious person that wins the spoils.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó bá ní ìtara ló ní àtètèbá.

English: The person being chased by a masquerader should persevere; just as an earthling tires, so does the being from heaven.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí eégún ń lé kó máa rọ́jú; bó ti ń rẹ ará ayé, bẹ́ẹ̀ ní ń rẹ ará ọ̀run.

English: Whoever dives head first to the ground has made a creditable attempt at suicide.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó forí sọlẹ̀ẹ́ gbìyànjú ikú.

English: A person fed by others is never aware that there is famine.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí à ḿbọ́ ò mọ̀ pé ìyàn-án mú.

English: Whoever leaps up decapitates dance.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó fò sókèé bẹ́ ijó lórí.

English: A person dying from overwork is better than a person dying of destitution.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí iṣẹ́ ń paá yá ju ẹni tí ìṣẹ́ ń pa.

English: Those who arrive late are the ones who find the watery residue of the stew awaiting them.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó bá pẹ́ lẹ́yìn ni à ń yọ́ omi ọbẹ̀ dè.

English: The man who “claimed to have” killed six people during the Ọla war: people exclaimed in disbelief, “Ha, ha, ha!” He asked them to bring an ayò board, and he won six games. He said, if there were no witnesses for what happened in the secluded forest, aren't there witnesses for what happens in the house?
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó pa mẹ́fà lógun Ọ̀la: wọ́n ní “Háà, hà, háà!” Ó ní kí wọ́n gbé ọpọ́n ayò wá, ó tún pa mẹ́fà; ó ní bí ojú kò tó tẹ̀gi, ojú kò tó tilé?

English: The person digging a grave is the one performing his or her funerary duties; the person crying is merely making a noise.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ń gbẹ́lẹ̀ ní ń sìnkú; ẹni tí ń sunkún ariwo ló ń pa.

English: Only a person who looks at the bride's face knows that the bride is crying.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó bá wo ojú ìyàwó ní ń mọ̀ pé ìyàwó ń sunkún.

English: Whoever likes fineries should engage in a trade; it is the person blessed by riches that is wise.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ọ̀ṣọ́ bá wù kó ṣòwò; ẹni ajé yalée rẹ̀ ló gbọ́n.

English: Only those whose livelihood depends on Jẹgẹdẹ call him a silk cotton tree.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó bá ńjẹ lábẹ́ẹ Jẹ́gẹ́dẹ́ ní ńpè é nígi àràbà.

English: Whoever assigns a task to Ìgè Àdùbí assigns it to himself or herself; Ìgè Àdùbí will neither agree to do the task nor will he refuse.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó bẹ Ìgè Àdùbí níṣẹ́, araa rẹ̀ ló bẹ̀; Ìgè Àdùbí ò níí jẹ́, bẹ́ẹ̀ni kò níí kọ̀.

English: A person whose greetings do not fill one's stomach cannot cause one to starve by withholding the greetings.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí kíkíi rẹ̀ ò yóni, àìkíi rẹ̀ ò lè pani lébi.

English: It is at one's occupation that one proves oneself an idler.
Yoruba: Ẹnu iṣẹ́ ẹni ni a ti ń mọ ẹni lọ́lẹ.

English: Empty mouths do not make chewing noises.
Yoruba: Ẹnu òfìfo kì í dún yànmù-yànmù.

English: The mouth cooks vegetable stew most expertly; the hand emulating a machete cuts a field most effortlessly.
Yoruba: Ẹnú dùn-ún ròfọ́; agada ọwọ́ dùn-ún ṣánko.

English: The forest knows no fear, and neither does the river know fear; the grind-stone never shows fear in the face of pepper.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀rù kì í ba igbó, bẹ́ẹ̀ni kì í ba odò; ẹ̀rù kì í ba ọlọ lójú ata.

English: The head is never so frightened that it disappears into the shoulder.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀rù kì í ba orí kó sá wọnú.

English: Fear of battle never afflicts a warrior.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀rù ogun kì í ba jagun-jagun.

English: The feet are never so heavy that the owner cannot lift them.
Yoruba: Ẹsẹ̀ kì í wúwo kí ẹlésẹ̀ má lè gbé e.

English: Slowly slowly is the way a snail climbs a tree.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀sọ̀ ẹ̀sọ̀ ni ìgbín fi ń gbà gun igi.

English: One does not refrain from mounting a horse that has thrown one.
Yoruba: Ẹṣin kì í dani kí á má tún gùn ún.

English: A horse does not get loose and stop to free its companion.
Yoruba: Ẹṣin kì í já kó já èkejìi rẹ̀.

English: Disgrace comes upon the shiftless.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀tẹ́ bá ọ̀lẹ.

English: A bird does not tell a bird that a stone is on its way.
Yoruba: Ẹyẹ ò sọ fún ẹyẹ pé òkò ń bọ̀.

English: Leave the hooked stick alone for the leaf plucker; leave the husband alone for the jealous woman.
Yoruba: Fi gọ̀gọ̀ sílẹ̀ fún ọ̀dáwé; fi ọkọ sílẹ̀ fún onílara.

English: It is only because one loves spinach that one calls it a friend of corn loaf; what the dandy has at home is enough food for him or her.
Yoruba: Fífẹ́ la fẹ́ ẹ̀fọ́ tí à ń pèé ní ọ̀rẹ́ ẹ̀kọ ti ilé ogeé tó ogeé jẹ.

English: “Prepare the corn pap and let us eat it together” is an indication that the speaker lacks what it takes to be a husband.
Yoruba: “Fọ́ ẹ̀kọ ká jọ mu ú,” kò tó ọkọlóbìnrin-ín ṣe ni.

English: No carver of mortars can do a thing to the banana stem.
Yoruba: Gbẹ́dó-gbẹ́dó kan ò lè fi ọ̀gẹ̀dẹ̀ ṣe nǹkan.

English: Fear of the snake keeps one from stepping on the young of the snake.
Yoruba: Ìbẹ̀rù ejò ò jẹ́ ká tẹ ọmọ ejò mọ́lẹ̀.

English: Every place is hospitable and comfortable for the dove.
Yoruba: Ibi gbogbo ní ń rọ àdàbà lọ́rùn.

English: Every place deserves to be treated with respect and reverence.
Yoruba: Ibi gbogbo nilẹ̀ ọ̀wọ̀.

English: The spot one cautions the gbégbé plant not to inhabit, there it will surely inhabit.
Yoruba: Ibi tí a ní kí gbégbé má gbèé, ibẹ̀ ní ń gbé.

English: Wherever one orders wild spinach not to step on, there it will surely trample.
Yoruba: Ibi tí a ní kí tẹ̀tẹ̀ má tẹ̀, ibẹ̀ ní ń tẹ̀.

English: How much distance exists between the nose and the mouth? How much distance exists between Làǹlátẹ̀ and Èrúwà?
Yoruba: Ibo ni imú wà sẹnu? Ibo ni Làǹlátẹ̀ẹ́ wà sí Èrúwà?

English: The sword never departs without returning.
Yoruba: Idà kì í lọ kídà má bọ̀.
