English: Whoever would have children of her own must rejoice with those who already have.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó bá máa bímọ á yọ̀ fọ́lọ́mọ.

English: Whoever has reached the top, let him or her pull his or her friend by the hand; whoever has food to eat, let him or her share it with his or her friend.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó gòkè, kó fa ọ̀rẹ́ẹ rẹ̀ lọ́wọ́; ẹni tó rí jẹ, kó fún ọ̀rẹ́ẹ rẹ̀ jẹ.

English: Whoever asks about a matter genuinely wishes to know its causes.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó bèèrè ọ̀rọ̀ ló fẹ́ ìdíi rẹ̀ ẹ́gbọ́.

English: A person whom one does a favor but who shows no gratitude is like a robber who has stolen one's goods.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí a ṣe lóore tí kò dúpẹ́, bí ọlọ́ṣà kóni lẹ́rù ni.

English: The person who adorns herself with beads has done the ultimate in self-beautifying; the person who gives one a child (in marriage) has done the ultimate in favor.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó so ìlẹ̀kẹ̀ parí ọ̀ṣọ́; ẹni tó fúnni lọ́mọ parí oore.

English: Whoever defames others defames himself or herself.
Yoruba: Ẹni tí ó ṣe ìbàjẹ́ èèyàn-án ṣe ìbàjẹ́ araa rẹ̀.

English: The pigeon hides its own disgrace and goes ridiculing the chicken.
Yoruba: Ẹyẹlé fi ẹ̀sín-in rẹ̀ pamọ́, ó ń ṣe ẹ̀sín adìẹ.

English: The blemish of the yam is the blemish of the knife; whoever besmirches other people's names besmirches his/her own.
Yoruba: Ìbàjẹ́ iṣu nìbàjẹ́ ọ̀bẹ; ẹni tó ṣe ìbàjẹ́ èèyàn-án ṣe ìbàjẹ́ ara ẹ̀.

English: The calabash of a kind-heated person never breaks; the china plate of a kind-hearted person never cracks; both riches and children ever converge in the home of a kind-hearted person.
Yoruba: Igbá olóore kì í fọ́; àwo olóore kì í fàya; towó tọmọ ní ń ya ilé olóore.

English: The calabash belonging to a patient person never breaks; the china plate belonging to a patient person never cracks.
Yoruba: Igbá onípẹ̀lẹ́ kì í fọ́; àwo onípẹ̀lẹ́ kì í fàya.

English: The home of a kind-hearted person never collapses completely; the home of a wicked person always collapses, leaving nothing standing.
Yoruba: Ilé olóore kì í wó tán; tìkà kì í wó kù.

English: To visit the home of a generous person is to be plied with food aplenty; who would think of visiting a miser?
Yoruba: Ilé ọ̀ṣọnú àyàyó; ta ní jẹ́ yalé ahun-káhun?

English: Ill will “is the” medicine that ensures misfortune.
Yoruba: Inú búburú, oògùn òṣì.

English: Good will towards others does not kill; it only gets one into trouble.
Yoruba: Inúure kì í pani, wàhálà ní ń kó báni.

English: “The pounded yam is good and the stew is delicious” killed Akíndélé on his farm at Ìgbájọ́ “God, I will not give you some food to eat” is what killed the priest at Ìkiré.
Yoruba: “Iyán dára, ọbẹ̀ẹ́ dùn” ló pa Akíndélé lóko Ìgbájọ; “Òrìṣà, n kò fún ọ ní èdì jẹ” ló pa abọrìṣà Ìkirè.

English: The wife ate the yam-flour meal and ate the calabash with it.
Yoruba: Ìyàwó jẹ ọkà jẹ igbá.

English: One may slash at it and slash at it, and one may shake the sand from its roots for ever, but nothing affects the eéran grass like being abandoned.
Yoruba: Kí á ṣá a ṣá a, kí á gbọ̀n ọ́n gbọ̀n ọ́n; ká fi oko eéran sílẹ̀ ló dá eéran lára.

English: “This thing is not plentiful; I cannot give you some of it”: the person is a miser.
Yoruba: “Kiní yìí ò pọ̀; n ò lè fún ọ níbẹ̀”: olúwarẹ̀ ahun ni.

English: “This thing that you have given me is not plentiful”: that statement indicates a greedy person.
Yoruba: “Kiní yìí tí o fún mi ò pọ̀”: ahun ní ń jẹ́ bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: He-will-not-bring-what-he-has will not have what one has.
Yoruba: Kò mú ti ọwọ́ ẹ̀ wá ò gba tọwọ́ ẹni.

English: “We have nothing, we have nothing!” Yet their children always have full stomachs.
Yoruba: Kò sí kò sí; bẹ́ẹ̀ni ọmọ wọn ń yó.

English: “There is not much of it” is what turns one into a miser.
Yoruba: Kò tó nǹkan ní ń sọni dahun.

English: “Do not share in my delicious meal,” chases away the animal.
Yoruba: “Má bàá mi jẹ ìdùn,” ẹran ní ń lé lọ.

English: “Just so you won't find my hand empty” roasted popcorn for the masquerader; the masquerader also responded with “Just so you won't find my hands empty” and gave him a wooden doll.
Yoruba: “Má fẹ̀ẹ́ ọwọ́ọ̀ mi kù” tí ń yan gúgúrú fún eégún; eégún náàá ní “Má fẹ̀ẹ́ ọwọ́ọ̀ mi kù”; ó fún un ní ọmọláńgidi.

English: Had I money I would cook bean meal for the Agọ́n masquerader; the brown monkey's raiding of his farm never elicits a complaint from him.
Yoruba: M̀bá-lówó-m̀bá-se-ọ̀lẹ̀lẹ̀-fún-Agọ́n: ìjímèrè kì í jẹ oko ẹ̀ kó sọ̀.

English: “Bring! Bring!” is the sound of the pigeon's wings.
Yoruba: “Mú wá, mú wá” lapá ẹyẹlé ń ké.

English: The big spender is not a prodigal.
Yoruba: Náwó-náwó kì í ṣàpà.

English: There you ate, there you drank, and there you fouled.
Yoruba: O jẹbẹ, o mubẹ, o babẹ jẹ́.

English: “Greetings to you at work” cannot invite people's anger.
Yoruba: “O kú iṣẹ́” ò lè bí aráyé nínú.

English: “Its impression on me is tremendous,” such is Arogun's corn meal; I bought only one, but she gave me two hundred as makeweight (or extra measure).
Yoruba: “Ó kún mi lójú,” ẹ̀kọ Arogun; ọ̀kan ṣoṣo ni mo rà, igba ènì ló fi sí i.

English: A small kolanut is superior to a large stone.
Yoruba: Obì kékeré kọjá òkúta ńlá.

English: A woman who bears a child that requires only cold water for all cures has saved her husband much worry; he will never again go searching for medicinal leaves, nor will he go digging roots.
Yoruba: Obìnrin tó bímọ tó bí olómitútù, wàhálà ọkọ ẹ̀ẹ́ dínkù; kò ní já ewé mọ́, bẹ́ẹ̀ni kò ní wa egbò.

English: A woman has a child by you and you still say you do not see her inside “know her mind”; would you have her expose her intestines?
Yoruba: Obínrin-ín bímo fún ọ o ní o ò rínú ẹ̀; o fẹ́ kó o nífun ni?

English: Ògún  does not fashion ivory, the blacksmith does not make shoes; were farming not a difficult pursuit the blacksmith would not manufacture hoes for sale.
Yoruba: Ògún ò rọ ike; àgbẹ̀dẹ ò rọ bàtà; oko ò ṣòroó ro, àgbẹ̀dẹ ò pa ọkọ́ tà.

English: What will help a miser spend his money is right there in his/her pocket.
Yoruba: Ohun tí ń bá ahun náwó ẹ̀ ḿbẹ lápòo ẹ̀.

English: The rain beats the coco-yam leaf; if it will tear, let it tear.
Yoruba: Òjò pa ewée kòkò; bó lè ya kó ya.

English: It is out of regard for onlookers that one sings in praise of the dead; the dead did not prescribe a song before departing this life.
Yoruba: Ojú la rí là ń kọrin òkú, òkú ò forin sáyé kó tó lọ.

English: Eyes are what see look on eyes and fill with kindness.
Yoruba: Ojú ní ń rójú ṣàánú.

English: Only the king of this earth is blind; that of heaven is wide-eyed, watching evil doers.
Yoruba: Ojú ọba ayé ló fọ́; tọ̀rún là kedere, ó ń wo aṣebi.

English: Òkulu asks to whom should he lodge his complaint? Did anybody lodge his complaint with Òkulu?
Yoruba: Òkulú ní ta ni òun ó ro tòun fún? Ta ní wá ro tiẹ̀ fun Òkulu?

English: The goitered person going in front ruins the fortunes of the one coming behind.
Yoruba: Onígẹ̀gẹ̀ ìṣájú ba tìkẹyìn jẹ́.

English: A good deed does not go for nought; a wicked deed is never lost; drowning while doing a favor is what makes the good person lose out on the rewards for his goodness.
Yoruba: Oore kì í gbé; ìkà kì í dànù; à-ṣoore-jindò ní ń múni pàdánù oore.

English: The favor one does a chicken is not for nought; in due course it will make stew to delight one's mouth.
Yoruba: Oore tí a ṣe fádìẹ ò gbé; bó pẹ́ títí a ṣomi tooro síni lẹ́nu.

English: Only a person who thinks of the future commiserates with an orphan; otherwise, who would show kindness to an Ègùn person?
Yoruba: Òrẹ́yìn ní ń ṣe ọmọ òkù pẹ̀lẹ́; ta ní jẹ́ ṣe ọmọ Ègùn lóore?

English: An ill-natured woman will not give birth to twins; only good-natured people give birth to twins.
Yoruba: Òṣónú ò bí èjìrẹ́; onínúure ní ń bí ẹdun.

English: Money is what calls for spending money.
Yoruba: Owó ló ń pe ìná owó.

English: Big shot of Ìwátà towń the locusts do not know who is honest; the locusts arrive and the locusts eat up the good person's farm.
Yoruba: Ọ̀gá Ìwátà, eṣú ò mọ olóòótọ́; eṣú dé, eṣú jẹ oko olóore.

English: The drunkard is not a prodigal; it is his money that he is spending.
Yoruba: Ọ̀mùtí kì í ṣàpà; owó ẹ̀ ló ń ná.

English: There is no compulsion in voluntary work.
Yoruba: Ọ̀ràn-an-yàn ò sí nínúu iyánrán.

English: Wine stays in the home of the miser until it goes sour.
Yoruba: Ọtí gbélé ahun ó kan.

English: The assignment for an invalid must be different from everybody else's.
Yoruba: Ọ̀tọ̀ niṣẹ́ olókùnrùn.

English: Excessive stinginess is what slams the door of fortune in one's face.
Yoruba: Ọwọ́ híhá àhájù ní ń dínà ire mọ́ni.

English: He who derides others steps outside and does not amount to much; it is he who has no basis for bragging that derides others.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀gàn-pẹ̀gàn-án bọ́ sóde kò ní láárí; ẹni tí ò rówó ṣe fújà ní ń pẹ̀gàn ẹni.

English: He who extends kindness beforehand: his goods will not stay long at the frontier.
Yoruba: Ṣe sílẹ̀: ẹrùu ẹ̀ kì í pẹ́ níbodè.

English: The detractor of others does not possess a change of clothing; the garment of the insulter of people is always skimpy.
Yoruba: Ṣẹ̀gàn-ṣẹ̀gàn ò láṣọ méjì; pé-ń-pé laṣọ abúni ḿmọ.

English: The wicked person does a little wickedness to himself or herself.
Yoruba: Ṣìkà-ṣìkà-á fi díẹ̀ ṣe ara ẹ̀.

English: The wicked forgets kinship; the person who hurts others forgets tomorrow.
Yoruba: Ṣìkà-ṣìkà-á gbàgbé àjọbí, adánilóró gbàgbé ọ̀la.

English: The wicked person will never describe himself as wicked.
Yoruba: Ṣìkà-ṣìkà ò jẹ́ pe ara ẹ̀ níkà.

English: Both the leaf and the root take pity on the climbing parasite.
Yoruba: Tewé tegbò ní ń ṣàánú àfòmọ́.

English: Both trees and palms take pity on the climbing plant.
Yoruba: Tigi tọ̀pẹ̀ ní ń ṣàánú àfòmọ́.

English: Both trees and palms extend kindness to the African black pepper plant.
Yoruba: Tigi tọ̀pẹ̀ ní ń sàánú ìyèré lóko.

English: Wickedness or kindness, neither goes for nought.
Yoruba: Tìkà toore, ọ̀kan kì í gbé.

English: Only coolness come out of the fish's mouth.
Yoruba: Tútù ní ń tẹnu ẹja wá.
